headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Laurel, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Navient Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I'll now turn the call over to Joe Fisher, Vice P
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Laurel, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Navient Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I'll now turn the call over to Joe Fisher, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laurel. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2014 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions. Before we begin,
componenttext:
Thank you, Laurel. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2014 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions. 
Before we begin, keep in mind that our discussion will contain predictions, expectations and forward-looking statements. Actual results in the future may be materially different from those discussed here. These could be due to a variety of factors. Listeners should refer to the discussion of those factors in the company's Form 10 and other filings with the SEC. 
During this conference call, we will refer to non-GAAP measures we call our core earnings. A descriptions of core earnings solution to the measures and our GAAP results can be found in the fourth quarter 2014 supplemental earnings disclosure. This is posted along with our earnings press release on the investors page at navient.com. 
Thank you, and I will turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Good morning, and thank you for listening in today. I appreciate your interest and your support. 2014 was a busy and productive year. We started the year as one company with a very long list of tasks to complete and we finished the year as Na
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Good morning, and thank you for listening in today. I appreciate your interest and your support. 2014 was a busy and productive year. We started the year as one company with a very long list of tasks to complete and we finished the year as Navient having successfully completed the legal and operational separation from Sallie Mae. 
While the separation project consumed most of the resources here, we retained our focus on our business, delivering outstanding performance and generating strong financial results. Highlights for the year include: Of course, our completion of the separation from Sallie Mae; the acquisition of $13 billion in student loans; we reduced the private credit charge-offs by 18% to $717 million for the year; our servicing skills enabled our federal loan customers to significantly outperform the national average with a cohort to rate 48% lower than all other servicers; we distributed $849 million to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases; and we generated $2.10 of core earnings per share. 
I'm very pleased with our performance in 2014 and the resulting gains for our shareholders. The separation not only provide proof to be a catalyst to unlock the value of our business, but also to unlock Navient's potential to grow in businesses beyond education finance. 
While I'm proud of our accomplishments in 2014, I want to focus my comments on here and now, our plans for 2015. Our goals for 2015 can be summed up by one word: Growth. We see growth opportunities in each of our operating areas. 
In asset management, we continue to see opportunities to purchase both federal and private loan portfolios. And while we are unlikely to repeat the volume acquired in 2014, we believe there will be substantial opportunities in 2015 as the environmental factors remains unchanged. Our competitive advantage has also remained intact though we did see what we believed to be irrational pricing on some portfolios in late 2014. 
We also see continued opportunities to increase the expected cash flows from our federal and private loan portfolios as credit continues to improve and we benefit from lower financing costs and low interest rates. During 2014, we increased the undiscounted expected cash flows from our loan portfolios by $3.6 billion, including $3 billion from portfolio acquisitions. 
In our business services segment, while total revenues will decline as a result of rehabilitation fee cuts from last year and the wind down of the transition services we provided to Sallie Mae Bank in 2014, we expect to see growth in our loan servicing business from both the Department of Education and third-party service contracts. We also see opportunities to grow our municipal asset recovery business and believe we'll have the opportunity to bid on meaningful government collection contracts. 
Our success and opportunities in this area are driven by our strong performance. Our goals to deliver industry leading results and to enable customer success while doing so on a cost-effective and compliant fashion. We believe our industry-leading performance, cost efficiency and control structure are significant competitive advantages. 
The improving economy and growth in employment for young workers is helping student loan performance. We also see borrowers making better decisions, allowing them to successfully manage their student loan payments. The fact is that nationally, delinquencies and defaults are declining and Navient is leading the way with more customers enrolled in affordable repayment programs and dramatically lowered default rates compared to the national average. 
With the separation complete, we'll return our focus to improving our operational efficiency. We have a long track record of annual efficiency gains and we are confident we can continue to produce further improvement. 
We are also keeping our commitments to return the value we create to investors. In December, we announced a new authorization to repurchase up to $1 billion in our common stock. This authority is based on a very strong capital foundation and the very sizable and predictable cash flows generated by our student loan portfolio. 
Given the season nature of our portfolio, our significant reserves and conservative funding approach, we allocate 50 basis points of capital to our FFELP portfolio and 8% to our private loan portfolio. The result is an exceptionally strong capital base, well in excess of our capital locations. It supports our outstanding debt, our capital return plans, and the investments required to support our growth objectives. To borrow a phrase, our predictable cash flow, high percentage of duration match debt and strong capital base truly creates a fortress balance sheet. 
While our outlook for growth is positive, like to remind folks that 2015 related will need to overcome some significant headwind. For example, the rehabilitation fee cuts and the amortization of our FFELP portfolio will reduce net income from these businesses by an estimated $75 million in 2015. In addition, we continue to feel the number of information requests and exams from federal and state regulators and expect the level of activity in 2015 to remain similar to last year. Though these request are time-consuming and expensive, we continue -- we are committed to being a responsible partner. 
We are confident in our ability to generate core earnings per share of $2.20 in 2015 and to generate ongoing EPS growth in the years beyond. I see a company and a team with significant strengths and with the cash flows, performance, efficiency and controls to grow and succeed, creating value for our customers, employees and shareholders. 
Somsak will now provide more details of our financial results for the quarter and the full year. Thank you.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation, which is available on our website beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings. Excluding expenses associated
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation, which is available on our website beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings. 
Excluding expenses associated with regulatory matters, we earned $2.10 per share for the full year and $0.54 per share for the fourth quarter. And as Jack mentioned, we expect our core EPS to be $2.20 for 2015. 
Our fourth quarter operating expenses totaled $206 million and $804 million for the year. These expenses included a $4 million incremental costs related to the $9.5 billion of loans acquired during the quarter. We do expect to transfer a majority of these loans to our servicing platform by the third quarter of 2015. As a result, we expect to incur onetime conversion expenses of approximately $25 million and ongoing incremental servicing expenses of approximately $20 million in 2015. 
Let's turn to Slide 5 to discuss our FFELP segment results. Core earnings were $82 million for the fourth quarter compared with $81 million for the fourth quarter of 2013. FFELP student loan spread was 100 basis points in the quarter as these assets continue to generate high-quality, predictable returns and cash flows. For 2015, we expect our student loan spread for FFELP to be in the mid-90s.  We acquired $9.5 billion of FFELP loans during the quarter, bringing our year-to-date FFELP loan acquisitions to $11.3 billion. 
Let's turn to Slide 6 in our private education loans segment. Core earnings in this segment increased $6 million from the year-ago quarter to $92 million. Profitability continues to improve as spreads remain consistent and losses continue to decline. Our fourth quarter student loan spread came in at 3.99%. And for 2015, we expect our student loan spread for our private portfolio to be approximately 4%. 
Charge-offs for the fourth quarter were at 2.5%, which is a significant reduction from the year-ago quarter. We continue to see year-over-year improvements in both our total and 90-plus day delinquency rates. The improvement in our outlook for future charge-offs led to a decrease in our position for loan losses was came in at $128 million for the quarter and that's a decrease of $24 million in the year-ago quarter. 
Slide 7 shows our asset quality trends over time and how our portfolio are dominated by high-quality loans. Our highest risk segment, what we call nontraditional loans, is now down to only 8% of our portfolio. And as you can see on the chart on the right, losses have steadily declined across all our loan segments in the past 4 years. This portfolio is well-seasoned with 91% of our loans in repayment status having made more than 12 payments. 
Let's turn to Slide 8 to review our business services segment. In this segment, core earnings were $98 million for the quarter compared with $187 million in the fourth quarter 2013. We saw a decrease in our asset recovery revenue for $28 million versus the year-ago quarter. This decline was driven by the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2013, which reduced the revenue earned from helping previously defaulted federal loan borrowers rehabilitate their loans. The new fee -- new reduced fee structure became effective on July 1, 2014. We do expect our asset recovery revenues has to be between $75 million and $80 million per quarter during 2015. 
The company now services 12 million borrowers with 6.2 million borrowers under the Department of Education servicing contract. Servicing revenue from this contract was $34 million for the quarter compared with $31 million in the prior year. 
Let's turn to Slide 9 and review the increases we have seen in our projected cash flows from our educational loan portfolio. This portfolio is expected to generate significant and predictable cash flows of $36 billion over the next 20-plus years. In 2014, we received actual cash collections of $2.7 billion, but yet added $3.6 billion of future cash flows through acquisitions, refinancings, improvement in credit quality and additional foreign income. During the quarter, we added more certainty to our cash flows by hedging $14 billion of loans and locking in on $660 million of future floor income. To date, we have locked or hedged $1.0 billion of the $1.9 billion of projected future floor income. We do expect to enhance these cash flows in meaningful ways as we take advantage of the marketplace overall. 
I'm going to move to Slide 10 and highlight our loan acquisition refinancing activity for the year. We acquired $13 billion of loans in 2014 and closed on the $10 billion ABCP facility that helped financed these acquisitions. We do believe that student loan purchase opportunities will continue going forward. 
On the financing front, our ABS transactions continue to attract strong investor demand. For the year, we should $6.8 billion of ABS. Just last week, we priced a $689 million private ABS transactions, which came in at tighter spreads than our previous private ABS deal. 
During the quarter, we repurchased 8.7 million shares for $168 million. And for the full year, we repurchased 30.4 million shares for $600 million. And during the fourth quarter, the board authorized a $1 billion share repurchase program. All of these activity was undertaking while maintaining a strong capital position. 
On Slide 11, you will see that since 2006, we have increased our tangible equity ratio as well as our net asset ratio, while at the same time, reducing our unsecured debt outstanding from nearly $50 billion to $17.5 billion today. We feel that our debt maturities are well matched to our expected cash flows and our coverage ratios are conservative. At year-end 2014, our tangible equity ratio was 2.6% compared to 2.3% in 2013.
With a well-seasoned portfolio and conservative funding strategy, we believe that the appropriate capital level for our private credit portfolio is 8%. In the past, when we were an originator of private loans, we have provided an additional 4% of capital against these assets. 
And finally, turning to GAAP results on Slide 12, we recorded fourth quarter GAAP net income of $263 million or $0.64 per share. And that's compared to net income of $270 million or $0.60 per share for the year-ago quarter. The primary differences between core earnings and GAAP results are the March related to our derivative position, expenses related to the restructuring or reorganization and the income associated with SLM BankCo prior to the spin. 
Just to reiterate, our core EPS guidance of $2.20 for 2015 includes: FFELP student loans spread in the mid-90s; private student loan spread of approximately 4%; onetime conversion expenses of $25 million; and ongoing incremental servicing expenses of $20 million in 2015; and asset recovery revenues between $75 million and $80 million per quarter. 
With that, I'd like to now open the call for questions.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sameer, yes, what we try to do is just go through and there's no exact science in that but it's -- what we try to do is look into the rate environment beyond more than just intermediate period and the hedge that we entered into nearly locked in to floor i
componenttext: Sameer, yes, what we try to do is just go through and there's no exact science in that but it's -- what we try to do is look into the rate environment beyond more than just intermediate period and the hedge that we entered into nearly locked in to floor income that went from 2017 to 2019. So what we're trying to do is just lock in, yes, what I'll call longer term value floors up to 2019, more than anything else.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just my last question on the share buyback authorization for $1 billion I mean, how should we think about that? Would you plan to spend all of that this year? Is that contingent on how much you might acquire in terms of FFELP or private stu
componenttext: Okay. And then just my last question on the share buyback authorization for $1 billion I mean, how should we think about that? Would you plan to spend all of that this year? Is that contingent on how much you might acquire in terms of FFELP or private student loans? Or how do you think about that? Or should we assume that some of [indiscernible] into 2016?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the authorization, it takes into consideration our assumptions for loan acquisitions, our capital generation, our -- the investments that we're making to supporting our growth objectives. We do expect the majority, if not all of that, to be used in 201
componenttext: So the authorization, it takes into consideration our assumptions for loan acquisitions, our capital generation, our -- the investments that we're making to supporting our growth objectives. We do expect the majority, if not all of that, to be used in 2015. However, it is a function of the environment. If we see opportunities to buy portfolios greater than our projections, that could alter some of that, particularly if they were private credit loans, less so on the FFELP side. But that's our plan at the moment.

componenttext: Well, the Wells portfolio was the largest portfolio held by and yes, we are seeing some more activity. I think the drivers, what we see is being the drivers for thanks, in particular, to sell is the fact that loan growth is growing So they're seeing demand for loan elsewhere in their business, which gives them an opportunity to redeploy those cash flows. The regulatory environments as it is associated with both consumer assets and the student loans, as well as their obligations to oversee third-party vendors are the principal drivers there.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so these loans are all service today by third parties. The majority of the loans are eligible to be transferred. So when we acquired the portfolio, we also acquired the servicing rights associated with them. That portfolio that is eligible to be tran
componenttext: Yes, so these loans are all service today by third parties. The majority of the loans are eligible to be transferred. So when we acquired the portfolio, we also acquired the servicing rights associated with them. That portfolio that is eligible to be transferred will be transferred by the third quarter of next year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is in our forecast. But generally what we had been able to do year-over-year is improve the operating costs of our international operations. And so that would be everything from what is a cost to service a loan in repayment, to what is our cost of
componenttext: Yes, it is in our forecast. But generally what we had been able to do year-over-year is improve the operating costs of our international operations. And so that would be everything from what is a cost to service a loan in repayment, to what is our cost of collecting on a delinquent account, to boarding new acquisitions onto our servicing platform. What we typically do is we measure the unit activities in those areas and over the years, we've been automating a number of functions that space, improving both our operating efficiencies as well as the control structure associated with those activities and we continue to see opportunities to do that. An example of a big item that we rolled out last year or this fall, 2014 fall, was our mobile web application for customers. And this dramatically simplified their ability to make payments on a mobile device, which our customers increasingly do. And it gave them the flexibility to actually make -- allocate those payments to specific loans. And that -- both a customer experience benefit but also improve our operating expense as that function was previously more manual.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015

componenttext: Got it. And then finally, could you just give us some color on the types of FFELP loans you acquired in the quarter outside of the Wells deal, I guess there was $1 billion of other loans. What type of loans were those? And could you give us a sense of how the returns on those compared to your portfolio, your average portfolio return?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So they -- it's a variety of different smaller portfolio purchases. A good piece of these are purchases coming from guarantee agencies as borrowers are rehabilitated and the loans are returned to good standing. And then smaller portfolios that we acquired
componenttext: So they -- it's a variety of different smaller portfolio purchases. A good piece of these are purchases coming from guarantee agencies as borrowers are rehabilitated and the loans are returned to good standing. And then smaller portfolios that we acquired, some of which were on our servicing platform, some of which were not. The returns vary pretty significantly, depending upon the different features there, are characteries of the loans. Honestly, loans that are on our servicing platform have -- can generate the best returns after operating expense because they -- the incremental cost is relatively low to service compared to a third-party service contract, as an example. But the returns, I would say, yes, they're consistent with the spread guidance that Somsak gave for our FFELP portfolio in his remarks.

And then, each year, the departments uses their core card mechanism to reallocate the volume in our -- based on our scores for the last measurement period, we increased our allocations share to 24% of new placements for the upcoming year. Those are the big drivers.

componenttext: Sure, I mean, exclusive of the incremental costs, the servicing cost that were -- yes, I just talk about the $4 million of cost we incurred in the fourth quarter. I think we've been running about $800 million annually. And given the increased compliance costs, I mean, as well as the fact that we're going to be increasing our loan service, I think, outside of the intermodal cost, I alluded an $800 million run rate is probably appropriate going forward.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alan Straus with Schroder's.

componenttextpreview: Just curious, what tax rate are you guys assuming for the year? And second question is, on the private student loan side, do you see any chance of acquisitions? Is it something that you're interested in besides from Sallie Mae?

componenttext: Yes. When the tax rate we expect to have is 37% for both 2014 and '15.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on the private the acquisition front, yes, we're definitely interested in acquiring portfolios in that area and we do see opportunities and are pursuing the -- for acquisitions outside of Sallie Mae Bank. They're much smaller than the FFELP side, but
componenttext: And on the private the acquisition front, yes, we're definitely interested in acquiring portfolios in that area and we do see opportunities and are pursuing the -- for acquisitions outside of Sallie Mae Bank. They're much smaller than the FFELP side, but the returns, yes, as you can see from the margins that Somsak provided is in his opening remarks are about 4x what they are in the FFELP space. So those are -- those can be very attractive opportunities. And we deliver a lot of value when we acquire them because of our servicing capabilities. We're very good at helping customers understand their payment obligations and find payment solutions that they can afford. Our programs there have been -- have really led the industry in that side. And we see it in our FFELP performance.

componenttext: No, I think it's just getting people comfortable with the process. I mean, demonstrating what we're doing on that side of the equation and how we're helping customers. I also think that if the loan loans are third-party serviced, the regulatory environment and ownership of the lender over that third party's performance is a growing sector that is driving the interest of banks, in particular, to sell. And so when you look on the FFELP side, that's a very significant factor oversee third-party vendor if it's my own internal shock for business that I'm not in any longer. I think that's a factor that's driving the desire to sell, and it's true for both federal and private.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So when we look at what the reserve -- what the capital levels are for our portfolios, it's driven by a function of what we expect the loss rates to be and then the cap, which are covered by reserves and then an estimate for capital base on a variety
componenttext: Yes. So when we look at what the reserve -- what the capital levels are for our portfolios, it's driven by a function of what we expect the loss rates to be and then the cap, which are covered by reserves and then an estimate for capital base on a variety based on what kind of funding capabilities we have on those assets, what percentage of funding we can obtain and what kinds of loss rates we might be exposed to above and beyond our expectations. As our private loan portfolio has seasoned and moved through a -- substantially moved through its fourth peak periods and as we see a higher percentage of our portfolio covered by life of loan loss reserves, our TDR portfolio, it has moved capital from -- allowed us to basically move from providing coverage to capital through providing it through reserves. And it has allowed us to pull our capital breaks down in that area.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015

componenttext: So then would you expect to reach that 8% on a capitalization basis over a certain period of time? Are you going to continue to operate as an excess to that 8% allocation?

componenttext: So obviously -- so we don't think it's appropriate. When we were at 12% and that was such an enormous cushion against kind of a potential credit losses that might occur in stressed environments, we tended to run closer to those numbers. We tended to run closer to those numbers. At 8%, we [indiscernible] our funding structure. So I think, you see the capital levels that we're running at to be fairly consistent going forward.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Laurel, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Navient Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.I'll now turn the call over to Joe Fisher, Vice
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Laurel, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Navient Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.
I'll now turn the call over to Joe Fisher, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laurel. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2014 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.Before we begin, k
componenttext:
Thank you, Laurel. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2014 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.
Before we begin, keep in mind our discussion will contain predictions, expectations and forward-looking statements. Actual results in the future may be materially different from those discussed here. This could be due to a variety of factors. Listeners should refer to the discussion of those factors on the company's Form 10 and other filings with the SEC.
During this conference call, we will refer to non-GAAP measures we call our core earnings. A description of core earnings, a full reconciliation to GAAP measures and our GAAP results can be found in the fourth quarter 2014 supplemental earnings disclosure. This is posted along with our earnings press release on the Investors page at navient.com.
Thank you, and I will turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Good morning, and thank you for listening in today. I appreciate your interest and your support. 2014 was a busy and productive year. We started the year as one company with a very long list of tasks to complete, and we finished the year as N
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Good morning, and thank you for listening in today. I appreciate your interest and your support. 2014 was a busy and productive year. We started the year as one company with a very long list of tasks to complete, and we finished the year as Navient, having successfully completed the legal and operational separation from Sallie Mae.
While the separation project consumed most of the resources here, we retained our focus on our business, delivering outstanding performance and generating strong financial results. Highlights for the year include, of course, our completion of the separation from Sallie Mae; the acquisition of $13 billion in student loans; we reduced the private credit charge-offs by 18% to $717 million for the year; our servicing skills enabled our federal loan customers to significantly outperform the national average with a cohort default rate 48% lower than all other servicers; we distributed $849 million to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases; and we generated $2.10 of core earnings per share.
I'm very pleased with our performance in 2014 and the resulting gains for our shareholders. The separation not only provide proof to be a catalyst to unlock the value of our business, but is also unlock Navient's potential to grow in businesses beyond education finance.
While I'm proud of our accomplishments in 2014, I want to focus my comments on here and now, our plans for 2015. Our goals for 2015 can be summed up by one word: growth. We see growth opportunities in each of our operating areas.
In Asset Management, we continue to see opportunities to purchase both federal and private loan portfolios. And while we are unlikely to repeat the volume acquired in 2014, we believe there will be substantial opportunities in 2015 as the environmental factors remain unchanged. Our competitive advantage has also remained intact, though we did see what we believed to be irrational pricing on some portfolios in late 2014.
We also see continued opportunities to increase the expected cash flows from our federal and private loan portfolios as credit continues to improve and we benefit from lower financing costs and low interest rates. During 2014, we increased the undiscounted expected cash flows from our loan portfolios by $3.6 billion, including $3 billion from portfolio acquisitions.
In our Business Services segment, while total revenues will decline as a result of rehabilitation fee cuts from last year and the wind-down of the transition services we provided to Sallie Mae Bank in 2014, we expect to see growth in our loan servicing business from both the Department of Education and third-party service contracts. We also see opportunities to grow our municipal asset recovery business and believe we'll have the opportunity to bid on meaningful government collection contracts.
Our success and opportunities in this area are driven by our strong performance. Our goals are to deliver industry leading results and to enable customer success while doing so on a cost-effective and compliant fashion. We believe our industry-leading performance, cost efficiency and control structure are significant competitive advantages.
The improving economy and growth in employment for young workers is helping student loan performance. We also see borrowers making better decisions, allowing them to successfully manage their student loan payments. The fact is that nationally, delinquencies and defaults are declining, and Navient is leading the way with more customers enrolled in affordable repayment programs and dramatically lowered default rates compared to the national average.
With the separation complete, we'll return our focus to improving our operational efficiency. We have a long track record of annual efficiency gains, and we are confident we can continue to produce further improvement.
We are also keeping our commitments to return the value we create to investors. In December, we announced a new authorization to repurchase up to $1 billion in our common stock. This authority is based on a very strong capital foundation and the very sizable and predictable cash flows generated by our student loan portfolio.
Given the season nature of our portfolio, our significant reserves and conservative funding approach, we allocate 50 basis points of capital to our FFELP portfolio and 8% to our private loan portfolio. The result is an exceptionally strong capital base, well in excess of our capital allocations. It supports our outstanding debt, our capital return plans and the investment required to support our growth objectives. To borrow a phrase, our predictable cash flow, high percentage of duration match debt and strong capital base truly creates a fortress balance sheet.
While our outlook for growth is positive, I'd like to remind folks that 2015 will need to overcome some significant headwinds. For example, the rehabilitation fee cuts and the amortization of our FFELP portfolio will reduce net income from these businesses by an estimated $75 million in 2015. In addition, we continue to feel the number of information requests and exams from federal and state regulators and expect the level of activity in 2015 to remain similar to last year. Though these requests are time-consuming and expensive, we are committed to being a responsive partner.
We are confident in our ability to generate core earnings per share of $2.20 in 2015 and to generate ongoing EPS growth in the years beyond. I see a company and a team with significant strengths and with the cash flows, performance, efficiency and controls to grow and succeed, creating value for our customers, employees and shareholders.
Somsak will now provide more details of our financial results for the quarter and the full year. Thank you.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation, which is available on our website, beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings.Excluding expenses associated
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation, which is available on our website, beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings.
Excluding expenses associated with regulatory matters, we earned $2.10 per share for the full year and $0.54 per share for the fourth quarter. And as Jack mentioned, we expect our core EPS to be $2.20 for 2015.
Our fourth quarter operating expenses totaled $206 million and $804 million for the year. These expenses included a $4 million incremental costs related to the $9.5 billion of loans acquired during the quarter. We do expect to transfer a majority of these loans to our servicing platform by the third quarter of 2015. As a result, we expect to incur onetime conversion expenses of approximately $25 million and ongoing incremental servicing expenses of approximately $20 million in 2015.
Let's turn to Slide 5 to discuss our FFELP segment results. Core earnings were $82 million for the fourth quarter compared with $81 million for the fourth quarter of 2013. FFELP student loan spread was 100 basis points in the quarter as these assets continue to generate high-quality, predictable returns and cash flows. For 2015, we expect our student loan spread for FFELP to be in the mid-90s.  We acquired $9.5 billion of FFELP loans during the quarter, bringing our year-to-date FFELP loan acquisitions to $11.3 billion.
Let's turn to Slide 6 in our Private Education Loans segment. Core earnings in this segment increased $6 million from the year-ago quarter to $92 million. Profitability continues to improve as spreads remain consistent and losses continue to decline. Our fourth quarter student loan spread came in at 3.99%. And for 2015, we expect our student loan spread for our private portfolio to be approximately 4%.
Charge-offs for the fourth quarter were at 2.5%, which is a significant reduction from the year-ago quarter. We continue to see year-over-year improvements in both our total and 90-plus day delinquency rates. The improvement in our outlook for future charge-offs led to a decrease in our position for loan losses, which came in at $128 million for the quarter, and that's a decrease of $24 million from the year-ago quarter.
Slide 7 shows our asset quality trends over time and how our portfolio are dominated by high-quality loans. Our highest risk segment, what we call nontraditional loans, is now down to only 8% of our portfolio. And as you can see on the chart on the right, losses have steadily declined across all our loan segments in the past 4 years. This portfolio is well-seasoned, with 91% of our loans in repayment status having made more than 12 payments.
Let's turn to Slide 8 to review our Business Services segment. In this segment, core earnings were $98 million for the quarter compared with $187 million in the fourth quarter 2013. We saw a decrease in our asset recovery revenue of $28 million versus the year-ago quarter. This decline was driven by the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2013, which reduced the revenue earned from helping previously defaulted federal loan borrowers rehabilitate their loans. The new fee -- new reduced fee structure became effective on July 1, 2014. We do expect our asset recovery revenues to be between $75 million and $80 million per quarter during 2015.
The company now services 12 million borrowers, with 6.2 million borrowers under the Department of Education servicing contract. Servicing revenue from this contract was $34 million for the quarter compared with $31 million in the prior year.
Let's turn to Slide 9 and review the increases we have seen in our projected cash flows from our education loan portfolio. This portfolio is expected to generate significant and predictable cash flows of $36 billion over the next 20-plus years. In 2014, we received actual cash collections of $2.7 billion but yet added $3.6 billion of future cash flows through acquisitions, refinancings, improvement in credit quality and additional floor income. During the quarter, we added more certainty to our cash flows by hedging $14 billion of loans and locking in on $660 million of future floor income. To date, we have locked in or hedged $1.0 billion of the $1.9 billion of projected future floor income. We do expect to enhance these cash flows in meaningful ways as we take advantage of the marketplace overall.
I'm going to move to Slide 10 and highlight our loan acquisition refinancing activity for the year. We acquired $13 billion of loans in 2014 and closed on the $10 billion ABCP facility that helped finance these acquisitions. We do believe that student loan purchase opportunities will continue going forward.
On the financing front, our ABS transactions continue to attract strong investor demand. For the year, we issued $6.8 billion of ABS. Just last week, we priced $689 million private ABS transactions, which came in at tighter spreads than our previous private ABS deal.
During the quarter, we repurchased 8.7 million shares for $168 million. And for the full year, we repurchased 30.4 million shares for $600 million. And during the fourth quarter, the board authorized a $1 billion share repurchase program. All of this activity was undertaking while maintaining a strong capital position.
On Slide 11, you will see that since 2006, we have increased our tangible equity ratio as well as our net asset ratio, while at the same time, reducing our unsecured debt outstanding from nearly $50 billion to $17.5 billion today. We feel that our debt maturities are well matched to our expected cash flows and our coverage ratios are conservative. At year-end 2014, our tangible equity ratio was 2.6% compared to 2.3% in 2013.
With a well-seasoned portfolio and conservative funding strategy, we believe that the appropriate capital level for our private credit portfolio is 8%. In the past, when we were an originator of private loans, we had provided an additional 4% of capital against these assets.
And finally, turning to GAAP results on Slide 12. We recorded fourth quarter GAAP net income of $263 million or $0.64 per share, and that's compared to net income of $270 million or $0.60 per share for the year-ago quarter. The primary differences between core earnings and GAAP results are the marks  related to our derivative position, expenses related to the restructuring or reorganization and the income associated with SLM BankCo prior to the spin.
Just to reiterate, our core EPS guidance of $2.20 for 2015 includes: FFELP student loan spread in the mid-90s; private student loan spread of approximately 4%; onetime conversion expenses of $25 million and ongoing incremental servicing expenses of $20 million in 2015; and asset recovery revenues between $75 million and $80 million per quarter.
With that, I'd like to now open the call for questions.

componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of your floor income and locking in floor income through hedges, I think it gets cheaper for you to actually lock those in through those forward contracts as rates rise. So what's your thinking around locking in additional floor income? How much would rates need to increase before you maybe have an increased appetite for locking in that floor income?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sameer, yes, what we try to do is just go through, and there's no exact science in that, but it's -- what we try to do is look in into the rate environment beyond more than just intermediate period, and the hedge that we entered into clearly locked in to
componenttext: Sameer, yes, what we try to do is just go through, and there's no exact science in that, but it's -- what we try to do is look in into the rate environment beyond more than just intermediate period, and the hedge that we entered into clearly locked in to floor income that went from 2017 to 2019. So what we're trying to do is just lock in, yes, what I'll call longer-term value floors up to 2019 more than anything else.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just my last question on the share buyback authorization for $1 billion. I mean, how should we think about that? Would you plan to spend all of that this year? Is that contingent on how much you might acquire in terms of FFELP or private st
componenttext: Okay. And then just my last question on the share buyback authorization for $1 billion. I mean, how should we think about that? Would you plan to spend all of that this year? Is that contingent on how much you might acquire in terms of FFELP or private student loans? Or how do you think about that? Or should we assume some of the bids into 2016?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the authorization, it takes into consideration our assumptions for loan acquisitions, our capital generation, our -- the investments that we'll make into supporting our growth objectives. We do expect the majority, if not all of that, to be used in 201
componenttext: So the authorization, it takes into consideration our assumptions for loan acquisitions, our capital generation, our -- the investments that we'll make into supporting our growth objectives. We do expect the majority, if not all of that, to be used in 2015. However, it is a function of the environment. If we see opportunities to buy portfolios greater than our projections, that could alter some of that, particularly if they were private credit loans, less so on the FFELP side. But that's our plan at the moment.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the Wells portfolio was the largest portfolio held by banks, and yes, we are seeing some more activity. I think the drivers -- what we see as being the drivers for banks, in particular, to sell is the fact that loan growth is growing, so they're see
componenttext: Well, the Wells portfolio was the largest portfolio held by banks, and yes, we are seeing some more activity. I think the drivers -- what we see as being the drivers for banks, in particular, to sell is the fact that loan growth is growing, so they're seeing demand for loan elsewhere in their business, which gives them an opportunity to redeploy those cash flows. The regulatory environments as it is associated with both consumer assets and the student loans space as well as their obligations to oversee third-party vendors are the principal drivers there.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So these loans are all serviced today by third parties. The majority of the loans are eligible to be transferred. So when we acquired the portfolio, we also acquired the servicing rights associated with them. That portfolio that is eligible to be tra
componenttext: Yes. So these loans are all serviced today by third parties. The majority of the loans are eligible to be transferred. So when we acquired the portfolio, we also acquired the servicing rights associated with them. That portfolio that is eligible to be transferred will be transferred by the third quarter of next year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is in our forecast. But generally, what we had been able to do year-over-year is improve the operating costs of our internal operations. And so that would be everything from what does it cost to service a loan in repayment, to what is our cost of
componenttext: Yes, it is in our forecast. But generally, what we had been able to do year-over-year is improve the operating costs of our internal operations. And so that would be everything from what does it cost to service a loan in repayment, to what is our cost of collecting on a delinquent account, to boarding new acquisitions onto our servicing platform. What we typically do is we measure the unit activities in those areas. And over the years, we've been automating a number of the functions in that space, improving both our operating efficiencies as well as the control structure associated with those activities, and we continue to see opportunities to do that. An example of a big item that we rolled out last year or this fall, 2014 fall, was our mobile web application for customers. And this dramatically simplified their ability to make payments on a mobile device, which our customers increasingly do. And it gave them the flexibility to actually make -- allocate those payments to specific loans. And that -- both as a customer experience benefit, but it also improved our operating expenses that add to that function, which previously more manual.

componenttext: So they -- it's a variety of different smaller portfolio purchases. A good piece of these are purchases coming from guarantee agencies as borrowers are rehabilitated and the loans are returned to good standing. And then smaller portfolios that we acquired, some of which were on our servicing platform, some of which were not. The returns vary pretty significantly, depending upon the different features there or characteristics of the loans. Obviously, loans that are on our servicing platform have -- can generate the best returns after operating expense because they -- the incremental cost is relatively low to service compared to a third-party service contract, as an example. But the returns, I would say, yes, they're consistent with the spread guidance that Somsak gave for our FFELP portfolio in his remarks.

componenttext: And on the private acquisition front, yes, we're definitely interested in acquiring portfolios in that area, and we do see opportunities and are pursuing them for acquisitions outside of Sallie Mae Bank. So those are -- those can be very attractive opportunities. And we deliver a lot of value when we acquire them because of our servicing capabilities. We're very good at helping customers understand their payment obligations and find payment solutions that they can afford. Our programs there have been out and have really led the industry in that side. And we see it in our FFELP performance.

componenttext: No, I think it's just getting people comfortable with the process. I mean, in demonstrating what we're doing on that side of the equation and how we're helping customers. I also think that if the loans are third-party serviced, the regulatory environment and ownership of the lender over that third party's performance is a growing factor that is driving the interest of banks, in particular, to sell. And so when you look at it on the FFELP side, that's a very significant factor. But got to oversee a third-party vendor is if it's my own and internal shock for a business that I'm not in any longer. I think that's a factor that's driving the desire to sell, and it's true on both federal and private.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So when we look at what the reserve -- what the capital levels are for our portfolios, it's driven by a function of what we expect the loss rates to be and then the cap, which are covered by reserves, and then an estimate for the capital base on a va
componenttext: Yes. So when we look at what the reserve -- what the capital levels are for our portfolios, it's driven by a function of what we expect the loss rates to be and then the cap, which are covered by reserves, and then an estimate for the capital base on a variety of factors just based on what kind of funding capabilities we have on those assets, what percentage of funding we can obtain and what kinds of loss rates we might be exposed to above and beyond our expectations. As our private loan portfolio has seasoned and moved through -- substantially moved through its peak default periods and as we see a higher percentage of our portfolio covered by life of loan loss reserves, our TDR portfolio, it has moved capital from -- allowed us to basically move from providing coverage to capital through providing it through reserves. And it has allowed us to pull our capital rates down in that area.

componenttext: So we don't think it's appropriate. When we were at 12%, and that was such an enormous cushion against kind of the potential credit losses that might occur in stressed environments, we tended to run closer to those numbers. At 8%, we formed our funding structure. So I think you'd see the capital levels that we're running at to be fairly consistent going forward.

Good morning. My name is Laurel, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Navient Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.
I'll now turn the call over to Joe Fisher, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laurel. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2014 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.Before we begin, k
componenttext:
Thank you, Laurel. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2014 Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.
Before we begin, keep in mind our discussion will contain predictions, expectations and forward-looking statements. Actual results in the future may be materially different from those discussed here. This could be due to a variety of factors. Listeners should refer to the discussion of those factors on the company's Form 10 and other filings with the SEC.
During this conference call, we will refer to non-GAAP measures we call our core earnings. A description of core earnings, a full reconciliation to GAAP measures and our GAAP results can be found in the fourth quarter 2014 supplemental earnings disclosure. This is posted along with our earnings press release on the Investors page at navient.com.
Thank you, and I will turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Good morning, and thank you for listening in today. I appreciate your interest and your support. 2014 was a busy and productive year. We started the year as one company with a very long list of tasks to complete, and we finished the year as N
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Good morning, and thank you for listening in today. I appreciate your interest and your support. 2014 was a busy and productive year. We started the year as one company with a very long list of tasks to complete, and we finished the year as Navient, having successfully completed the legal and operational separation from Sallie Mae.
While the separation project consumed most of the resources here, we retained our focus on our business, delivering outstanding performance and generating strong financial results. Highlights for the year include, of course, our completion of the separation from Sallie Mae; the acquisition of $13 billion in student loans; we reduced private credit charge-offs by 18% to $717 million for the year; our servicing skills enabled our federal loan customers to significantly outperform the national average with a cohort default rate 48% lower than all other servicers; we distributed $849 million to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases; and we generated $2.10 of core earnings per share.
I'm very pleased with our performance in 2014 and the resulting gains for our shareholders. The separation not only provide -- proved to be a catalyst to unlock the value of our business, but has also unlocked Navient's potential to grow in businesses beyond education finance.
While I'm proud of our accomplishments in 2014, I want to focus my comments on here and now, our plans for 2015. Our goals for 2015 can be summed up by one word: growth. We see growth opportunities in each of our operating areas.
In Asset Management, we continue to see opportunities to purchase both federal and private loan portfolios. And while we are unlikely to repeat the volume acquired in 2014, we believe there will be substantial opportunities in 2015 as the environmental factors remain unchanged. Our competitive advantage has also remained intact, though we did see what we believed to be irrational pricing on some portfolios in late 2014.
We also see continued opportunities to increase the expected cash flows from our federal and private loan portfolios as credit continues to improve and we benefit from lower financing costs and low interest rates. During 2014, we increased the undiscounted expected cash flows from our loan portfolios by $3.6 billion, including $3 billion from portfolio acquisitions.
In our Business Services segment, while total revenues will decline as a result of rehabilitation fee cuts from last year and the wind-down of the transition services we provided to Sallie Mae Bank in 2014, we expect to see growth in our loan servicing business from both the Department of Education and third-party service contracts. We also see opportunities to grow our municipal asset recovery business and believe we'll have the opportunity to bid on meaningful government collection contracts.
Our success and opportunities in this area are driven by our strong performance. Our goals are to deliver industry leading results and to enable customer success while doing so in a cost-effective and compliant fashion. We believe our industry-leading performance, cost efficiency and control structure are significant competitive advantages.
The improving economy and growth in employment for young workers is helping student loan performance. We also see borrowers making better decisions, allowing them to successfully manage their student loan payments. The fact is that nationally, delinquencies and defaults are declining, and Navient is leading the way with more customers enrolled in affordable repayment programs and dramatically lower default rates compared to the national average.
With the separation complete, we'll return our focus to improving our operational efficiency. We have a long track record of annual efficiency gains, and we are confident we can continue to produce further improvement.
We are also keeping our commitments to return the value we create to investors. In December, we announced a new authorization to repurchase up to $1 billion in our common stock. This authority is based on a very strong capital foundation and the very sizable and predictable cash flows generated by our student loan portfolio.
Given the season nature of our portfolio, our significant reserves and conservative funding approach, we allocate 50 basis points of capital to our FFELP portfolio and 8% to our private loan portfolio. The result is an exceptionally strong capital base, well in excess of our capital allocations. It supports our outstanding debt, our capital return plans and the investment required to support our growth objectives. To borrow a phrase, our predictable cash flow, high percentage of duration match debt and strong capital base truly creates a fortress balance sheet.
While our outlook for growth is positive, I'd like to remind folks that 2015 will need to overcome some significant headwinds. For example, the rehabilitation fee cuts and the amortization of our FFELP portfolio will reduce net income from these businesses by an estimated $75 million in 2015. In addition, we continue to field a number of information requests and exams from federal and state regulators and expect the level of activity in 2015 to remain similar to last year. Though these requests are time-consuming and expensive, we are committed to being a responsive partner.
We are confident in our ability to generate core earnings per share of $2.20 in 2015 and to generate ongoing EPS growth in the years beyond. I see a company and a team with significant strengths and with the cash flows, performance, efficiency and controls to grow and succeed, creating value for our customers, employees and shareholders.
Somsak will now provide more details of our financial results for the quarter and the full year. Thank you.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation, which is available on our website, beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings.Excluding expenses associated
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation, which is available on our website, beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings.
Excluding expenses associated with regulatory matters, we earned $2.10 per share for the full year and $0.54 per share for the fourth quarter. And as Jack mentioned, we expect our core EPS to be $2.20 for 2015.
Our fourth quarter operating expenses totaled $206 million and $804 million for the year. These expenses included a $4 million incremental costs related to the $9.5 billion of loans acquired during the quarter. We do expect to transfer a majority of these loans to our servicing platform by the third quarter of 2015. As a result, we expect to incur onetime conversion expenses of approximately $25 million and ongoing incremental servicing expenses of approximately $20 million in 2015.
Let's turn to Slide 5 to discuss our FFELP segment results. Core earnings were $82 million for the fourth quarter compared with $81 million for the fourth quarter of 2013. FFELP student loan spread was 100 basis points in the quarter as these assets continue to generate high-quality, predictable returns and cash flows. For 2015, we expect our student loan spread for FFELP to be in the mid-90s.  We acquired $9.5 billion of FFELP loans during the quarter, bringing our year-to-date FFELP loan acquisitions to $11.3 billion.
Let's turn to Slide 6 in our Private Education Loans segment. Core earnings in this segment increased $6 million from the year-ago quarter to $92 million. Profitability continues to improve as spreads remain consistent and losses continue to decline. Our fourth quarter student loan spread came in at 3.99%. And for 2015, we expect our student loan spread for our private portfolio to be approximately 4%.
Charge-offs for the fourth quarter were at 2.5%, which is a significant reduction from the year-ago quarter. We continue to see year-over-year improvements in both our total and 90-plus day delinquency rates. The improvement in our outlook for future charge-offs led to a decrease in our position for loan losses, which came in at $128 million for the quarter, and that's a decrease of $24 million from the year-ago quarter.
Slide 7 shows our asset quality trends over time and how our portfolio are dominated by high-quality loans. Our highest risk segment, what we call nontraditional loans, is now down to only 8% of our portfolio. And as you can see on the chart on the right, losses have steadily declined across all our loan segments in the past 4 years. This portfolio is well-seasoned, with 91% of our loans in repayment status having made more than 12 payments.
Let's turn to Slide 8 to review our Business Services segment. In this segment, core earnings were $98 million for the quarter compared with $187 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. We saw a decrease in our asset recovery revenue of $28 million versus the year-ago quarter. This decline was driven by the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2013, which reduced the revenue earned from helping previously defaulted federal loan borrowers rehabilitate their loans. The new fee -- new reduced fee structure became effective on July 1, 2014. We do expect our asset recovery revenues to be between $75 million and $80 million per quarter during 2015.
The company now services 12 million borrowers, with 6.2 million borrowers under the Department of Education servicing contract. Servicing revenue from this contract was $34 million for the quarter compared with $31 million in the prior year.
Let's turn to Slide 9 and review the increases we have seen in our projected cash flows from our education loan portfolio. This portfolio is expected to generate significant and predictable cash flows of $36 billion over the next 20-plus years. In 2014, we received actual cash collections of $2.7 billion but yet added $3.6 billion of future cash flows through acquisitions, refinancings, improvement in credit quality and additional floor income. During the quarter, we added more certainty to our cash flows by hedging $14 billion of loans and locking in on $660 million of future floor income. To date, we have locked in or hedged $1.0 billion of the $1.9 billion of projected future floor income. We do expect to enhance these cash flows in meaningful ways as we take advantage of the marketplace overall.
I'm going to move to Slide 10 and highlight our loan acquisition refinancing activity for the year. We acquired $13 billion of loans in 2014 and closed on the $10 billion ABCP facility that helped finance these acquisitions. We do believe that student loan purchase opportunities will continue going forward.
On the financing front, our ABS transactions continue to attract strong investor demand. For the year, we issued $6.8 billion of ABS. Just last week, we priced $689 million private ABS transactions, which came in at tighter spreads than our previous private ABS deal.
During the quarter, we repurchased 8.7 million shares for $168 million. And for the full year, we repurchased 30.4 million shares for $600 million. And during the fourth quarter, the board authorized a $1 billion share repurchase program. All of this activity was undertaken while maintaining a strong capital position.
On Slide 11, you will see that since 2006, we have increased our tangible equity ratio as well as our net asset ratio, while at the same time, reducing our unsecured debt outstanding from nearly $50 billion to $17.5 billion today. We feel that our debt maturities are well matched to our expected cash flows and our coverage ratios are conservative. At year-end 2014, our tangible equity ratio was 2.6% compared to 2.3% in 2013.
With a well-seasoned portfolio and conservative funding strategy, we believe that the appropriate capital level for our private credit portfolio is 8%. In the past, when we were an originator of private loans, we had provided an additional 4% of capital against these assets.
And finally, turning to GAAP results on Slide 12. We recorded fourth quarter GAAP net income of $263 million or $0.64 per share, and that's compared to net income of $270 million or $0.60 per share for the year-ago quarter. The primary differences between core earnings and GAAP results are the marks  related to our derivative position, expenses related to the restructuring or reorganization and the income associated with SLM BankCo prior to the spin.
Just to reiterate, our core EPS guidance of $2.20 for 2015 includes: FFELP student loan spread in the mid-90s; private student loan spread of approximately 4%; onetime conversion expenses of $25 million and ongoing incremental servicing expenses of $20 million in 2015; and asset recovery revenues between $75 million and $80 million per quarter.
With that, I'd like to now open the call for questions.

componenttext: Okay. componenttextpreview: Sameer, yes, what we try to do is just go through, and there's no exact science in that, but it's -- what we try to do is look in into the rate environment beyond more than just intermediate period, and the hedge that we entered into clearly locked in to
componenttext: Sameer, yes, what we try to do is just go through, and there's no exact science in that, but it's -- what we try to do is look in into the rate environment beyond more than just intermediate period, and the hedge that we entered into clearly locked in to floor income that went from 2017 to 2019. So what we're trying to do is just lock in, yes, what I'll call longer-term value floors up to 2019 more than anything else.

componenttext: Okay. And then just my last question on the share buyback authorization for $1 billion. I mean, how should we think about that? Would you plan to spend all of that this year? headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the authorization, it takes into consideration our assumptions for loan acquisitions, our capital generation, our -- the investments that we'll make into supporting our growth objectives. We do expect the majority, if not all of that, to be used in 201
componenttext: So the authorization, it takes into consideration our assumptions for loan acquisitions, our capital generation, our -- the investments that we'll make into supporting our growth objectives. We do expect the majority, if not all of that, to be used in 2015. However, it is a function of the environment. If we see opportunities to buy portfolios greater than our projections, that could alter some of that, particularly if they were private credit loans, less so on the FFELP side. But that's our plan at the moment.

componenttext: So we're not -- some of that needs to be dated. We don't really want to talk about it in terms of the pure details here. But it is based on what we see in terms of opportunities that are in the pipeline today as well as opportunities that we think have a strong chance of materializing during the course of the year. I just want to leave it at that.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the M&A environment out there, specifically from a FFELP standpoint, are you seeing more activity now that the Wells portfolio has moved? And on the private side, anything to note there?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the M&A environment out there, specifically from a FFELP standpoint, are you seeing more activity now that the Wells portfolio has moved? And on the private side, anything to note there?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the Wells portfolio was the largest portfolio held by banks, and yes, we are seeing some more activity. I think the drivers -- what we see as being the drivers for banks, in particular, to sell is the fact that loan growth is growing, so they're see
componenttext: Well, the Wells portfolio was the largest portfolio held by banks, and yes, we are seeing some more activity. I think the drivers -- what we see as being the drivers for banks, in particular, to sell is the fact that loan growth is growing, so they're seeing demand for loan elsewhere in their business, which gives them an opportunity to redeploy those cash flows. The regulatory environments as it is associated with both consumer assets and the student loans space as well as their obligations to oversee third-party vendors are the principal drivers there.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So these loans are all serviced today by third parties. The majority of the loans are eligible to be transferred. So when we acquired the portfolio, we also acquired the servicing rights associated with them. That portfolio that is eligible to be tra
componenttext: Yes. So these loans are all serviced today by third parties. The majority of the loans are eligible to be transferred. So when we acquired the portfolio, we also acquired the servicing rights associated with them. That portfolio that is eligible to be transferred will be transferred by the third quarter of next year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is in our forecast. But generally, what we had been able to do year-over-year is improve the operating costs of our internal operations. And so that would be everything from what does it cost to service a loan in repayment, to what is our cost of
componenttext: Yes, it is in our forecast. But generally, what we had been able to do year-over-year is improve the operating costs of our internal operations. And so that would be everything from what does it cost to service a loan in repayment, to what is our cost of collecting on a delinquent account, to boarding new acquisitions onto our servicing platform. What we typically do is we measure the unit activities in those areas. And over the years, we've been automating a number of the functions in that space, improving both our operating efficiencies as well as the control structure associated with those activities, and we continue to see opportunities to do that. An example of a big item that we rolled out last year or this fall, 2014 fall, was our mobile web application for customers. And this dramatically simplified their ability to make payments on a mobile device, which our customers increasingly do. And it gave them the flexibility to actually make -- allocate those payments to specific loans. And that -- both as a customer experience benefit, but it also improved our operating expenses that add -- that function was previously more manual.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then finally, could you just give us some color on the types of FFELP loans you acquired in the quarter outside of the Wells deal? I guess there was $1 billion of other loans. What type of loans were those? And could you give us a sense of how
componenttext: Got it. And then finally, could you just give us some color on the types of FFELP loans you acquired in the quarter outside of the Wells deal? I guess there was $1 billion of other loans. What type of loans were those? And could you give us a sense of how the returns on those compare to your portfolio, your average portfolio return?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So they -- it's a variety of different smaller portfolio purchases. A good piece of these are purchases coming from guarantee agencies as borrowers are rehabilitated and the loans are returned to good standing. And then smaller portfolios that we acquired
componenttext: So they -- it's a variety of different smaller portfolio purchases. A good piece of these are purchases coming from guarantee agencies as borrowers are rehabilitated and the loans are returned to good standing. And then smaller portfolios that we acquired, some of which were on our servicing platform, some of which were not. The returns vary pretty significantly, depending upon the different features there or characteristics of the loans. Obviously, loans that are on our servicing platform have -- can generate the best returns after operating expense because they -- the incremental cost is relatively low to service compared to a third-party service contract, as an example. But the returns, I would say, yes, they're consistent with the spread guidance that Somsak gave for our FFELP portfolio in his remarks.

componenttextpreview: So yes. So each year, the Department of Ed increase is really coming from 2 things. It's coming from the loans that were added in the last academic -- the last calendar year, having a full year impact on the revenue stream. More of those loans in repaymen
componenttext: So yes. So each year, the Department of Ed increase is really coming from 2 things. It's coming from the loans that were added in the last academic -- the last calendar year, having a full year impact on the revenue stream. More of those loans in repayment, which we get paid a higher fee. There's also higher [indiscernible] associated with servicing those loans. And then, each year, the departments uses their score card mechanism to reallocate the volume in our -- based on our scores for the last measurement period, we increased our allocation share to 24% of new placements for the upcoming year. Those are the big drivers.

componenttext: Sure. I mean, exclusive of the incremental costs, the servicing costs that were -- yes, I just talked about the $4 million of costs we incurred in the fourth quarter. I think we've been running about $800 million annually. And given the increased compliance costs and as well as the fact that we're going to be increasing our loan service, I think, outside of the incremental costs, I alluded to an $800 million run rate is probably appropriate going forward.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And on the private acquisition front, yes, we're definitely interested in acquiring portfolios in that area, and we do see opportunities and are pursuing them for acquisitions outside of Sallie Mae Bank. They're much smaller than the FFELP side, but the r
componenttext: And on the private acquisition front, yes, we're definitely interested in acquiring portfolios in that area, and we do see opportunities and are pursuing them for acquisitions outside of Sallie Mae Bank. They're much smaller than the FFELP side, but the returns, yes, you can see from the margins that Somsak provided in his opening remarks are about 4x what they are in the FFELP space. So those are -- those can be very attractive opportunities. And we deliver a lot of value when we acquire them because of our servicing capabilities. We're very good at helping customers understand their payment obligations and find payment solutions that they can afford. Our programs there have been out and have really led the industry in that side. And we see it in our FFELP performance.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015

componenttext: And just to follow up, what's the stumbling block that there have been few acquisitions? Is it all price or is it regulatory issues?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's a bit of both, frankly.
componenttext: I think it's a bit of both, frankly.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: What would you need to break through on the regulatory side? Is that just something that can't be overcome because...
componenttext: What would you need to break through on the regulatory side? Is that just something that can't be overcome because...

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think it's just getting people comfortable with the process. I mean, in demonstrating what we're doing on that side of the equation and how we're helping customers. I also think that if the loans are third-party serviced, the regulatory environment
componenttext: No, I think it's just getting people comfortable with the process. I mean, in demonstrating what we're doing on that side of the equation and how we're helping customers. I also think that if the loans are third-party serviced, the regulatory environment and ownership of the lender over that third party's performance is a growing factor that is driving the interest of banks, in particular, to sell. And so when you look at it on the FFELP side, that's a very significant factor. But I've got to oversee a third-party vendor as if it's my own and internal shop for a business that I'm not in any longer. I think that's a factor that's driving the desire to sell, and it's true on both federal and private.
