headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you confirm that you're reducing your equity allocation to the private student loan to 8% from 12% and maybe provide a little more color on that shift?
componenttext: Could you confirm that you're reducing your equity allocation to the private student loan to 8% from 12% and maybe provide a little more color on that shift?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So when we look at what the reserve -- what the capital levels are for our portfolios, it's driven by a function of what we expect the loss rates to be and then the cap, which are covered by reserves, and then an estimate for the capital base on a va
componenttext: Yes. So when we look at what the reserve -- what the capital levels are for our portfolios, it's driven by a function of what we expect the loss rates to be and then the cap, which are covered by reserves, and then an estimate for the capital base on a variety of factors just based on what kind of funding capabilities we have on those assets, what percentage of funding we can obtain and what kinds of loss rates we might be exposed to above and beyond our expectations. As our private loan portfolio has seasoned and moved through -- substantially moved through its peak default periods and as we see a higher percentage of our portfolio covered by life of loan loss reserves, our TDR portfolio, it has moved capital from -- allowed us to basically move from providing coverage through capital through providing it through reserves. And it has allowed us to pull our capital rates down in that area.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So then would you expect to reach that 8% on a capitalization basis over a certain period of time? Or are you going to continue to operate an excess to that 8% allocation?
componenttext: So then would you expect to reach that 8% on a capitalization basis over a certain period of time? Or are you going to continue to operate an excess to that 8% allocation?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we don't think it's appropriate. When we were at 12%, and that was such an enormous cushion against kind of the potential credit losses that might occur in stressed environments, we tended to run closer to those numbers. At 8%, we formed our funding st
componenttext: So we don't think it's appropriate. When we were at 12%, and that was such an enormous cushion against kind of the potential credit losses that might occur in stressed environments, we tended to run closer to those numbers. At 8%, we formed our funding structure. So I think you'd see the capital levels that we're running at to be fairly consistent going forward.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Keith, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Navient First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Joe Fisher, you may begin your conference.
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Keith, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Navient First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Joe Fisher, you may begin your conference.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2015 First Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.Before we begin, kee
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2015 First Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.
Before we begin, keep in mind our discussion will contain predictions, expectations and forward-looking statements.
Actual results in the future may be materially different from those discussed here. This could be due to a variety of factors.
Listeners should refer to the discussion of those factors on the company's Form 10 and other filings with the SEC.
During this conference call, we will refer to non-GAAP measures we call our core earnings.
A description of core earnings, a full reconciliation to GAAP measures and our GAAP results can be found in the first quarter 2015 supplemental earnings disclosure.
This is posted, along with the earnings press release, on the Investors page at navient.com.
Thank you, and now I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our first quarter's earnings call. Thank you for listening. I appreciate your interest and your support. Later this month, on April 30, we will mark our 1 year anniversary at Navient. We've accomplishe
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our first quarter's earnings call. Thank you for listening. I appreciate your interest and your support. 
Later this month, on April 30, we will mark our 1 year anniversary at Navient. We've accomplished much in this 12-month period, and we are well positioned to continue our ongoing success in the future. 
In the past 12 months, we've acquired $13 billion in student loans, assisted over 12 million student loans, servicing customers in their path to successfully managing their loans, added $2.6 billion of projected cash flows to our Student Loan portfolio and received $4.2 billion from cash collections and financings. We returned over $948 million to shareholders in dividends and share repurchases. 
We began executing on our growth strategy, most notably with this quarter's acquisition of Gila, and we launched the Navient brand to our customers. This quarter's results, which Somsak will cover in more detail in a few minutes, continued these trends with core earnings of $0.48 a share, $830 million in student loan acquisitions, continued improvement in Student Loan performance and $363 million returned to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. 
While this quarter's results are good, we can and will do better. We need to move faster to grow and diversify our business revenues. We need to decrease our need for high cost unsecured debt, and we must continue to do more to make our business efficient. 
In Asset Management, in addition to the $830 million in student loans we acquired this quarter, we sold $189 million in third-party service FFELP loans, generating a gain of $5 million. The market for loan assets today, including student loans, is a sellers market. While we continue to expect the volume of loans available for sale to be sizable, we often see very high prices being paid. We will remain disciplined in our pricing and not chase volume for volume's sake. 
Given our significant cost advantage in servicing and our ability to deliver superior performance and customer success, our sweet spot remains whole loans, where we can convert the portfolio to our servicing platform. Here, we believe we will continue to remain competitive. However, depending on market conditions, we may offer additional portfolios of third-party service loans for sale. 
During the quarter, we realized $800 million in cash flow from our Student Loan portfolio and added an additional $1.1 billion to our future cash flows through acquisitions on lower interest rates and an improved credit expectations. 
In Business Services, we now service over $300 billion in student loans for more than 12.5 million customers. On the credit front, we continue see delinquency rates and our outlook for future expected charge-offs on our private portfolio improved. For example, the 90-day delinquency rate on our private loan portfolio fell to 3.6% at March 31 from 3.9% a year ago. 
On the FFELP side, contrary to reports of much higher national rates, our 90-day delinquency rate was 8.4% at month-end, and yes, our rate is calculated using only loans in repayment in the denominator. More importantly, for the federal loans we service, we continue to see significant improvement in recent graduates' ability to successfully manage their loans. 
For example, the class of 2014, which recently entered repayment, is showing the best performance of any recent graduating class. In fact, measured at the same time in repayment, their 30-plus delinquency rate is 1/2 the rate for borrowers who graduated in the Great Recession and 6% lower than the class of 2013. These results illustrate the continued material improvement in student loan performance we've seen since the peak of the Great Recession. 
When used wisely, educational loans help millions of students achieve their education dreams and earn a higher standard of living. And our data shows that on average, these borrowers have manageable balances and are successful in managing their loans. 
The federal loan program, however, offers limited resources to help students and families make more informed and better decisions before they borrow. As a result, although overall trends are good and are improving, not all borrowers are experiencing the potential benefits of higher education. 
As a servicer, relationship with borrowers only begins after the loan is made. As a result, our efforts and outreach are designed to help all borrowers understand the repayment options available to them and to help them navigate a path to successfully manage their loans. 
In our asset recovery business, I'm very pleased to welcome Gila to our team. Gila, which was acquired in February, adds a talented, innovative management team, proven capabilities and over 600 clients to our business platform. This acquisition is a very strong fit with our growth objectives in this space, and in just a few months, they are already exceeding plan. We'll continue to look for ways to grow in this space, both organically and through future acquisitions. 
Also during the quarter, the Department of Education decided to not extend our 2009 education loan collections contract. This was disappointing and surprising news as we have consistently achieved top performance rankings and received satisfactory reviews from the department, including the most recent review conducted after their announcement of nonrenewal. 
While the long-term opportunities for the Department of Education loan collections contract remain unresolved, we'll continue to focus our efforts on delivering superior results and the strong compliance focus our asset recovery customers have long experienced from us and count on us for. 
Total operating expenses for the quarter include several seasonal factors that did not repeat during the rest of the year. In addition, we are incurring expense associated with the acquisition of the Wells portfolio, which includes both third-party rates that run significantly higher than our own costs and onetime costs associated with the planning and execution of the transfer to the majority of these loans onto our platform. 
The conversion process remains on track to be completed before the end of the third quarter, and we will produce material benefits in both operating expense and loan performance. 
During the quarter, we continue to receive a number of requests for information from multiple regulatory bodies. The information required to be produced is voluminous and is both time intensive and costly to produce, adding to our total expenses. 
We continue to be responsive and collaborative while providing additional insight into the efforts we make to help our customers successfully manage their loans. For example, in addition to helping our customers avoid the negative consequences of default with default rates 40% better than the industry average, we recently launched a series of webinars to help our customers on a variety of financial topics, including navigating the significant and growing complexity of the Federal Student Loan Program such as differences between income-sensitive or income-based repayment options. Working with policymakers to reduce program complexity has been a significant focus for us. 
Finally, we're also keeping our commitment to maintain a strong financial profile and create value for our shareholders. Our capital levels remain both strong and conservative given our risk profile, and our reserves for loan losses cover more than 2x annualized charge-offs. 
While maintaining the strong financial profile, we've repurchased $300 million in shares, mainly in February and March and paid out $63 million in dividends during the quarter. 
I continue to remain confident in our ability to generate core earnings per share of $2.20 for the year and our ability to lead the industry and helping customers successfully manage their loans and to execute on our growth initiatives. Combined with the $35 million -- $35 billion in cash flows we expect to generate from our loan portfolio, we will continue to deliver value for our customers, employees and shareholders. 
Somsak will now provide more details of our financial results for the quarter.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings. In the first quarter, we reported core earnings of $0.48 per shar
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings. 
In the first quarter, we reported core earnings of $0.48 per share compared to $0.49 per share from a year ago after adjusting for expenses related to regulatory matters. Our first quarter operating expenses totaled $230 million, and that's compared to adjusted operating expenses of $207 million from the year-ago quarter. 
The increase in operating expenses is related to incremental cost for -- resulting from the recent Gila acquisition, incremental third-party servicing cost related to the $8.5 billion of loans acquired from Wells in the prior quarter and cost related to operating as a new separate company post spin. As a result, we do expect our core EPS to be $2.20 in 2015 and operating expenses to come in less than $900 million in 2015. 
Let's move to Slide 5 to discuss our FFELP segment results. FFELP core earnings were $85 million for the first quarter compared with $64 million in first quarter 2014. In the quarter, FFELP student loan spread was 96 basis points, and the associated NIM was 88 basis points. The full year spread will be impacted by a potential future loan acquisitions as well as future LIBOR rates, which will impact the amount of unhedged floor income in our portfolio. Going forward, we expect our FFELP student loan spread to be in the low to mid-90s and the net interest margin to be roughly 8 basis points lower than this spread. 
Let's turn to Slide 6 to review our private education loan segment results. Core earnings in this segment increased $3 million from the year-ago quarter to $77 million. Our first quarter student loan spread came in at 3.87%, and the associated NIM was 3.74%. Compared to the prior year, the spread was impacted by an increase in cost of funds in several onetime items, the largest of which was a $4.2 million acceleration of deferred financing fees. 
For the rest of 2015, we expect the private student loan spread to be approximately 4% and the associated net interest margin to be approximately 10 basis points lower than the spread. 
Our first quarter charge-offs were 2.9% or $28 million lower than the first quarter of last year. We continue to see year-over-year improvements in our forbearance, total delinquency and 90-plus day delinquency rates. The improvement in our outlook for future charge-offs led to a decrease in our provision for losses, which came in at $120 million for the quarter, and that's a decrease of $16 million from a year-ago quarter. 
Slide 7 shows our asset quality trends over the last 5 years. Our private credit portfolio is well-seasoned portfolio with 93% of our loans in repayment status having made more than 12 payments. Our highest-risk segment, what we call nontraditional loans, that portfolio is now down to only 8% of our portfolio. We expect charge-offs to continue their year-over-year improvement and our annual charge-offs for 2015 is expected to end between 2.2% and 2.4%.
Let's turn to Slide 8 to review our Business Services segment. In this segment, core earnings were $86 million in the quarter, and that's compared with $116 million in first quarter of 2014. We saw an increase in our asset recovery revenues of $9 million versus the fourth quarter, and this increase was primarily related to the acquisition of Gila, which expands our footprint in the asset recovery and business process outsourcing space. 
The decline from the year-ago quarter was driven by a new reduced free structure for guarantee agencies, which became effective on July 1, 2014. We do expect our asset recovery revenues to be approximately $90 million per quarter for the remainder of 2015. 
Today, the company services loans for 12.5 million borrowers with 6.2 million borrowers under the Department of Education servicing contract. Our third-party servicing revenue increased to $44 million in the quarter with $31 million coming from the Department of Education servicing contract. 
Let's now turn to Slide 9 for highlights of our loan acquisition or financing activity for the year. We acquired $830 million of student loans in the first quarter. 
As Jack mentioned, our best opportunity for loan purchases remain whole loan portfolios that we can convert our servicing platform. And in addition, we may be seller of additional portfolios of third-party service loans. 
Our ABS transaction continued to attract strong investor demand. In the quarter, we issued $1.7 billion of asset backed securitizations, and just last week, we priced a $997 million FFELP ABS transaction, which came in at tighter spreads than our previous ABS issuance. 
In the quarter, we issued $0.5 billion of 6-year unsecured notes to better match our maturity profile to the predictable cash flows that come from our Student Loan portfolio. In the past year, we have reduced our unsecured debt outstanding by roughly $600 million while increasing our projected cash flows by $2.6 billion, which came through loan acquisitions, higher floor income and improving credit performance. 
In the quarter, we repurchased 14.7 million shares with $300 million, and that activity mainly occurred in February and March. We have remaining authority of $700 million under our current share repurchase plan, and all of this activity was undertaken while maintaining a strong capital position. 
As of March 31, 2015, our tangible net asset to unsecured debt ratio was at 1.25x. 
And finally, turning to GAAP results on Slide 10. We recorded first quarter GAAP net income of $292 million or $0.72 per share, and that's compared with net income of $219 million or $0.49 per share in the first quarter 2014. And just as a reminder, the primary differences between core earnings and GAAP results are the related to our derivative position, expenses related to the restructuring and reorganization that came as a result of the spin transaction and an income associated with SLM BankCo. 
With that, I will now open the call for questions.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So thanks for your question, Moshe. This is one of the areas that we identified as an opportunity for growth is in the asset recovery space and particularly in the state and municipal areas. Gila, which, as I mentioned, has over 600 contracts with clients
componenttext: So thanks for your question, Moshe. This is one of the areas that we identified as an opportunity for growth is in the asset recovery space and particularly in the state and municipal areas. Gila, which, as I mentioned, has over 600 contracts with clients in 39 states across the country, really has done a great job of building a franchise that does both as a recovery and in combination with a business process outsourcing, and it's this kind of combination of activities that marry both our operations capabilities with our collections performance that is attractive to us and an area that would expect to grow both organically and through acquisitions. The organic side of the equation is obviously an area where we're most focused on and expect to be able to leverage the skills of both companies to grow faster than we would have otherwise. Somsak, you want to cover the revenue?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Revenue. Yes, the annual revenues that we expect to generate or the Gila expects to generate about along the $70 million per year.
componenttext: Revenue. Yes, the annual revenues that we expect to generate or the Gila expects to generate about along the $70 million per year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just kind of pulling up, Jack, you made a comment it sounded a little wistful, but you don't really get involved with the borrower before the borrower makes that decision to make the loan. Is there any discussion anywhere about having other part
componenttext: Okay. And just kind of pulling up, Jack, you made a comment it sounded a little wistful, but you don't really get involved with the borrower before the borrower makes that decision to make the loan. Is there any discussion anywhere about having other parties get involved in order to make that help that borrower make a more informed decision? Any opportunities that you would see for the company there.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think this is one of the challenges in this space in which we operate is that student loan servicers are deemed responsible for how well or not well borrowers do in managing their loans yet we're handed the account only after the monies been len
componenttext: Yes. So I think this is one of the challenges in this space in which we operate is that student loan servicers are deemed responsible for how well or not well borrowers do in managing their loans yet we're handed the account only after the monies been lent and spent, as we say. And one of things that we've been advocating for both on a policy side as well as with on the Department of Education is specifically that, is use some of the skills that we -- and data that we built over the years to help customers make better or more informed decisions before they borrow the funds. If you think about all of the efforts that go on in the federal loan programs today, all the borrowing initiatives are driven towards helping borrowers who have already find themselves in a position of having borrowed too much money or money than they can afford, and we think a portion of that should really go to prevention, and it's not as if you're saying, no, you can't go to school. It's just hopping borrowers pick the school that better fits their profile or understand what the true cost of or the full cost of getting a degree will be and making sure that they have the resources to be able to do that. We have all of that data and skills today. We can use that to the -- with a high degree of accuracy to predict performance and allow for very direct and almost customized outreach to borrowers before loans are made. Of course, someone has to be willing to pay for that, that level of education and service.

componenttext: I wonder is there anything more you can say about the Department of Ed collections contract loss, and kind of relating what they did to what you got in your reviews? Better explanation now?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as we said, they have -- they did not provide us -- they simply decided not to extend our contract. They did not terminate it. And as a result of that, the view has been they have not needed to provide us with a detailed information behind some of
componenttext: Yes. So as we said, they have -- they did not provide us -- they simply decided not to extend our contract. They did not terminate it. And as a result of that, the view has been they have not needed to provide us with a detailed information behind some of their statements. We continue to press for that. I think the filing in federal courts delayed a little bit or impacts the ability to share that information. That was a court decision to dismiss the case on jurisdictional grounds. We're still waiting for the actual writeup of the opinion here before we make decisions on the next steps, but we are obviously disappointed in the process. We would expect that if someone is making a claim of noncompliance that we would be -- have the opportunity to review those instances and be able to respond. We know that when we look at our own work here and when we look at the reviews that the Department of Ed conducted over the past 1.5 years, we don't see similar kinds of issues or findings.

componenttext: We -- so our plan is to continue -- we have $17 billion of unsecured debt outstanding. Our plan is to continue to reduce that as the portfolio amortizes. One of the challenges in the marketplace today is that the unsecured debt is clearly our most expensive source of financing for our portfolio, and we're really looking at different ways to reduce the demand or the need for that as a source of funding, and that includes both ABS funding as well as the prepayment of the debt or repayment of the debt through cash flow collections.

componenttext: Okay. And I know that we've seen consolidations to third parties pick up a little bit in your FFELP portfolio. Just can you talk about your thoughts there, and whether you would contemplate some sort of refi-ed product at this point to capture some of those consolidations? Or how you you're thinking about that space?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the marketplace is definitely -- as interest rates extremely low it's definitely more attractive right now. It is targeted principally to borrowers with coming out of graduate schools. So high balance debt, a good income, good credit profile -- very, v
componenttext: So the marketplace is definitely -- as interest rates extremely low it's definitely more attractive right now. It is targeted principally to borrowers with coming out of graduate schools. So high balance debt, a good income, good credit profile -- very, very high credit profiles of the customers. So it hasn't had a huge impact on our holdings of loans. It's been a bigger issue on the servicing side of the equation. So it's a marketplace that we think has some positive attributes to it, and we continue to look at it.

componenttextpreview: I just had a couple of questions maybe to drill down on the question before. I mean, Sallie Mae basically sold a bunch of loans at 10.5% premiums. I guess when we think about those levels of premiums, do you think that that's something that's attractive f
componenttext: I just had a couple of questions maybe to drill down on the question before. I mean, Sallie Mae basically sold a bunch of loans at 10.5% premiums. I guess when we think about those levels of premiums, do you think that that's something that's attractive for you guys to go out and sell at in terms of the level? And then second, I guess how do you think about that in terms of you being able to purchase loans from Sallie Mae going forward?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So obviously, the premiums paid on any portfolio are highly dependent upon the cash flows of the individual transactions. So this was a relatively new portfolio so long average lives, high yielding and high credit quality. There's no question about it has
componenttext: So obviously, the premiums paid on any portfolio are highly dependent upon the cash flows of the individual transactions. So this was a relatively new portfolio so long average lives, high yielding and high credit quality. There's no question about it has an impact on our ability to purchase those portfolios. The transaction that you mentioned was sold in both ABS and then a residual sale, and buyers are -- I would look at it as being people who are looking at alternatives to just traditional corporate debt. That makes it difficult for us to compete in that particular space. Whether or not you're a buyer or seller, our own portfolios really as a function of the individual cash flows associated with those deals and not so much the price that's being paid, but it is the reflection of what we would expect the cash flows to be, what the appropriate discount rate is and then what a potential buyer would apply in those set of circumstances. So it's to the extent they match up against what we would expect or be different, that would drive most of those decisions.

componenttext: Yes, no question. I mean, we look at our portfolios of student loans as a -- as we own a series of cash flows. Those cash flows happen to be very predictable, sizable, $35 billion is the expected life of loan cash flows on that. If someone else puts a higher value on those cash flows than we do, we -- it's a financial asset that we own here, and we should be looking at it as such.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. And then I guess my second question is, Jack, you mentioned that banks are sellers of these assets, but pricing is definitely aggressive or competitive. Could you just talk about what your thoughts are in terms of an acquisition this year a
componenttext: Okay, perfect. And then I guess my second question is, Jack, you mentioned that banks are sellers of these assets, but pricing is definitely aggressive or competitive. Could you just talk about what your thoughts are in terms of an acquisition this year and based on the landscape that's shaping up. I think U.S. Bank moved some of its loans to held for sale. Bank of America's done the same. So maybe you can just talk about that a little bit.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we did buy $830 million of loans this quarter. We look for portfolios where we can add value. Where we add value is where we can apply our significantly lower cost of servicing to a portfolio and drive better cash flow performance. Our customers t
componenttext: Yes. So we did buy $830 million of loans this quarter. We look for portfolios where we can add value. Where we add value is where we can apply our significantly lower cost of servicing to a portfolio and drive better cash flow performance. Our customers that default at the lower rate, 40% lower than the national average. And so when you combine those 2 things, that's where we both deliver and can capture value from acquisitions. Portfolios that are sold with life-of-loan servicing on third-party platforms, we can't bring any of those benefits to the borrowers or to the portfolio, and so our pricing is, by definition, less competitive, and those portfolios are less attractive to us. Some of them, some of the transactions that we have not acquired this year, the majority of them are, in fact, those types of transactions, life-of-loan servicing out of third-party platform.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up on the acquisition. As you're looking at these collections platform, I guess where do you see the most opportunity? Is it the student loan area? Are there other opportunities in student loans?
componenttext: Just to follow up on the acquisition. As you're looking at these collections platform, I guess where do you see the most opportunity? Is it the student loan area? Are there other opportunities in student loans?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So when we refer -- what we look for in the asset recovery space is asset classes and programs where through both a combination of our efforts and the rationale for the consumer to resolve the outstanding debt match up well. So we don't do work in things
componenttext: So when we refer -- what we look for in the asset recovery space is asset classes and programs where through both a combination of our efforts and the rationale for the consumer to resolve the outstanding debt match up well. So we don't do work in things like credit card asset recovery. It's a commodity -- more of a commodity service area that's not particularly attractive. When we do things in a municipal area, it may be fines or taxes that need to be paid in order to renew their license or free up a lien on property. So there's an added incentive to do that. We like the space a lot. It's an area where we have a relatively small market share today even with the Gila acquisition. We think the space, in particular, offers an opportunity to combine both asset recovery and business processing services to the entities, which help make the business more leverageable from a margin perspective, and that's really where the focus has been in terms of our growth. We do an outstanding job in the education space. We lead the industry in terms of helping customers rehabilitate their loans. A huge benefit to the customer in terms of the value that they receive for resolving a debt obligation owed to the federal government, which does not go away, but it is an area on the guarantor side of the equation, where the portfolio available to collect is declining as loans have moved into direct lending and the contract moves to the Department of Ed side of the equation. We are very interested in winning a role in the new contract in that space, but it obviously has to be at the economics in terms of both margin and regulatory aspects that combined to make it attractive for us.

componenttext: Well. Our equity capital is similarly really supporting the majority of it is supporting our student loan assets as well and principally on the private credit side of the equation, FFELP assets don't require a lot of capital as you know., And so certainly as the portfolio amortizes and the cash flow is generated, we see opportunities of returns is coming from 2 sources: the excess spread generated or as you call it, the...

componenttext: I had a couple of questions. The first one was if you could just revisit your commentary around the NIM for private student loans. It sounds like you talked about the year-over-year decline in the NIM, and I think you called out $4.2 million?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: In accelerated deferred financing fees. So can you just flesh that out again what that specifically related to? And then if one were to look at the sequential decline in the NIM for private student loans, if I'm doing my math correctly, it looks like the
componenttext: In accelerated deferred financing fees. So can you just flesh that out again what that specifically related to? And then if one were to look at the sequential decline in the NIM for private student loans, if I'm doing my math correctly, it looks like the dollar impact is closer to $10 million or $11 million. So what else might have been flowing through that line item that may have affected the NIM this quarter? Can you just talk about that? That'd be helpful.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure. The $4.2 million item was really related to a specific piece of financing that was redeemed early, and once it was redeemed early, we had deferred financing fees that we previously capitalized, and that gets amortized over the expected remaini
componenttext: Sure, sure. The $4.2 million item was really related to a specific piece of financing that was redeemed early, and once it was redeemed early, we had deferred financing fees that we previously capitalized, and that gets amortized over the expected remaining life of the debt. So since it was called early, this -- we have to charge-off that amount ran through NIM. As far as the remaining -- you're right. I'll call it the other items as far as the sequential reduction in NIM probably accounted for about $10 million or so. It's just a variety of other one -- smaller onetime items that ran through the quarters that we don't expect to recur for the rest of the year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. Okay. And just switching gears a little bit. Jack, you talked about your interest in acquiring additional debt recovery companies, collection company. Now would you wait until you get additional clarification from the CFPB as far as
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. Okay. And just switching gears a little bit. Jack, you talked about your interest in acquiring additional debt recovery companies, collection company. Now would you wait until you get additional clarification from the CFPB as far as even new rules because in the proposed rules for say, the lending industry, that's created significant amount of turmoil for that industry. So my sense is you probably prefer to wait for additional clarity from the CFPB as far as new rules for the debt recovery, but I just want to get a sense for whether you feel additional acquisition may be more than 12 months out once we get more clarity? Or are you willing to at the right price pull the trigger sooner than that?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the -- it all depends on the type of asset class that the entity is operating within. In the state and municipal side of the equation set a combination these activities can be combination of both asset recovery and processing. So it may be t
componenttext: Well, I think the -- it all depends on the type of asset class that the entity is operating within. In the state and municipal side of the equation set a combination these activities can be combination of both asset recovery and processing. So it may be the billing activities associated with an unpaid receivable, notifications about options to repay on that and then actually processing the collection work. That's an area where we think the rules are pretty clear. We have a very strong internal compliance program to monitor our activities in this particular space and had built systems and controls that help us do a great job for our clients while maintaining a strong compliance profile. We obviously would continue to work and have a close working relationship with the CFPB to make sure we understand those rules, talk about where there are areas for potential borrower confusion or impact and make sure that we're adjusting our activities accordingly so that it's a net work in compliance and doing a better job for our clients.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of the litigation against the DOE you provided some commentary earlier, but I just wanted to clarify. It sounds like the judge there has not opined on the merits of the case. So as you mentioned it, the decision was more based on j
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of the litigation against the DOE you provided some commentary earlier, but I just wanted to clarify. It sounds like the judge there has not opined on the merits of the case. So as you mentioned it, the decision was more based on jurisdictional grounds, but where do you stand now in terms of that litigation? Are you going to have a chance to discuss the merits of the case and try to get additional information from the DOE as far as specifically what things you violated? Or are you going to need to file a separate lawsuit? Can you just tell us where that ends in terms of the legal process?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: So the case was dismissed on jurisdictional grounds. The opinion has not been issued yet, and I think until -- next steps would really take place once we've had a chance to read the opinion and understand better what the judge's ruling was based on and then explore what our other options are. But you're correct in that he did not rule on the merits of the case, just the jurisdiction.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just had a couple of follow-up questions. First, I wanted to clarify the comments around loan portfolio acquisition. Jack, you had indicated that it is a bit of a seller's market, and pricing is aggressive. But my question is are you seeing that same
componenttext: Yes. Just had a couple of follow-up questions. First, I wanted to clarify the comments around loan portfolio acquisition. Jack, you had indicated that it is a bit of a seller's market, and pricing is aggressive. But my question is are you seeing that same level of competition around portfolios that really are in your sweet spot where there's no finance attached and no life-of-loan servicing, where presumably there just aren't competitors out there who can bring to bear the same advantages that you can.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the competition is equal I think in both whether the loans are servicing release or tied to third-party servicing. The difference is that in a loan portfolio with servicing release, we can actually bring significant advantages, cost advantages to th
componenttext: Well, the competition is equal I think in both whether the loans are servicing release or tied to third-party servicing. The difference is that in a loan portfolio with servicing release, we can actually bring significant advantages, cost advantages to the equation that others who don't have a servicing platform, which is one of the places where the high prices are coming from cannot. So that's a big differentiator. The other piece of this is clearly size, right? I mean, the bigger the portfolio, the better, the more competitive we can be simply because it limits how many people have the availability to come up with that kind of cash to purchase a whole loan portfolio. When selling residuals even though the notional amount of the loans is -- could be relatively high. The actual check that is required could be written could be relatively small. I hope that helps.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: Okay. Now just a follow-up question on capital returns. I think in the past when you are part of Sallie Mae had a policy of kind of setting a repurchase authorization for the year to the board then kind of blowing through it relatively early and then going back and getting permission for more. I think, Jack, you've indicated that your preference going forward is to kind of set the amount of the beginning of the year and having that be what you buy back. You did buy back a little bit more than the kind of the annualized pace of $1 billion. Should we still expect that that's kind of the number for 2015 or might you go back late in the year and ask for authorization about to buy back more stock?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we are trying to provide a more visible, predictable pace of activity. So the $1 billion is what we expect to repurchase this year.
componenttext: No, we are trying to provide a more visible, predictable pace of activity. So the $1 billion is what we expect to repurchase this year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Keith, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Navient First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Joe Fisher, you may begin your conference.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2015 First Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.Before we begin, kee
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2015 First Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.
Before we begin, keep in mind our discussion will contain predictions, expectations and forward-looking statements. Actual results in the future may be materially different from those discussed here. This could be due to a variety of factors. Listeners should refer to the discussion of those factors on the company's Form 10 and other filings with the SEC.
During this conference call, we will refer to non-GAAP measures we call our core earnings. A description of core earnings, a full reconciliation to GAAP measures and our GAAP results can be found in the first quarter 2015 supplemental earnings disclosure. This is posted, along with the earnings press release, on the Investors page at navient.com.
Thank you, and now I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our first quarter's earnings call. Thank you for listening. I appreciate your interest and your support.Later this month, on April 30, we will mark our 1 year anniversary at Navient. We've accomplished
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our first quarter's earnings call. Thank you for listening. I appreciate your interest and your support.
Later this month, on April 30, we will mark our 1 year anniversary at Navient. We've accomplished much in this 12-month period, and we are well positioned to continue our ongoing success in the future.
In the past 12 months, we've acquired $13 billion in student loans, assisted over 12 million student loans, servicing customers in their path to successfully managing their loans, added $2.6 billion of projected cash flows to our student loan portfolio and received $4.2 billion from cash collections and financings. We returned over $948 million to shareholders in dividends and share repurchases. We began executing on our growth strategy, most notably with this quarter's acquisition of Gila, and we launched the Navient brand to our customers.
This quarter's results, which Somsak will cover in more detail in a few minutes, continued these trends with core earnings of $0.48 a share, $830 million in student loan acquisitions, continued improvement in student loan performance and $363 million returned to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. While this quarter's results are good, we can and will do better. We need to move faster to grow and diversify our business revenues. We need to decrease our need for high-cost unsecured debt, and we must continue to do more to make our business efficient.
In asset management, in addition to the $830 million in student loans we acquired this quarter, we sold $189 million in third-party service FFELP loans, generating a gain of $5 million. The market for loan assets today, including student loans, is a sellers' market. While we continue to expect the volume of loans available for sale to be sizable, we often see very high prices being paid. We will remain disciplined in our pricing and not chase volume for volumes' sake.
Given our significant cost advantage in servicing and our ability to deliver superior performance and customer success, our sweet spot remains whole loans where we can convert the portfolio to our servicing platform. Here, we believe we will continue to remain competitive. However, depending on market conditions, we may offer additional portfolios of third-party service loans for sale.
During the quarter, we realized $800 million in cash flow from our student loan portfolio and added an additional $1.1 billion to our future cash flows through acquisitions from lower interest rates and in improved credit expectations.
In business services, we now service over $300 billion in student loans for more than 12.5 million customers. On the credit front, we continue see delinquency rates and our outlook for future expected charge-offs on our private portfolio improve. For example, the 90-day delinquency rate on our private loan portfolio fell to 3.6% at March 31 from 3.9% a year ago.
On the FFELP side, contrary to reports of much higher national rates, our 90-day delinquency rate was 8.4% at month end, and yes, our rate is calculated using only loans in repayment in the denominator.
More importantly, for the federal loans we service, we continue to see significant improvement in recent graduates' ability to successfully manage their loans. For example, the class of 2014, which recently entered repayment, is showing the best performance of any recent graduating class. In fact, measured at the same time in repayment, their 30-plus delinquency rate is 1/2 the rate for borrowers who graduated in the Great Recession and 6% lower than the class of 2013. These results illustrate the continued material improvement in student loan performance we have seen since the peak of the Great Recession.
When used wisely, educational loans help millions of students achieve their education dreams and earn a higher standard of living. And our data shows that on average, these borrowers have manageable balances and are successful in managing their loans.
The federal loan program, however, offers limited resources to help students and families make more informed and better decisions before they borrow. As a result, although overall trends are good and are improving, not all borrowers are experiencing the potential benefits of higher education.
As a servicer, our relationship with borrowers only begins after the loan is made. As a result, our efforts and outreach are designed to help all borrowers understand the repayment options available to them and to help them navigate a path to successfully manage their loans.
In our asset recovery business, I'm very pleased to welcome Gila to our team. Gila, which was acquired in February, adds a talented, innovative management team, proven capabilities and over 600 clients to our business platform. This acquisition is a very strong fit with our growth objectives in this space, and in just a few months, they are already exceeding plan. We'll continue to look for ways to grow in this space, both organically and through future acquisitions.
Also during the quarter, the Department of Education decided to not extend our 2009 education loan collections contract. This was disappointing and surprising news as we had consistently achieved top performance rankings and received satisfactory reviews from the department, including the most recent review conducted after their announcement of nonrenewal.
While the long-term opportunities for the Department of Education loan collections contract remain unresolved, we'll continue to focus our efforts on delivering superior results and the strong compliance focus our asset recovery customers have long experienced from us and count on us for.
Total operating expenses for the quarter include several seasonal factors that did not repeat during the rest of the year. In addition, we are incurring expense associated with the acquisition of the Wells portfolio, which includes both third-party rates that run significantly higher than our own costs and onetime costs associated with the planning and execution of the transfer of the majority of these loans onto our platform. The conversion process remains on track to be completed before the end of the third quarter, and we will produce material benefits in both operating expense and loan performance.
During the quarter, we continue to receive a number of requests for information from multiple regulatory bodies. The information required to be produced is voluminous and is both time intensive and costly to produce, adding to our total expenses.
We continue to be responsive and collaborative while providing additional insight into the efforts we make to help our customers successfully manage their loans. For example, in addition to helping our customers avoid the negative consequences of default with default rates 40% better than the industry average, we recently launched a series of webinars to help our customers on a variety of financial topics, including navigating the significant and growing complexity of the Federal Student Loan Program such as differences between income-sensitive or income-based repayment options. Working with policymakers to reduce program complexity has been a significant focus for us.
Finally, we're also keeping our commitment to maintain a strong financial profile and create value for our shareholders. Our capital levels remain both strong and conservative given our risk profile, and our reserves for loan losses cover more than 2x annualized charge-offs.
While maintaining the strong financial profile, we've repurchased $300 million in shares, mainly in February and March, and paid out $63 million in dividends during the quarter.
I continue to remain confident in our ability to generate core earnings per share of $2.20 for the year and our ability to lead the industry and helping customers successfully manage their loans and to execute on our growth initiatives. Combined with the $35 million -- $35 billion in cash flows we expect to generate from our loan portfolio, we will continue to deliver value for our customers, employees and shareholders.
Somsak will now provide more details of our financial results for the quarter. Sak?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings.In the first quarter, we reported core earnings of $0.48 per share
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings.
In the first quarter, we reported core earnings of $0.48 per share compared to $0.49 per share from a year ago after adjusting for expenses related to regulatory matters. Our first quarter operating expenses totaled $230 million, and that's compared to adjusted operating expenses of $207 million from the year ago quarter.
The increase in operating expenses is related to incremental cost for -- resulting from the recent Gila acquisition, incremental third-party servicing cost related to the $8.5 billion of loans acquired from Wells in the prior quarter and cost related to operating as a new separate company post spin. As a result, we do expect our core EPS to be $2.20 in 2015 and operating expenses to come in less than $900 million for 2015.
Let's move to Slide 5 to discuss our FFELP segment results. FFELP core earnings were $85 million for the first quarter compared with $64 million in first quarter of 2014. In the quarter, FFELP student loan spread was 96 basis points, and the associated NIM was 88 basis points.
The full year spread will be impacted by potential future loan acquisitions as well as future LIBOR rates, which will impact the amount of unhedged floor income in our portfolio. Going forward, we expect our FFELP student loan spread to be in the low to mid-90s and the net interest margin to be roughly 8 basis points lower than this spread.
Let's turn to Slide 6 to review our private education loan segment results. Core earnings in this segment increased $3 million from the year ago quarter to $77 million. Our first quarter student loan spread came in at 3.87% and the associated NIM was 3.74%.
Compared to the prior year, the spread was impacted by an increase in cost of funds in several onetime items, the largest of which was a $4.2 million acceleration of deferred financing fees. For the rest of 2015, we expect the private student loan spread to be approximately 4% and the associated net interest margin to be approximately 10 basis points lower than the spread.
Our first quarter charge-offs were 2.9% or $28 million lower than the first quarter of last year. And we continue to see year-over-year improvements in our forbearance, total delinquency and 90-plus-day delinquency rates. The improvement in our outlook for future charge-offs led to a decrease in our provision for losses, which came in at $120 million for the quarter, and that's a decrease of $16 million from a year ago quarter.
Slide 7 shows our asset quality trends over the last 5 years. Our private credit portfolio is a well-seasoned portfolio with 93% of our loans in repayment status having made more than 12 payments. Our highest risk segment, what we call nontraditional loans, that portfolio is now down to only 8% of our portfolio. We expect charge-offs to continue their year-over-year improvement, and our annual charge-offs for 2015 is expected to end between 2.2% and 2.4%.
Let's turn to Slide 8 to review our business services segment. In this segment, core earnings were $86 million in the quarter, and that's compared with $116 million in first quarter of 2014. We saw an increase in our asset recovery revenues of $9 million versus the fourth quarter, and this increase was primarily related to the acquisition of Gila, which expands our footprint in the asset recovery and business process outsourcing space.
The decline from the year ago quarter was driven by a new reduced free [ph] structure for guarantee agencies, which became effective on July 1, 2014. We do expect our asset recovery revenues to be approximately $90 million per quarter for the remainder of 2015.
Today, the company services loans for 12.5 million borrowers, with 6.2 million borrowers under the Department of Education servicing contract. Our third-party servicing revenue increased to $44 million in the quarter, with $31 million coming from the Department of Education servicing contract.
Let's now turn to Slide 9 for highlights of our loan acquisition or financing activity for the year. We acquired $830 million of student loans in the first quarter. As Jack mentioned, our best opportunity for loan purchases remain whole loan portfolios that we can convert to our servicing platform. And in addition, we may be a seller of additional portfolios of third-party service loans.
Our ABS transaction continued to attract strong investor demand. In the quarter, we issued $1.7 billion of asset-backed securitizations. And just last week, we priced a $997 million FFELP ABS transaction, which came in at tighter spreads than our previous ABS issuance.
In the quarter, we issued $0.5 billion of 6-year unsecured notes to better match our maturity profile to the predictable cash flows that come from our student loan portfolio. In the past year, we have reduced our unsecured debt outstanding by roughly $600 million while increasing our projected cash flows by $2.6 billion, which came through loan acquisitions, higher floor income and improving credit performance.
In the quarter, we repurchased 14.7 million shares for $300 million, and that activity mainly occurred in February and March. We have remaining authority of $700 million under our current share repurchase plan, and all of this activity was undertaken while maintaining a strong capital position. As of March 31, 2015, our tangible net asset to unsecured debt ratio was at 1.25x.
And finally, turning to GAAP results on Slide 10. We recorded first quarter GAAP net income of $292 million or $0.72 per share, and that's compared with net income of $219 million or $0.49 per share in the first quarter 2014. And just as a reminder, the primary differences between core earnings and GAAP results are the march [ph] related to our derivative position, expenses related to the restructuring and reorganization that came as a result of the spin transaction and any income associated with SLM BankCo.
With that, I will now open the call for questions.

componenttextpreview: So thanks for your question, Moshe. This is one of the areas that we identified as an opportunity for our growth, is in the asset recovery space and particularly, in the state and municipal areas. Gila, which, as I mentioned, has over 600 contracts with c
componenttext: So thanks for your question, Moshe. This is one of the areas that we identified as an opportunity for our growth, is in the asset recovery space and particularly, in the state and municipal areas. Gila, which, as I mentioned, has over 600 contracts with clients in 39 states across the country, really has done a great job of building a franchise that does both, as a recovery and in combination with a business process outsourcing, and it's this kind of combination of activities that marry both our operations capabilities with our collections performance that is attractive to us and an area that we'd expect to grow both organically and through acquisitions. The organic side of the equation is obviously an area where we're most focused on and expect to be able to leverage the skills of both companies to grow faster than we would have otherwise. Sak, do you want to cover the...

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The revenue? Yes. The annual revenues that we expect to generate -- or the Gila expects to generate about -- along $70 million per year.
componenttext: The revenue? Yes. The annual revenues that we expect to generate -- or the Gila expects to generate about -- along $70 million per year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just kind of pulling up, Jack, you made a comment, it sounded a little wistful, that you don't really get involved with a borrower before the borrower makes that decision to make the loan. Is there any discussion anywhere about having other part
componenttext: Okay. And just kind of pulling up, Jack, you made a comment, it sounded a little wistful, that you don't really get involved with a borrower before the borrower makes that decision to make the loan. Is there any discussion anywhere about having other parties get involved in order to make the -- make that -- help that borrower make a more informed decision? Any opportunities that you would see for the company in there?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think this is one of the challenges in this space in which we operate, is that student loan servicers are deemed responsible for how well or not well borrowers do in managing their loans, yet we're handed the account only after the money has bee
componenttext: Yes. So I think this is one of the challenges in this space in which we operate, is that student loan servicers are deemed responsible for how well or not well borrowers do in managing their loans, yet we're handed the account only after the money has been lent and spent, as we say. And one of things that we've been advocating for, both on a policy side as well as with -- on -- with the Department of Education is specifically that, is use some of the skills that we -- and data that we've built over the years to help customers make better or more informed decisions before they borrow the funds. If you think about all of the efforts that go on in the federal loan programs today, all the borrower initiatives are driven towards helping borrowers who have already -- or find themselves in a position of having borrowed too much money or more money than they can afford, and we think a portion of that should really go to prevention. And it's not as if you're saying, "No, you don't -- you can't go to school," it's just helping borrowers pick the school that better fits their profile or understand what the true cost or the full cost of getting a degree will be and making sure that they have the resources to be able to do that. We have all of that data and skills today. We can use that to the -- with a high degree of accuracy to predict performance and allow for our very direct and almost customized outreach to borrowers before the loans are made. Of course, someone has to be willing to pay for that, that level of education and service.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder is there anything more you can say about the Department of Ed collections contract loss and kind of relating what they did to what you got in your reviews? Is there better explanation now?
componenttext: I wonder is there anything more you can say about the Department of Ed collections contract loss and kind of relating what they did to what you got in your reviews? Is there better explanation now?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as we've said, we -- they have -- they did not provide us -- they simply decided not to extend our contract. They did not terminate it. And as a result of that, the view has been that they have not needed to provide us with the detailed informatio
componenttext: Yes. So as we've said, we -- they have -- they did not provide us -- they simply decided not to extend our contract. They did not terminate it. And as a result of that, the view has been that they have not needed to provide us with the detailed information behind some of their statements. We continue to press for that. I think the filing in federal courts delayed a little bit or is -- impacts the ability to share that information. There was a court decision to dismiss the case on jurisdiction grounds. We're still waiting for the actual writeup of the opinion here before we make decisions on the next steps. But we are obviously disappointed in the process. We would expect that if someone is making a claim of noncompliance that we would be -- have the opportunity to review those instances and be able to respond. We know that when we look at our own work here and when we look at the reviews that the Department of Ed conducted over the past 1.5 years, we don't see similar kinds of issues or findings.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And did they say that you were able to bid for future contracts or that's no longer possible?
componenttext: And did they say that you were able to bid for future contracts or that's no longer possible?

componenttext: They continue to say that we remain -- our position as one of the finalists in the new collections contract remains. No decision has been made on that contract at this point in time.

componenttext: Okay. And then do you have a plan for how much long-term debt you might prepay this year?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We -- so our plan is to continue to -- we have $17 billion of unsecured debt outstanding. Our plan is to continue to reduce that as the portfolio amortizes. One of the challenges in the marketplace today is that the unsecured debt is clearly our most expe
componenttext: We -- so our plan is to continue to -- we have $17 billion of unsecured debt outstanding. Our plan is to continue to reduce that as the portfolio amortizes. One of the challenges in the marketplace today is that the unsecured debt is clearly our most expensive source of financing for our portfolio, and we're really looking at different ways to reduce the demand or the need for that as a source of funding, and that includes both ABS funding as well as the prepayment of the debt or repayment of the debt through cash flow collections.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you might -- I mean, given as backed [ph] initiatives, you might securitize more of the unencumbered loans and pay down some more?
componenttext: Okay. So you might -- I mean, given as backed [ph] initiatives, you might securitize more of the unencumbered loans and pay down some more?

componenttext: Right. But regardless of that, I mean, the balance of unsecured debt will decline.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
