headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, and welcome to Navient 2015 Second Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.Before we begin,
componenttext:
Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, and welcome to Navient 2015 Second Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.
Before we begin, keep in mind our discussion will contain predictions, expectations and forward-looking statements.
Actual results in the future may be materially different from those discussed here. This could be due to a variety of factors.
Listeners should refer to the discussion of those factors on the company's Form 10-K and other filings with the SEC.
During this conference call, we will refer to non-GAAP measures we call our core earnings.
A description of core earnings, full reconciliation to GAAP measures and our GAAP results can be found in the second quarter 2015 supplemental earnings disclosure.
This is posted, along with the earnings press release, on the Investors page at navient.com.
Thank you, and now I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to our second quarter's earnings call. Thanks for listening, and I appreciate your interest and support. So even though the financial performance on many of our segments of our business was strong, a few
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to our second quarter's earnings call. Thanks for listening, and I appreciate your interest and support. 
So even though the financial performance on many of our segments of our business was strong, a few areas were not. This quarter's results and our revised guidance for 2015 are clearly a disappointment in direction and impact. 
Our results and the change in guidance were really driven by 3 main items. First, our original forecast assumed we would be able to purchase Private Education Loans this year. Aggressive bidding from others and delayed timing by some sellers reduced the prospects here. While we still expect to have the opportunity to bid on private loan portfolios later this year, if successful, they will likely occur too late to contribute to this year's earnings. 
Also included in our forecast was the ability to refinance some of our higher-cost asset-backed securities issued during the recession. The opportunities to do so have not materialized thus far, but we will continue to pursue them. 
Finally, we've seen higher default rates than we projected in a narrow segment of our private loan portfolio. This segment of borrowers returned to school during the great recession and exited from their in-school deferment in 2014. 
The size of exits also increased to $2.5 billion in 2014, up from $1.8 billion in 2013. We expect deferment exits to decline to $1.7 billion in 2015. These 2014 exits, which did not include borrowers who were entering repayment for the first time, are experiencing significantly higher levels of delinquency and default from prior cohorts. 
As a result, we increased our loss forecast for 2015 by approximately $100 million. We believe we have this issue well reserved for. 
While the impact on our financial results for 2015 from these items is not insignificant, they're not reflective of the larger story here. 
First, our expected cash flows from our Student Loan portfolio remain a sizable $33.2 billion, and year-to-date, our Student Loan portfolio generated $1.6 billion in loan-related cash flow, and we added $500 million in expected future cash flows from a combination of student loan acquisitions, net of financings, and increased forecast of floor income. 
This quarter also saw positive trends in several other areas. For example, we've purchased $1 billion in student loans. We achieved a second-place finish in the Department of Education loan servicing scorecard, driven by our industry-leading default prevention success. 
We saw another year-over-year improvement in new college graduate credit trends and generated strong growth of fee income from our asset recovery businesses, and we returned over $360 million to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. 
Earlier this quarter, we announced an organizational redesign and a corresponding restructuring. This effort is designed to align our business units to further improve organizational effectiveness and efficiency. 
We created 2 main business teams: an asset management and servicing group and asset recovery and business services group. We also streamlined layers to improve speed of execution, efficiency and enhanced the lines of responsibility in these business areas. 
While the primary objectives of this change -- changes, which contributed to a restructuring charge of $29 million this quarter, which will improve the effectiveness and align our team into the related business groups, these changes will also improve our operating efficiency going forward. 
For example, we expect to see a total run rate benefit in operating expense of approximately $25 million in 2016. Growing our fee-related business lines and improving our operating margins continues to be a major area of focus for us. For example, we have been successfully growing our asset recovery revenue with a focus in areas beyond student loans. 
Earlier this year, we acquired Gila, a $70 million in revenue asset recovery and business service company, to add to this effort. The integration process has proceeded very smoothly, and Gila's management team has quickly demonstrated their capabilities with the successful implementation of a large and very complicated services contract and overall performance better than expectations. 
We continue to look for opportunities to expand our asset recovery and business services skills into new areas. In our loan servicing operations, we also continue to deliver superior results. We excel at helping our federal student loan customers successfully manage their student loans with overall default rates that are 48% lower than all other servicers combined. 
Our efforts to help our customers understand the very complex array of repayment options available to them and select the option that helps them successfully manage their loans. While our efforts continue to produce lower delinquency and default rates, the economy is also helping borrowers as they leave school. 
Combined, these factors are driving significantly better loan performance. Each spring, we track the performance of recent graduates as they enter repayment for the first time. 
Looking at the performance of recent graduates 6 months into repayment, we see that the incidence of severe delinquency has fallen each and every year from a recession high of 22% for the class of 2010 to a low of 8% for the class of 2014, the most recent graduating class to enter repayment. Our better-than-average delinquency default performance is the result of our data-driven outreach efforts that help us reach borrowers and offer affordable solutions. This is why we advocate so strongly for customer contact. It works. 
With the reauthorization of the federal student loan programs gearing up, we've been strong advocates for program simplicity and for tools that help students and families make their decisions about paying for college before they borrow. Today, in the federal loan programs, there are 15 repayment options, 8 loan forgiveness programs and some 35 forbearance and deferment options for federal borrowers to navigate. 
Not surprisingly, our customers seek our help to understand the options they're eligible for and how to choose the plan that works best for them. These federal efforts, however, are focused on helping borrowers manage payments only after the loan is made. Simplifying this complexity and helping borrowers make more informed decisions before they borrow should be top priorities. 
Moody's and Fitch's ABS teams recently wrote about the impact of extended repayment options on federal student loan asset-backed securities. In their view, this may impact whether or not a bond is paid in full by the bond -- legal final maturity date. We actively monitor the performance of our student loans Securitization Trust, including adherence to the final -- the legal final maturity date. 
Since 2013, we have amended 17 trusts and exercised loan purchase rights of $428 million to address potential issues. In order to amend the legal final maturity date, we encourage note holders to reach out to us so we can work with the agencies to modify the terms and successfully resolve this potential issue. 
As the largest issuer of student loan backed securities, we take our leadership role seriously, and we're working with the rating agencies, trustees and investors to develop alternatives to minimize any impact to our ABS investors. These efforts are consistent with our commitments to maintain a strong financial profile for our investors. 
Our capital and liquidity remain both strong and conservative given our risk profile, and our reserves for loan losses cover more than 2x annualized charge-offs. Our capital return approach is fully consistent with these commitments. 
At Navient, we have made a significant and ongoing investments in customer success and compliance. We believe that our success is aligned with our customers' success. 
Since the recession, we've been engaged with several regulatory agencies and have responded to numerous data requests. While these inquiries are time and data intensive and therefore, are costly, our focus is to remain responsive and collaborative. We also make the effort to provide additional insight into the trends we see and the efforts we make to drive customer success. 
We're extremely proud of our track record in producing the highest success rates in the industry. We believe our experience and ability to use our deep data to continue to drive customer success are the foundation of our continued ability to add value. 
Finally, while I am deeply disappointed with the impact a few areas had on our financial goals, I am confident in our ability to execute on our business plan, and I am committed and our team is committed to creating value for our customers, employees, bond investors and shareholders. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Somsak for a more detailed view of the financial results.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation beginning on Slide 4, which provides a summary of our. In the second quarter, we reported $0.40 per share, and that's compared to $0.56
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation beginning on Slide 4, which provides a summary of our. 
In the second quarter, we reported $0.40 per share, and that's compared to $0.56 per share from a year-ago quarter. Our second quarter operating expenses totaled $225 million compared to operating expenses of $195 million from the year-ago quarter. The increase in operating expenses related to incremental cost resulting from the recent acquisition of Gila, incremental third-party servicing cost related to the $8.5 billion of loans acquired in fourth quarter of 2014, higher servicing and asset recovery bonds and increased regulatory compliance costs. 
We expect core EPS to be approximately $1.85 in 2015 and operating expenses of less than $900 million for 2015. 
Now let's turn to Slide 5 to discuss our FFELP segment results. FFELP core earnings were $93 million for the second quarter compared to $72 million in the second quarter of 2014. 
In the quarter, the FFELP student loan spread was 91 basis points, and the associated NIM was 81 basis points. The FFELP NIM may be impacted by future loan acquisitions and future LIBOR rates, which will impact the amount of unhedged core income in our portfolio. We do expect the FFELP net interest margin to range between 81 and 85 basis points for the second half of 2015. 
Let's now turn to Slide 6 and our private education loans segment. Core earnings in this segment decreased by $64 million from the year-ago quarter to $22 million. Our second quarter student loan spread came in at 3.66%, and the associated NIM was 3.55%. Compared to the prior year, the net interest margin was primarily impacted by the interest rate reserve adjustments associated with the increase to our provision for the quarter and higher cost of funds. 
The increase in our provision for loan losses, which came in at $191 million for the quarter, came as a result of the segment of borrowers that Jack mentioned previously. These borrowers extended deferment in 2014 and are experiencing unfavorable credit trends compared to those who exited in deferment in previous years. 
For the second half of 2015, we do expect the private student loan net interest margin to range between 3.83% and 3.85%, and we expect the provision for private education loans losses to between $575 million and $600 million for 2015. 
As a result of the recent performance in our long-term recovery rate on defaulted loans, the company changed its recovery rate assumption on charge-off loans 21%. In recent years, we have been charging off periodic shortfalls and expected recoveries against our allowance for private education loans losses and the related receivable for partially charged-off loan. 
The $330 million adjustment eliminates the allowance for estimated recovery shortfalls and reflects the company's confidence in its long-term recovery related assumptions. Our second quarter charge-offs came in at 2.3% -- 2.7%, excuse me, or $13 million higher than the second quarter of last year. Total delinquency was at 6.8%, and that's compared to 7.1% from a year ago, and the forbearance rate was 3.7% compared to 4.2% from a year ago.
Slide 7 shows our asset quality trends over the last 5 years. Our portfolio is well seasoned with 93% of our loans in repayment status having made more than 12 payments. And our highest-risk portfolio, what we call nontraditional loans, was down to only 8% of our portfolio. We expect annualized charge-off rates for the second half of 2015 to be between 2.2% and 2.4%.
Let's turn to Slide 8 to review our business services segment. In this segment, core earnings were $90 million in the quarter compared with $130 million in the second quarter of 2014. 
We saw an increase in our asset recovery revenue of $10 million versus first quarter. This increase was primarily related to the full integration of Gila, which expands our footprint in the asset recovery and business process outsourcing space. The decline from the year ago was driven by the new reduced fee structure for guaranty agencies, which became effective on July 1, 2014. 
We expect asset recovery revenues to be between $360 million and $370 million for the year. The company services loans for more than 12 million borrowers with 6.1 million borrowers under the Department of Education servicing contract. Third-party loan servicing revenue increased to $47 million in the quarter with $35 million coming from the Department of Education servicing contract.
Let's turn to Slide 9 for highlights of our loan acquisition and financing activity. We acquired $1 billion of student loans in the second quarter. And while we removed future private loan acquisition from our guidance, our best opportunity for loan purchases remained default loans that we could convert onto our servicing platform and take advantage -- in order to take advantage of our significant cost advantage in servicing and our ability to deliver superior performance and customer success. 
In the quarter, we issued $1.8 billion of asset-backed securitizations. And as Jack mentioned, we are proactively working with rating agencies and investors to develop alternatives to minimize any impact to our ABS investors. 
In the quarter, we repurchased $522 million of unsecured notes. In 2015, we have reduced our unsecured debt outstanding by roughly $1.2 billion through repurchases and maturities. 
In the quarter, we've repurchased 15.2 million shares or $300 million. We do have remaining authority of $400 million under our current share repurchase plan. All of this activity was undertaken while maintaining strong capital position. And as of the -- June 30, 2015, our tangible net asset to unsecured debt ratio was at 1.25x. 
And finally, turning GAAP results on Slide 10. We recorded second quarter GAAP net income of $182 million or $0.47 per share, and that's compared to net income of $370 million -- $307 million or $0.71 per share in the second quarter of 2014. And just as a reminder, the primary differences between core earnings and GAAP results are the marks related to our derivative position, expenses related to restructuring and reorganization and the income associated with SLM BankCo. 
With that, I'll now open the call for questions.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of David Hochstim with Buckingham Research.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder could you just talk about your thoughts regarding potential sale of some private loans? If prices are too high to buy, would that suggest that it would make sense to sell some loans? And I had another question.
componenttext: I wonder could you just talk about your thoughts regarding potential sale of some private loans? If prices are too high to buy, would that suggest that it would make sense to sell some loans? And I had another question.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we do look at this both -- as both a purchaser and a seller of loans. I think if we look at the marketplace overall, we would say that the prices that people are willing to pay for portfolios is aggressive, but it is not what I would call particu
componenttext: Sure. So we do look at this both -- as both a purchaser and a seller of loans. I think if we look at the marketplace overall, we would say that the prices that people are willing to pay for portfolios is aggressive, but it is not what I would call particularly deep, and so we have looked at opportunities in that area. We have sold some FFELP transactions as a -- FFELP portfolios, principally ones that were not serviced by us to reflect that, and we'd continue to look at opportunities in both the federal and private space going forward.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the FFELP loans that you bought, those -- how many different sellers were there?
componenttext: And the FFELP loans that you bought, those -- how many different sellers were there?

componenttext: There was a variety of portfolios from both guaranty agencies and banks.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you just talked about the chart on Slide 7 that you update every quarter with the loss performance of lower risk, moderate risk, elevated risk loans and just talk about how the $2.5 billion kind of relates to these different segments?
componenttext: Okay. And then you just talked about the chart on Slide 7 that you update every quarter with the loss performance of lower risk, moderate risk, elevated risk loans and just talk about how the $2.5 billion kind of relates to these different segments?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on the deferred exits, they really do cross all of the different components that are shown here, and so they're not unique to any of these risk segment that we broke out on this chart. This is what I think makes us a little bit unusual. What we saw in
componenttext: So on the deferred exits, they really do cross all of the different components that are shown here, and so they're not unique to any of these risk segment that we broke out on this chart. This is what I think makes us a little bit unusual. What we saw in this portfolio compared to other years is obviously a worse default performance as loans came out of fee and school deferment. When we look a little bit deeper at these loans, we saw that this year's cohort had a higher percentage of borrowers who are having difficulty making payments before they had returned to school than prior portfolios. And in particular, this portfolio had multiple occurrences of in-school deferments, meaning that these customers exited school, entered repayment, returned to school, exited school, entered repayment and then went back again, and that's what's a little bit unusual is normally, our in-school deferments are students from the undergraduate side going back together to graduate degree. We're seeing a little bit more students who are working hard to get their undergraduate degree, and with the recession impact, we just -- they did not perform. When we look at our overall delinquencies, particularly our high-level delinquencies over 90 days, we are at June 30, a dollar low for the last year and a low that is -- a rate that is $150 million less than what we were at, at year-end. So I think this issue was somewhat behind us. We -- our reserve policy, which looks at a 2-year window, certainly covers future expectations at similar rates from exits going forward. But both that and the lower dollar amount we think we've got this issue under control at this point.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe one last quick question before I get to the queue again. In asset recovery, are there contracts that Gila or the rest of the business looking at that might be additive this year? Or is it kind of a longer-term story?
componenttext: Maybe one last quick question before I get to the queue again. In asset recovery, are there contracts that Gila or the rest of the business looking at that might be additive this year? Or is it kind of a longer-term story?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. So this is a business unit that we've seen good growth that, and our focus has really been growing our business outside of the student loan arena, particularly with state and local governments. That's one of the big drivers of adding Gila to our portf
componenttext: No. So this is a business unit that we've seen good growth that, and our focus has really been growing our business outside of the student loan arena, particularly with state and local governments. That's one of the big drivers of adding Gila to our portfolio. Those contracts, particularly at the state and local level, are more numerous. They're also smaller in size. So yes, we do see opportunities to win new business in that area this year and will contribute to this year's earnings results and going forward as well.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: Great. But if you were to just look, at this point in time, at the dollar amount of those loans, which fall into that higher risk category, would you size that for us?

componenttext: No, because I understand that these loans have contributed to the increase in the charge-offs weren't necessarily nontraditional loans. They were just higher risk spread across the bucket, and I think you talked about the $2-plus billion in 2014 that entered repayment and then those $1.8 billion in 2015, and $1.7 billion in 2015, and I was just trying to get a sense for the total inventory of these higher risk loans in total if you could size that.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sameer, I wouldn't necessarily call them high-risk loans. These are just basically loans that are in what we have left to go through or the remaining loans in the deferment as Jack mentioned. We've got $1.7 billion of loans that are scheduled to exit the
componenttext: Sameer, I wouldn't necessarily call them high-risk loans. These are just basically loans that are in what we have left to go through or the remaining loans in the deferment as Jack mentioned. We've got $1.7 billion of loans that are scheduled to exit the deferment. I think what Jack's talking about a good chunk of those loans will now be what I call traditional deferment exits, more of the traditional borrowers that got an undergraduate degree and then got a graduate degree afterwards.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean, because I'm just trying to get a sense for some percentage of your loan portfolio that I think when you initially kind of made the announcement, you said there was a higher risk, and I think as Jack characterized it, there was there would be
componenttext: Okay. I mean, because I'm just trying to get a sense for some percentage of your loan portfolio that I think when you initially kind of made the announcement, you said there was a higher risk, and I think as Jack characterized it, there was there would be students who kind of dropped out or went back to school again, and then they just had trouble making repayment. So I was trying to see if you can isolate that piece of the portfolio just so we get a sense for that slug of hit relative the rest of your portfolio, which is performing well. So is there any way for us to size it, and that's what I was really getting at.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I need think you need to look at the inventory of what's entering or exiting deferment is really what I would focus on, Sameer. It's the $2.5 billion that exited in '14, $1.7 billion that'll exit in 2015, and we expect that number and obviously, new borro
componenttext: I need think you need to look at the inventory of what's entering or exiting deferment is really what I would focus on, Sameer. It's the $2.5 billion that exited in '14, $1.7 billion that'll exit in 2015, and we expect that number and obviously, new borrowers will go to school, but the projections would be for 2016 exits to be under $1 billion. So it's moving in the right direction. I mean, our portfolio is becoming more seasoned as Somsak provided in his statistics, and the performance becomes more predictable as borrowers are seasoned. This segment of borrowers who moved in and out of school several times during the recession and finally have exited more permanently now saw loss rates that were 45% higher than what we saw in 2013's cohort. We don't -- we certainly are reserved for that at this stage in the game, but we don't expect that kind of performance going forward.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on another note, I was just curious if you could share your thoughts given widening that spread, if you could just talk about how you think about share repurchases and capital return to shareholders versus just retiring debt. I know you did
componenttext: Okay. And then on another note, I was just curious if you could share your thoughts given widening that spread, if you could just talk about how you think about share repurchases and capital return to shareholders versus just retiring debt. I know you did some this quarter again versus issuing new debt and kind of refining out maturing debt. How do you think about that at this point in time?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the -- our share return policy and the practices that we follow here are driven by the fact that we generate a significant amount of capital each year from the earnings of our loan portfolio, and so the dollar amount that we returned this year are real
componenttext: So the -- our share return policy and the practices that we follow here are driven by the fact that we generate a significant amount of capital each year from the earnings of our loan portfolio, and so the dollar amount that we returned this year are really a reflection of those kind of strong and consistent cash flows. The -- as principal comes down and is collected on the loans, the debt is repaid, and the spread in the earnings that we generate that goes back to shareholders that profit margin. And in fact, we don't expect that to change in terms of our philosophy at this point, and we'll continue to be active in both share repurchases and dividends, consistent with the earnings and the excess capital we generate each year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a last question on your servicing revenue. I think you jumped a bit to $106 million from I think $77 million or so last quarter if I'm looking at the numbers correctly, and I was just wondering what this was not the asset recovery reve
componenttext: Okay. And then just a last question on your servicing revenue. I think you jumped a bit to $106 million from I think $77 million or so last quarter if I'm looking at the numbers correctly, and I was just wondering what this was not the asset recovery revenue, I was just wondering why that might have increased so much sequentially.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Basically, during the quarter, Sameer, we made an adjustment relative to servicing revenue to expect -- to reflect the day 1 recovery expectation for late fees that assessed on against our portfolio. Basically, that's a true-up calculation previousl
componenttext: Sure. Basically, during the quarter, Sameer, we made an adjustment relative to servicing revenue to expect -- to reflect the day 1 recovery expectation for late fees that assessed on against our portfolio. Basically, that's a true-up calculation previously been recognized the income or late fee income more or less on a cash basis.

componenttext: Okay. So you just changed your estimate for your expected recoveries of those late fees? That's essentially what happened?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just have a question on the NIM guidance and your comfort level going forward on the FFELP NIM guidance. Maybe you can just talk about your cost of fund assumption, and what the options might be to do better or worse than those assumptions. And then may
componenttext: I just have a question on the NIM guidance and your comfort level going forward on the FFELP NIM guidance. Maybe you can just talk about your cost of fund assumption, and what the options might be to do better or worse than those assumptions. And then maybe if you could just speak to the specific impacts that you might be seeing right now from the Moody's downgrade, that would be helpful as well.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Sanjay, the -- our spread -- our NIM guidance for the rest of the year is between 81 and 85 basis points. I think given that the vast majority of our portfolio is now funded to term, I think that cost of fund element for the rest of the year is pret
componenttext: Sure. Sanjay, the -- our spread -- our NIM guidance for the rest of the year is between 81 and 85 basis points. I think given that the vast majority of our portfolio is now funded to term, I think that cost of fund element for the rest of the year is pretty much locked in. I think the variable going for the rest of the year is going to end up being when LIBOR rates end up, which will have an impact on ultimately what our unhedged floor income might be, and that will be a variable to the spread for the rest of the year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the Moody's, is there a specific impact that you're seeing?
componenttext: And the Moody's, is there a specific impact that you're seeing?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, not for the rest of the year. It would only impact any financing activity that we would go -- that would occur going forward. But at this point, any of that impact really wouldn't have much impact on the spread for the rest of 2015 because those tra
componenttext: Well, not for the rest of the year. It would only impact any financing activity that we would go -- that would occur going forward. But at this point, any of that impact really wouldn't have much impact on the spread for the rest of 2015 because those transactions would come in late in the year, and I think it'd be a little premature to see what the ultimate impact on the future funding costs will be until they take action, and we see what the results are.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just add to that, that the -- look, the loans are -- this issue is a timing of payments, not a timing of earnings capabilities or generation from the portfolio. Their interest accruing loans are generating the margin that we expected them to, and
componenttext: I would just add to that, that the -- look, the loans are -- this issue is a timing of payments, not a timing of earnings capabilities or generation from the portfolio. Their interest accruing loans are generating the margin that we expected them to, and it's actually by extending the term, you're actually increasing the amount of cash flows that you'll earn from the trust or collect from the trust over the life of the loan. We have tools available to us that kind of manage this process. We do need some. We can work with the investors on this front, and I think combined, given our -- the size of our issuance in this area and our leadership role in working with investors, rating agencies and the trustees, we're -- we hope that we will be able to come up with some resolutions that will cause no disruption in this marketplace.

componenttext: Not necessarily. It's just -- you're just -- all you're doing is when we buy loans back from the trust, you're recycling them into new asset-backed securities. So...

componenttext: Okay. Got it. And I guess I have a question on the segment that you saw a little bit of losses in, I mean, are there any other segments like this one and other categories that might where there might be higher risk in the future of higher default or anything? I mean, is there something is there any else that we should be concerned about going forward?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think the things that I would -- we pay a lot of attention to is the portion of the portfolio that has been making payments for extended periods of time. And once a borrower is in that mode, the incidence of delinquency and default declines progressi
componenttext: So I think the things that I would -- we pay a lot of attention to is the portion of the portfolio that has been making payments for extended periods of time. And once a borrower is in that mode, the incidence of delinquency and default declines progressively each and every year as the number of payments grow. The majority of our portfolio is now in that mode, and so we had these small segments move in and out of repayment a couple of times, primarily I would say due to the great recession, and as long as the economy kind of stays where it is, we wouldn't expect to see a disruption. And in fact, we believe our portfolio performance comes more predictable as customers mature and season through cycles here.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. One final question, and I want to follow to what Sameer was asking on the share buyback. You guys have talked about kind of the level of capital you operate and the fact that your operating at higher levels of capital than what you might goin
componenttext: Okay. Great. One final question, and I want to follow to what Sameer was asking on the share buyback. You guys have talked about kind of the level of capital you operate and the fact that your operating at higher levels of capital than what you might going forward. I mean, is there any appetite to maybe use some of that excess capital to buy back additional shares, given where the stock is?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think our capital position has been consistent over this time frame in terms of both how much we expect to generate, how much we expect to return to shareholders. Generally, we like to have -- we don't want to run right down to the edge of where we s
componenttext: So I think our capital position has been consistent over this time frame in terms of both how much we expect to generate, how much we expect to return to shareholders. Generally, we like to have -- we don't want to run right down to the edge of where we set our standards. It gives us flexibility in terms of opportunities to buy loan portfolios, look at opportunities in the asset recovery business, for example, and our preference right now is to kind of stay with that framework.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: Just a question on the targeted OpEx savings of $25 million. I guess on an annual basis here, you have revenue declining, and you have -- you just have $25 million of OpEx savings. Just wondering how much incremental ability to you have to take cost out as the portfolio amortizes? And is there any incremental step up in expenses as you have some more of these loans entering repayment?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, Eric, one of the things that you've got to remember also is that within our guidance for -- from $900 million for 2015, there are also onetime expenses that we're incurring in '15 related to -- of about $25 million related to the $8.5 billion o
componenttext: Yes. Well, Eric, one of the things that you've got to remember also is that within our guidance for -- from $900 million for 2015, there are also onetime expenses that we're incurring in '15 related to -- of about $25 million related to the $8.5 billion of loans that we are converting onto our portfolio that we expect to complete later this year. So in terms of moving from the $900 million in 2015 [ph] -- going to 2016, not only do you have the removal of that $25 million, you've got another $25 million that's going to come out of the expense base next year because of our restructuring initiative.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd just add, Eric, that the $25 million I referenced in my opening remarks was not a forecast for what our OpEx would be in 2016. It was what we would expect to save as a result of this organizational initiative only.
componenttext: Yes, I'd just add, Eric, that the $25 million I referenced in my opening remarks was not a forecast for what our OpEx would be in 2016. It was what we would expect to save as a result of this organizational initiative only.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: Got it. So combined, you have $50 million that you would expect to get out. On top of that, I'm curious, I guess, how much more could you hypothetically take out over time? How much operating leverage could you take down further?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So our -- these are -- we're not getting into a forecast for 2016 OpEx. We've listed 2 items, and I want to be clear that, that's not necessarily comprehensive, and we don't want to -- I don't want to go down a laundry list here at this stage in the year.
componenttext: So our -- these are -- we're not getting into a forecast for 2016 OpEx. We've listed 2 items, and I want to be clear that, that's not necessarily comprehensive, and we don't want to -- I don't want to go down a laundry list here at this stage in the year. But when we look at our operating expenses items here, they're driven -- a good portion of them are driven by the variable nature of our revenues. So as loans mature and they actually become less costly, they can become less costly to service if they're making payments on a regular scheduled time frame. Our big drivers of servicing expense the number of units we're adding as we increase the number of accounts we are servicing for the Department of Education. So if you look at our business on the loan servicing side as an example, our account load has actually increased over the last 3 years even though our loan portfolio is amortizing down, right? Because we are adding new business and revenues associated with that. In the asset recoveries side of the equation, we have a similar activity of our FFELP-related work loads are decreasing, but our other workloads, particularly outside of the education lending space, have been increasing. So to some extent, operating expenses as a function of the revenue drivers that we have going, and our preference is, of course, to see revenues increasing.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: Got it. And just on the buyback, I think you had initially said that it would be an annual buyback. Is there any potential to reup it this year and accelerate?

componenttext: So this -- we look at this on a regular basis. We have both internally and with the board, and we work with them on a combined basis to decide what the appropriate level. I don't have much more to add to that at this point.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then not to beat a dead horse, but just on the cohort of the 2014 loan, the exit deferment, what made them different from 2012 and 2013? Were there any characteristics that were particularly different that led to the higher default rate?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the 2 biggest things are the ones i mentioned, which is that we had a higher percentage of these borrowers who had demonstrated difficulty making payments when they were in repayment prior to returning to school and then in prior cohorts. So that
componenttext: I think the 2 biggest things are the ones i mentioned, which is that we had a higher percentage of these borrowers who had demonstrated difficulty making payments when they were in repayment prior to returning to school and then in prior cohorts. So that gives you an example of an indication that they were struggling to begin with, and the second piece is the statistic that said more of these customers had moved in and out of school multiple times, not just 2 but more than 2 times. Those were the primary differences.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Correct, and look, the people return to school for multiple reasons, right? We have the normal trend we would see in our private loan portfolio is undergrads, which is the primary customer of which private loans are made, returning to school to get a grad
componenttext: Correct, and look, the people return to school for multiple reasons, right? We have the normal trend we would see in our private loan portfolio is undergrads, which is the primary customer of which private loans are made, returning to school to get a graduate degree. Those are generally positive trends, right? You are getting an advanced degree, and all of the history and data suggest that these customers coming out of graduate school have higher incomes, more stable jobs. In fact, in our private loan book, the best performing segment across the board is loans made to graduate school students. What we saw here is a second group of return to school, which is borrowers who, this isn't true for the entire 2.5 billion of course, but borrowers who did not attain their undergraduate degree went back to more classes, reentered repayment and were back again, and so these customers take long -- took longer to either attain an undergraduate degree or maybe did not obtain it at all, and the incidence of delinquency and default of borrowers who take more time to get an undergraduate degree is only higher, and I think that's what we're seeing in this particular cohort. Generally speaking, every year, it takes someone to graduate increases their debt load by about 10%. So if you're going from 4 years to 6 years, you have -- not only is it taking longer to get to the point of where you're going to generate higher income, but you've got more -- you have a higher debt burden as well. I would describe this pool and the losses coming more from customers who didn't complete their degree.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then just finally, I know you don't provide 2016 guidance, but as you think out to 2016, how much risk is there from additional NIM pressure? If your unsecured funding costs don't to recover, is there kind of a need to do finan
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then just finally, I know you don't provide 2016 guidance, but as you think out to 2016, how much risk is there from additional NIM pressure? If your unsecured funding costs don't to recover, is there kind of a need to do finance some more maturities as we look out next year?

componenttext: Well, certainly, that'll impact the spread going forward, but I think one of the things that we're going to need to look into is alternative sources of financing outside of unsecured debt.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly, there will be pressure on that just given the fact that older loans that earned floor income will amortized away quicker than our newer FFELP loan that will amortized lower. So that value actually declined over time.
componenttext: Certainly, there will be pressure on that just given the fact that older loans that earned floor income will amortized away quicker than our newer FFELP loan that will amortized lower. So that value actually declined over time.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct, and the other thing I will add is that we have hedged in a locked-in value of about $900 million of future floor income, and that's locked in through about 2019.
componenttext: That's correct, and the other thing I will add is that we have hedged in a locked-in value of about $900 million of future floor income, and that's locked in through about 2019.

componenttext: Yes, the vast majority of the bonds that bought so far this year has really been targeted at the January 2016 maturity that's coming due. So we had excess liquidity that were sitting on our balance sheet, and so we decided to better manage our NIM by basically buying those maturities out because they were going to be due within the next 12 months anyways.

componenttext: Private and FFELP absolutely, but private in particular I was referring to. And -- but they'll come too late in the year to have any meaningful impact on 2015 earnings. Clearly, we think we're the best buyer for student loan assets in terms of both federal and private given our low cost of our -- particularly to move them onto our servicing platforms given our low cost of servicing and the higher performance that we can generate out of a portfolio of student loans. So sometimes, the loan portfolios that are offered don't have -- aren't servicing released. We're going to be less competitive on those deals. Sometimes they're residuals in which case, you're basically just buying cash flows with no ability to kind of influence the performance. And in some instances on some smaller portfolios when -- particularly on the deal that was -- the private loan deal that was older your this year was a residual tranche. It brings in -- because there's no financing requirements and because the servicing is structured as part of the agreement, it brings in buyers who were not traditional buyers, and they're willing to pay higher prices than we would pay. The transactions we expect later this year are likely to be whole loans that we would be able to control servicing, and therefore, we think we have better chances of success.

componenttext: Right. Certainly good luck, but I would certainly observe if a whole year does go by, that couple of hundred million would certainly be excess at that point.

componenttext: I think it will create opportunities for us to buy student loans more than perhaps on some of these tranches, but the things we're looking for here are making sure that the bonds don't suffer downgrades due to timing issues, and we're working with investors and the rating agencies to be sure that happens. I think we're better served by having an orderly liquid ABS marketplace.

componenttext: Just want to follow-up on the comments about moving to additional secured funding from unsecured. You have a decent amount of unsecured maturities coming up. And then the second follow-up question is you had discussions with the rating agencies about what impact that might have to your secondary ratings?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: Yes, I think it just depends on what the availability is at this point. One of the things that we'll open up is within our private credit deals that once we have certain trusts that were issued post credit crisis, which we're paying down on term loan basis, and yes, at some point, we will be able to exercise our 10% call options so that we can buy out the assets out of those deals and take refinance those deals, take a chunk of those proceeds and use those to pay down unsecured debt over time.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttextpreview: Well, we'll be absolutely using our available cash to buy back debt early on as much as possible, and to the extent we have ability to raise cash through other sources then we have done things like loan sales previously to be able to raise additional cash
componenttext: Well, we'll be absolutely using our available cash to buy back debt early on as much as possible, and to the extent we have ability to raise cash through other sources then we have done things like loan sales previously to be able to raise additional cash. So to the extent it's economical and makes sense, those are the vehicles we would look to.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: So that's sounding like you're not expecting to tap the unsecured markets anytime soon.

componenttext: We will need to tap the unsecured markets from time to time, but one of the things that you'll -- I think Jack mentioned earlier that the unsecured debt is going to be -- will be a mix, an important funding mix going forward, but one of the things we want to do is rely less and less on that on that mix over time. And again as our balance sheet amortizes down, we expect the unsecured debt to amortize down along with that.

Good morning. My name is Stephanie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Navient Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.
I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Joe Fisher, Vice President of Investor Relations. You may begin.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, and welcome to Navient 2015 Second Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.Before we begin,
componenttext:
Thank you, Stephanie. Good morning, and welcome to Navient 2015 Second Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.
Before we begin, keep in mind our discussion will contain predictions, expectations and forward-looking statements. Actual results in the future may be materially different from those discussed here. This could be due to a variety of factors. Listeners should refer to the discussion of those factors in the company's Form 10-K and other filings with the SEC.
During this conference call, we will refer to non-GAAP measures we call our core earnings. A description of core earnings, full reconciliation to GAAP measures and our GAAP results can be found in the second quarter 2015 supplemental earnings disclosure. This is posted, along with the earnings press release on the Investors page at navient.com.
Thank you, and now I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to our second quarter's earnings call. Thanks for listening, and I appreciate your interest and support. So even though the financial performance on many of our segments of our business was strong, a few
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to our second quarter's earnings call. Thanks for listening, and I appreciate your interest and support. 
So even though the financial performance on many of our segments of our business was strong, a few areas were not. This quarter's results and our revised guidance for 2015 are clearly a disappointment in direction and impact. 
Our results and the change in guidance were really driven by 3 main items. First, our original forecast assumed we would be able to purchase private education loans this year. Aggressive bidding from others and delayed timing by some sellers reduced the prospects here. While we still expect to have the opportunity to bid on private loan portfolios later this year, if successful, they will likely occur too late to contribute to this year's earnings. 
Also included in our forecast was the ability to refinance some of our higher cost asset-backed securities issued during the recession. The opportunities to do so have not materialized thus far, but we will continue to pursue them. 
Finally, we've seen higher default rates than we projected in a narrow segment of our private loan portfolio. This segment of borrowers returned to school during the Great Recession and exited from their in-school deferment in 2014. The size of exits also increased to $2.5 billion in 2014, up from $1.8 billion in 2013. We expect deferment exits to decline to $1.7 billion in 2015.
These 2014 exits, which did not include borrowers who were entering repayment for the first time, are experiencing significantly higher levels of delinquency and default than prior cohorts. As a result, we increased our loss forecast for 2015 by approximately $100 million. We believe we have this issue well-reserved for. 
While the impact on our financial results for 2015 from these items is not insignificant, they're not reflective of the larger story here. First, our expected cash flows from our student loan portfolio remain a sizable $33.2 billion, and year-to-date, our student loan portfolio generated $1.6 billion in loan-related cash flow, and we added $500 million in expected future cash flows from a combination of student loan acquisitions, net of financings, and increased forecast of floor income. 
This quarter also saw positive trends in several other areas. For example, we purchased $1 billion in student loans. We achieved a second-place finish in the Department of Education loans servicing scorecard, driven by our industry-leading default prevention success. 
We saw another year-over-year improvement in new college graduate credit trends and generated strong growth in fee income from our asset recovery businesses, and we returned over $360 million to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. 
Earlier this quarter, we announced an organizational redesign and a corresponding restructuring. This effort is designed to align our business units to further improve organizational effectiveness and efficiency. 
We created 2 main business teams: an asset management and servicing group, and asset recovery and business services group. We also streamlined layers to improve speed of execution, efficiency and enhanced the lines of responsibility in these business areas. 
While the primary objectives of these change -- changes, which contributed to a restructuring charge of $29 million this quarter, which will improve the effectiveness and align our team into the related business groups, these changes will also improve our operating efficiency going forward. For example, we expect to see a total run rate benefit in operating expense of approximately $25 million in 2016.
Growing our fee-related business lines and improving our operating margins continues to be a major area of focus for us. For example, we have been successfully growing our asset recovery revenue with a focus in areas beyond student loans. 
Earlier this year, we acquired Gila, a $70 million in revenue asset recovery and business service company, to add to this effort. The integration process has proceeded very smoothly, and Gila's management team has quickly demonstrated their capabilities with the successful implementation of a large and very complicated services contract and overall performance better than expectations. 
We continue to look for opportunities to expand our asset recovery and business services skills into new areas. In our loan servicing operations, we also continue to deliver superior results. We excel at helping our federal student loan customers successfully manage their student loans with overall default rates that are 48% lower than all other servicers combined. 
Our efforts to help our customers understand the very complex array of repayment options available to them and select the option that helps them successfully manage their loans. While our efforts continue to produce lower delinquency and default rates, the economy is also helping borrowers as they leave school. Combined, these factors are driving significantly better loan performance.
Each spring, we track the performance of recent graduates as they enter repayment for the first time. Looking at the performance of recent graduates 6 months into repayment, we see that the incidence of severe delinquency has fallen each and every year from a recession high of 22% for the class of 2010 to a low of 8% for the class of 2014, the most recent graduating class to enter repayment. Our better-than-average delinquency default performance is the result of our data-driven outreach efforts that help us reach borrowers and offer affordable solutions. This is why we advocate so strongly for customer contact. It works. 
With the reauthorization of the Federal Student Loan Programs gearing up, we've been strong advocates for program simplicity and for tools that help students and families make better decisions about paying for college before they borrow. Today, in the federal loan programs, there are 15 repayment options, 8 loan-forgiveness programs and some 35 forbearance and deferment options for federal borrowers to navigate. 
Not surprisingly, our customers seek our help to understand the options they're eligible for and how to choose the plan that works best for them. These federal efforts, however, are focused on helping borrowers manage payments only after the loan is made. Simplifying this complexity and helping borrowers make more informed decisions before they borrow should be top priorities. 
Moody's and Fitch's ABS teams recently wrote about the impact of extended repayment options on federal student loan asset-backed securities. In their view, this may impact whether or not a bond is paid in full by the bond [ph] legal final maturity date. We actively monitor the performance of our student loan securitization trust, including adherence to the final -- the legal final maturity date. 
Since 2013, we have amended 17 trusts and exercised loan purchase rights of $428 million to address potential issues here. In order to amend the legal final maturity date, we encourage note holders to reach out to us so we can work with the agencies to modify the terms and successfully resolve this potential issue. 
As the largest issuer of student loan backed securities, we take our leadership role seriously, and we're working with the rating agencies, trustees and investors to develop alternatives to minimize any impact to our ABS investors.
These efforts are consistent with our commitment to maintain a strong financial profile for our investors. Our capital and liquidity remain both strong and conservative given our risk profile, and our reserves for loan losses cover more than 2x annualized charge-offs. Our capital return approach is fully consistent with these commitments. 
At Navient, we have made a significant and ongoing investments in customer success and compliance. We believe that our success is aligned with our customers' success. 
Since the recession, we've been engaged with several regulatory agencies and have responded to numerous data requests. While these inquiries are time and data intensive and therefore are costly, our focus is to remain responsive and collaborative.
We also make the effort to provide additional insight into the trends we see in the efforts we make to drive customer success. We're extremely proud of our track record in producing the highest success rates in the industry. We believe our experience and ability to use our deep data to continue to drive customer success are the foundation of our continued ability to add value. 
Finally, while I am deeply disappointed with the impact a few areas had on our financial goals, I am confident in our ability to execute on our business plan, and I am committed and our team is committed to creating value for our customers, employees, bond investors and shareholders. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Somsak, for a more detailed view of the financial results.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation beginning on Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings. In the second quarter, we reported $0.40 per share, and that's comp
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation beginning on Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings. 
In the second quarter, we reported $0.40 per share, and that's compared to $0.56 per share from a year-ago quarter.
Our second quarter operating expenses totaled $225 million compared to operating expenses of $195 million from a year-ago quarter. The increase in operating expenses related to incremental costs resulting from the recent acquisition of Gila, incremental third-party servicing costs related to the $8.5 billion of loans acquired in fourth quarter of 2014, higher servicing and asset recovery bonds, and increased regulatory compliance costs. We expect core EPS to be approximately $1.85 in 2015 and operating expenses of less than $900 million for 2015. 
Now let's turn to Slide 5 to discuss our FFELP segment results. FFELP core earnings were $93 million for the second quarter compared to $72 million in the second quarter of 2014. In the quarter, the FFELP student loan spread was 91 basis points, and the associated NIM was 81 basis points. The FFELP NIM may be impacted by future loan acquisitions and future LIBOR rates, which will impact the amount of unhedged core income in our portfolio. We do expect the FFELP net interest margin to range between 81 and 85 basis points for the second half of 2015. 
Let's now turn to Slide 6 and our private education loans segment. Core earnings in this segment decreased by $64 million from the year-ago quarter to $22 million. Our second quarter student loan spread came in at 3.66%, and the associated NIM was 3.55%. Compared to the prior year, the net interest margin was primarily impacted by the interest rate reserve adjustments associated with the increase to our provision for the quarter and higher cost of funds. 
The increase in our provision for loan losses, which came in at $191 million for the quarter, came as a result of the segment of borrowers that Jack mentioned previously. These borrowers exited deferment in 2014 and are experiencing unfavorable credit trends compared to those who exited in deferment previous years. 
For the second half of 2015, we do expect the private student loan net interest margin to range between 3.83% and 3.85%, and we expect the provision for private education loans losses to between $575 million and $600 million for 2015. 
As a result of the recent performance in our long-term recovery rate on defaulted loans, the company changed its recovery rate assumption on charge-off loans 21%. In recent years, we have been charging off periodic shortfalls and expected recoveries against our allowance for private education loans losses and the related receivable for partially charged-off loan. 
The $330 million adjustment eliminates the allowance for estimated recovery shortfalls and reflects the company's confidence in its long-term recovery rate assumptions. Our second quarter charge-offs came in at 2.3% -- 2.7%, excuse me, or $13 million higher than the second quarter of last year. Total delinquency was at 6.8%, and that's compared to 7.1% from a year ago, and the forbearance rate was 3.7% compared to 4.2% from a year ago.
Slide 7 shows our asset quality trends over the last 5 years. Our portfolio is well seasoned with 93% of our loans in repayment status having made more than 12 payments. And our highest-risk portfolio, what we call nontraditional loans, was down to only 8% of our portfolio. We expect annualized charge-off rates for the second half of 2015 to be between 2.2% and 2.4%.
Let's turn to Slide 8 to review our business services segment. In this segment, core earnings were $90 million in the quarter compared with $130 million in the second quarter of 2014. We saw an increase in our asset recovery revenue of $10 million versus first quarter. This increase was primarily related to the full integration of Gila, which expands our footprint in the asset recovery and business process outsourcing space. The decline from the year ago was driven by the new reduced fee structure for guarantee agencies, which became effective on July 1, 2014. 
We expect asset recovery revenues to be between $360 million and $370 million for the year. The company services loans for more than 12 million borrowers with 6.1 million borrowers under the Department of Education servicing contract. Third-party loan servicing revenue increased to $47 million in the quarter with $35 million coming from the Department of Education servicing contract.
Let's turn to Slide 9 for highlights of our loan acquisition and financing activity. We acquired $1 billion of student loans in the second quarter. And while we removed future private loan acquisitions from our guidance, our best opportunity for loan purchases remain default loans that we could convert onto our servicing platform and take advantage -- in order to take advantage of our significant cost advantage in servicing and our ability to deliver superior performance and customer success. 
In the quarter, we issued $1.8 billion of asset-backed securitizations. And as Jack mentioned, we are proactively working with rating agencies and investors to develop alternatives to minimize any impact to our ABS investors. 
In the quarter, we repurchased $522 million of unsecured notes. In 2015, we have reduced our unsecured debt outstanding by roughly $1.2 billion through repurchases and maturities. 
In the quarter, we've repurchased 15.2 million shares with $300 million. We do have remaining authority of $400 million under our current share repurchase plan. All of this activity was undertaken while maintaining strong capital position. And as of the -- June 30, 2015, our tangible net asset to unsecured debt ratio was at 1.25x. 
And finally, turning GAAP results on Slide 10. We recorded second quarter GAAP net income of $182 million or $0.47 per share, and that's compared to net income of 370 -- $307 million or $0.71 per share in the second quarter of 2014. And just as a reminder, the primary differences between core earnings and GAAP results are the marks related to our derivative positions, expenses related to restructuring and reorganization and the income associated with SLM BankCo. 
With that, I'll now open the call for questions.

componenttextpreview: Sure. So we do look at this both -- as both a purchaser and a seller of loans. I think if we look at the marketplace overall, we would say that the prices that people are willing to pay for portfolios is aggressive, but it is not what I would call particu
componenttext: Sure. So we do look at this both -- as both a purchaser and a seller of loans. I think if we look at the marketplace overall, we would say that the prices that people are willing to pay for portfolios is aggressive, but it is not what I would call particularly deep. And so we have looked at opportunities in that area. We have sold some FFELP transactions as a -- FFELP portfolios, principally ones that were not serviced by us to reflect that, and we'd continue to look at opportunities in both the federal and private space going forward.

componenttext: And the FFELP loans that you bought, those -- how many different sellers were there?

componenttextpreview: There was a variety of portfolios from both guarantee agencies and banks.
componenttext: There was a variety of portfolios from both guarantee agencies and banks.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then could you -- [indiscernible] Somsak just talked about the chart on Slide 7 that you update every quarter with the loss performance of low risk, moderate risk and elevated risk loans. And just talk about how the slug of the $2.5 billion kind
componenttext: Okay. And then could you -- [indiscernible] Somsak just talked about the chart on Slide 7 that you update every quarter with the loss performance of low risk, moderate risk and elevated risk loans. And just talk about how the slug of the $2.5 billion kind of relates to these different segments?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on the deferred exits, they really do cross all of the different components that are shown here, and so they're not unique to any of these risk segments that we broke out on this chart. This is what I think makes us a little bit unusual. What we saw in
componenttext: So on the deferred exits, they really do cross all of the different components that are shown here, and so they're not unique to any of these risk segments that we broke out on this chart. This is what I think makes us a little bit unusual. What we saw in this portfolio compared to other years is obviously a worse default performance as the loans came out of fee and school deferment. When we looked a little bit deeper at these loans, we saw that this year's cohort had a higher percentage of borrowers who are having difficulty making payments before they had returned to school than prior portfolios. And in particular, this portfolio had multiple occurrences of in-school deferments, meaning that these customers exited school, entered repayment, returned to school, exited school, entered repayment and then went back again. And that's what's a little bit unusual is normally our in-school deferments are students from the undergraduate side going back together to graduate degree and here I think we're seeing a little bit more students who are working hard to get their undergraduate degree, and with the recession impact, we just -- they did not perform. When we look at our overall delinquencies, particularly our high-level delinquencies over 90 days, we are at June 30, $1 low for the last year and a low that is -- a rate that is $150 million less than what we were at, at year-end. So I think this issue is somewhat behind us. We -- our reserve policy, which looks at a 2-year window, certainly covers future expectations at similar rates from exits going forward. But both that and the lower dollar amount, we think we've got this issue under control at this point.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe one last quick question before I get into queue again. In asset recovery, are there contracts that Gila or the rest of the business is looking at that might be additive this year? Or is it more kind of a longer-term story?
componenttext: Maybe one last quick question before I get into queue again. In asset recovery, are there contracts that Gila or the rest of the business is looking at that might be additive this year? Or is it more kind of a longer-term story?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. So this is a business that we've seen good growth at, and our focus has really been growing our business outside of the student loan arena, particularly with state and local governments. That's one of the big drivers of adding Gila to our portfolio. T
componenttext: No. So this is a business that we've seen good growth at, and our focus has really been growing our business outside of the student loan arena, particularly with state and local governments. That's one of the big drivers of adding Gila to our portfolio. Those contracts, particularly at the state and local level, are more numerous. They're also smaller in size. So yes, we do see opportunities to win new business in that area this year and will contribute to this year's earnings results and going forward as well.

componenttext: Great. Jack, could you or Somsak just talk about the inventory of those higher-risk receivables? But if you were to just look at this point in time at the dollar amount of those loans, which fall into that higher risk category, could you size that for us?
