componenttext: There was a variety of portfolios from both guarantee agencies and banks.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then could you -- you or Somsak just talked about the chart on Slide 7 that you update every quarter with the loss performance of low-risk, moderate-risk and elevated-risk loans. And just talk about how the slug of the $2.5 billion kind of relat
componenttext: Okay. And then could you -- you or Somsak just talked about the chart on Slide 7 that you update every quarter with the loss performance of low-risk, moderate-risk and elevated-risk loans. And just talk about how the slug of the $2.5 billion kind of relates to these different segments.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on the deferred exits, they really do cross all of the different components that are shown here, and so they're not unique to any of these risk segments that we broke out on this chart. This is what I think makes us a little bit unusual. What we saw in
componenttext: So on the deferred exits, they really do cross all of the different components that are shown here, and so they're not unique to any of these risk segments that we broke out on this chart. This is what I think makes us a little bit unusual. What we saw in this portfolio compared to other years is obviously a worse default performance as the loans came out of the in-school deferment. When we looked a little bit deeper at these loans, we saw that this year's cohort had a higher percentage of borrowers who are having difficulty making payments before they had returned to school than prior portfolios. And in particular, this portfolio had multiple occurrences of in-school deferments, meaning that these customers exited school, entered repayment, returned to school, exited school, entered repayment and then went back again. And that's what's a little bit unusual is normally our in-school deferments are students from the undergraduate side going back to get a graduate degree, and here I think we're seeing a little bit more students who are working hard to get their undergraduate degree, and with the recession impact, we just -- they did not perform. When we look at our overall delinquencies, particularly our high-level delinquencies over 90 days, we are, at June 30, a dollar low for the last year and a low that is -- a rate that is $150 million less than what we were at, at year-end. So I think this issue is somewhat behind us. We -- our reserve policy, which looks at a 2-year window, certainly covers future expectations at similar rates from exits going forward. But both that and the lower dollar amount, we think we've got this issue under control at this point.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe one last quick question before I get in the queue again. In asset recovery, are there contracts that Gila or the rest of the business is looking at that might be additive this year? Or is it more kind of a longer-term story?
componenttext: Maybe one last quick question before I get in the queue again. In asset recovery, are there contracts that Gila or the rest of the business is looking at that might be additive this year? Or is it more kind of a longer-term story?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. So this is a business that we've seen good growth at, and our focus has really been growing our business outside of the student loan arena, particularly with state and local governments. That's one of the big drivers of adding Gila to our portfolio. T
componenttext: No. So this is a business that we've seen good growth at, and our focus has really been growing our business outside of the student loan arena, particularly with state and local governments. That's one of the big drivers of adding Gila to our portfolio. Those contracts, particularly at the state and local level, are more numerous. They're also smaller in size. So yes, we do see opportunities to win new business in that area this year and will contribute to this year's earnings results and going forward as well.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sameer Gokhale with Janney Montgomery Scott.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sameer Gokhale with Janney Montgomery Scott.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Jack, could you or Somsak just talk about the inventory of those higher-risk receivables? Because you've talked, I think, about the dollar amount of loans that are exiting repayment out of this higher-risk category. But if you were to just look at
componenttext: Great. Jack, could you or Somsak just talk about the inventory of those higher-risk receivables? Because you've talked, I think, about the dollar amount of loans that are exiting repayment out of this higher-risk category. But if you were to just look at this point in time at the dollar amount of those loans, which fall into that higher risk category, could you size that for us?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: You're talking about the nontraditional loans [indiscernible]?
componenttext: You're talking about the nontraditional loans [indiscernible]?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, because as I understand it, these loans that have contributed to the increase in the charge-offs weren't necessarily nontraditional loans. They were just higher risk spread across the buckets. And I think you talked about the $2-plus billion in 2014 t
componenttext: No, because as I understand it, these loans that have contributed to the increase in the charge-offs weren't necessarily nontraditional loans. They were just higher risk spread across the buckets. And I think you talked about the $2-plus billion in 2014 that entered repayment and then those $1.8 billion in 2015 (sic) [ 2013 ], and $1.7 billion in 2015, and I was just trying to get a sense for the total inventory of these higher-risk loans in total, if you could size that.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sameer, I wouldn't necessarily call them high-risk loans. These are just basically loans that are in -- what we have left to go through or the remaining loans in deferment. As Jack mentioned, we've got $1.7 billion of loans that are scheduled to exit defe
componenttext: Sameer, I wouldn't necessarily call them high-risk loans. These are just basically loans that are in -- what we have left to go through or the remaining loans in deferment. As Jack mentioned, we've got $1.7 billion of loans that are scheduled to exit deferment. I think what Jack's talking about, a good chunk of those loans will now be what I'll call traditional deferment exits, more of the traditional borrower that got an undergraduate degree and then got a graduate degree afterwards.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean, because I'm just trying to get a sense for -- there was some percentage of your loan portfolio that I think when you initially kind of made the announcement, you said there was some higher risk, and I think, as Jack characterized it, there w
componenttext: Okay. I mean, because I'm just trying to get a sense for -- there was some percentage of your loan portfolio that I think when you initially kind of made the announcement, you said there was some higher risk, and I think, as Jack characterized it, there was -- there would be students who kind of dropped out or went back to school again, and then they just had trouble making repayment. So I was just trying to see if you can isolate that piece of the portfolio just so we get a sense for that slug of it relative the rest of your portfolio, which is performing well. So is there any way for us to size it? And that's what I was really getting at.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think you need to look at the inventory of what's entering or exiting deferment is really I would focus on, Sameer. It's the $2.5 billion that exited in '14, $1.7 billion that will exit in 2015, and we expect that number -- and obviously, new borrowers
componenttext: I think you need to look at the inventory of what's entering or exiting deferment is really I would focus on, Sameer. It's the $2.5 billion that exited in '14, $1.7 billion that will exit in 2015, and we expect that number -- and obviously, new borrowers can go to school, but the projections would be for 2016 exits to be under $1 billion. So it's moving in the right direction. Our portfolio is becoming more seasoned, as Somsak provided in his statistics, and the performance becomes more predictable as borrowers are seasoned. This segment of borrowers, who moved in and out of school several times during the recession and finally have exited more permanently now, saw loss rates that were 45% higher than what we saw in 2013's cohort. We don't -- we certainly are reserved for that at this stage in the game, but we don't expect that kind of performance going forward.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on another note, I was just curious if you could share your thoughts, given widening debt spreads, if you could just talk about how you think about share repurchases and capital return to shareholders versus just retiring debt. I know you d
componenttext: Okay. And then on another note, I was just curious if you could share your thoughts, given widening debt spreads, if you could just talk about how you think about share repurchases and capital return to shareholders versus just retiring debt. I know you did some this quarter again versus issuing new debt and kind of refi-ing out maturing debt. How do you think about that at this point in time?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the -- our share return policy and the practices that we follow here are driven by the fact that we generate a significant amount of capital each year from the earnings of our loan portfolio. And so the dollar amounts that we returned this year are rea
componenttext: So the -- our share return policy and the practices that we follow here are driven by the fact that we generate a significant amount of capital each year from the earnings of our loan portfolio. And so the dollar amounts that we returned this year are really a reflection of those kind of strong and consistent cash flows. The -- as principal comes down and is collected on the loans, the debt is repaid, and it's the spread in the earnings that we generate that goes back to shareholders, that profit margin in effect. We don't expect that to change in terms of our philosophy at this point, and we'll continue to be active in both share repurchases and dividends, consistent with the earnings and the excess capital we generate each year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a last question on your servicing revenue. It seemed to have jumped a bit to $106 million from, I think, $77 million or so last quarter, if I'm looking at the numbers correctly. And I was just wondering what -- this was not the asset r
componenttext: Okay. And then just a last question on your servicing revenue. It seemed to have jumped a bit to $106 million from, I think, $77 million or so last quarter, if I'm looking at the numbers correctly. And I was just wondering what -- this was not the asset recovery revenue. I was just wondering why that might have increased so much sequentially.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Basically, during the quarter, Sameer, we made an adjustment relative to servicing revenue to expect -- to reflect the day-1 recovery expectation for late fees that are assessed on -- against our portfolio. Basically, that's a true-up calculation, w
componenttext: Sure. Basically, during the quarter, Sameer, we made an adjustment relative to servicing revenue to expect -- to reflect the day-1 recovery expectation for late fees that are assessed on -- against our portfolio. Basically, that's a true-up calculation, which has previously would -- been recognized, income or late fee income on -- more or less on a cash basis.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you just changed your estimate for your expected recoveries of those late fees. That's essentially what happened?
componenttext: Okay. So you just changed your estimate for your expected recoveries of those late fees. That's essentially what happened?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line from Sanjay Sakhrani with KBW.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line from Sanjay Sakhrani with KBW.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just have a question on the NIM guidance and your comfort level going forward on the FFELP NIM guidance. Maybe you could just talk about your cost-of-fund assumptions, and what the options might be to do better or worse than those assumptions. And then ma
componenttext: Just have a question on the NIM guidance and your comfort level going forward on the FFELP NIM guidance. Maybe you could just talk about your cost-of-fund assumptions, and what the options might be to do better or worse than those assumptions. And then maybe if you could just speak to the specific impacts that you might be seeing right now from the Moody's downgrade, that would be helpful as well.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Sanjay, the -- our spread -- our NIM guidance for the rest of the year is between 81 and 85 basis points. I think given that a vast majority of our portfolio is now funded to term, I think that cost-of-funds element for the rest of the year is prett
componenttext: Sure. Sanjay, the -- our spread -- our NIM guidance for the rest of the year is between 81 and 85 basis points. I think given that a vast majority of our portfolio is now funded to term, I think that cost-of-funds element for the rest of the year is pretty much locked in. I think the variable going for the rest of the year is going to end up being where LIBOR rates end up, which will have an impact on ultimately what our unhedged floor income might be, and that will be a variable to the spread for the rest of the year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the Moody's, is there a specific impact that you're seeing?
componenttext: And the Moody's, is there a specific impact that you're seeing?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, not for the rest of the year. It would only impact any financing activity that we would go -- that would occur going forward. At this point, any of that impact really wouldn't have much impact on the spread for the rest of 2015, because those transa
componenttext: Well, not for the rest of the year. It would only impact any financing activity that we would go -- that would occur going forward. At this point, any of that impact really wouldn't have much impact on the spread for the rest of 2015, because those transactions would come in late in the year. And I think it'd be a little premature to see what the ultimate impact on the future funding costs will be until they take action, and we see what the results are.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just add to that, that the -- look, the loans are -- this issue is a timing of payments, not a timing of earnings capabilities or generation from the portfolio. They are interest-accruing loans, they're generating the margins that we expected them
componenttext: I would just add to that, that the -- look, the loans are -- this issue is a timing of payments, not a timing of earnings capabilities or generation from the portfolio. They are interest-accruing loans, they're generating the margins that we expected them to. And it's actually -- by extending the term, you're actually increasing the amount of cash flows that you'll earn from the trust or collect from the trust over the life of the loan. We have tools available to us to kind of manage this process. We do need some. We can work with the investors on this front. And I think combined, given our -- the size of our issuance in this area and our leadership role and working with investors, rating agencies and the trustees, we're -- we hope that this will -- we'll be able to come up with some resolutions that will cause no disruption in this marketplace.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean, is it fair to assume that this could be additive for you guys if you're buying back these trusts or the pieces of these trusts?
componenttext: Okay. I mean, is it fair to assume that this could be additive for you guys if you're buying back these trusts or the pieces of these trusts?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not necessarily. It's just -- you're just -- all you're doing is when we buy loans back from the trust, you're recycling them into new asset-backed securities. So...
componenttext: Not necessarily. It's just -- you're just -- all you're doing is when we buy loans back from the trust, you're recycling them into new asset-backed securities. So...

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And I guess I have a question on the segment that you saw elevated losses. And I mean, are there any other segments like this one in other categories that might -- where there might be higher risks in the future of higher defaults or anythin
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And I guess I have a question on the segment that you saw elevated losses. And I mean, are there any other segments like this one in other categories that might -- where there might be higher risks in the future of higher defaults or anything? I mean, is there something -- is there anything else that we should be concerned about going forward?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think the things that I would -- we pay a whole lot of attention to is the portion of the portfolio that has been making payments for extended periods of time. And once a borrower is in that mode, the incidence of delinquency and default declines pro
componenttext: So I think the things that I would -- we pay a whole lot of attention to is the portion of the portfolio that has been making payments for extended periods of time. And once a borrower is in that mode, the incidence of delinquency and default declines progressively each and every year as the number of payments grow. The majority of our portfolio is now in that mode, and so we had this small segment move in and out of repayment a couple of times, primarily I would say due to the Great Recession. And as long as the economy kind of stays where it is, we wouldn't expect to see a disruption. And in fact, we believe our portfolio performance becomes more predictable as customers mature and season through cycles here.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. One final question, and I want to follow up to what Sameer was asking on the share buyback. You guys have talked about kind of the levels of capital you operate and the fact that you're operating at higher levels of capital than what you migh
componenttext: Okay. Great. One final question, and I want to follow up to what Sameer was asking on the share buyback. You guys have talked about kind of the levels of capital you operate and the fact that you're operating at higher levels of capital than what you might going forward. I mean, is there any appetite to maybe use some of that excess capital to buy back additional shares, given where the stock is?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think our capital position has been consistent over this time frame in terms of both how much we expect to generate, how much we expect to return to shareholders. Generally, we like to have -- we don't want to run right down to the edge of where we s
componenttext: So I think our capital position has been consistent over this time frame in terms of both how much we expect to generate, how much we expect to return to shareholders. Generally, we like to have -- we don't want to run right down to the edge of where we set our standards. It gives us flexibility in terms of opportunities to buy loan portfolios, look at opportunities in the asset recovery business, for example, and our preference right now is this kind of -- going to stay with that framework.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Beardsley with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Beardsley with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the targeted OpEx savings of $25 million. I guess, on an annual basis here, you have revenue declining, and you have -- it seems you have $25 million of OpEx savings. Just wondering how much incremental ability do you have to take costs
componenttext: Just a question on the targeted OpEx savings of $25 million. I guess, on an annual basis here, you have revenue declining, and you have -- it seems you have $25 million of OpEx savings. Just wondering how much incremental ability do you have to take costs out as the portfolio amortizes. And is there any incremental step up in expenses as you have some more of these loans entering repayment?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, Eric, one of the things that you got to remember also is that within our guidance for -- of $900 million for 2015, there are also onetime expenses that we're incurring in '15 related to -- of about $25 million related to the $8.5 billion of loa
componenttext: Yes. Well, Eric, one of the things that you got to remember also is that within our guidance for -- of $900 million for 2015, there are also onetime expenses that we're incurring in '15 related to -- of about $25 million related to the $8.5 billion of loans that we are converting onto our portfolio that we expect to complete later this year. So in terms of moving from the $900 million to 2015 [ph] -- going to 2016, not only do you have the removal of that $25 million, you've got another $25 million that's going to come out of the expense base next year because of our restructuring initiative.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd just add to that, Eric, that the $25 million I referenced in my opening remarks was not a forecast for what our OpEx would be in 2016. It was what we would expect to save as a result of this organizational initiative only.
componenttext: Yes, I'd just add to that, Eric, that the $25 million I referenced in my opening remarks was not a forecast for what our OpEx would be in 2016. It was what we would expect to save as a result of this organizational initiative only.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. So combined, you have $50 million that you would expect to get out. On top of that, I'm curious, I guess, how much more could you hypothetically take out over time? How much operating leverage could you take down further?
componenttext: Got it. So combined, you have $50 million that you would expect to get out. On top of that, I'm curious, I guess, how much more could you hypothetically take out over time? How much operating leverage could you take down further?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So our -- these are -- we're not getting into a forecast for 2016 OpEx. We've listed 2 items that doesn't -- and I want to be clear that that's not necessarily comprehensive, and we don't want to go to -- I don't want to go down a laundry list here at thi
componenttext: So our -- these are -- we're not getting into a forecast for 2016 OpEx. We've listed 2 items that doesn't -- and I want to be clear that that's not necessarily comprehensive, and we don't want to go to -- I don't want to go down a laundry list here at this stage in the year. But when we look at our operating expense items here, they're driven -- a good portion of them are driven by the variable nature of our revenues. So as loans mature and they actually become less costly, they can become less costly to service if they're making payments on a regular scheduled time frame. Our big drivers of servicing expense are the number of units we're adding as we increase the number of accounts we are servicing for the Department of Education. So if you look at our business on the loan servicing side as an example, our account load has actually increased over the last 3 years even though our loan portfolio is amortizing down, right? Because we're adding new business and revenues associated with that. In the asset recovery side of the equation, we have a similar activity of our FFELP-related workloads are decreasing, but our other workloads, particularly outside of the education lending space, have been increasing. So to some extent, operating expense is a function of the revenue drivers that we have going. And my preference is, of course, to see revenues increasing.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just on the buyback, I think you had initially said that it would be an annual buyback. Is there any potential to re-up it this year and accelerate the usage of it?
componenttext: Got it. And just on the buyback, I think you had initially said that it would be an annual buyback. Is there any potential to re-up it this year and accelerate the usage of it?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this -- we look at this on a regular basis. We have -- both internally and with the board, and we work with them on a combined basis to decide what's the appropriate level. I don't have much more to add to that at this point.
componenttext: So this -- we look at this on a regular basis. We have -- both internally and with the board, and we work with them on a combined basis to decide what's the appropriate level. I don't have much more to add to that at this point.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just not to beat the dead horse, but just on the cohort of the 2014 loans that exit deferment, what made them different from 2012 and 2013? Were there any characteristics that were particularly different that led to the higher default rate?
componenttext: Okay. And then just not to beat the dead horse, but just on the cohort of the 2014 loans that exit deferment, what made them different from 2012 and 2013? Were there any characteristics that were particularly different that led to the higher default rate?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the 2 biggest things are the ones I mentioned, which is that we had a higher percentage of these borrowers who had demonstrated difficulty making payments when they were in repayment prior to returning to school, and -- than in prior cohorts. So t
componenttext: I think the 2 biggest things are the ones I mentioned, which is that we had a higher percentage of these borrowers who had demonstrated difficulty making payments when they were in repayment prior to returning to school, and -- than in prior cohorts. So that gives you an example of an indication that they were struggling to begin with. And the second piece is the statistic that said more of these customers had moved in and out of school multiple times, not just 2 but more than 2 times. Those were the primary differences.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then just lastly, you recently filed an appeal on the collections business loss with Department of Education. Is there any time lines of when you expect to hear back on that?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just lastly, you recently filed an appeal on the collections business loss with Department of Education. Is there any time lines of when you expect to hear back on that?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Unfortunately, the courts work at their pace. So no indication at this stage of the game.
componenttext: Unfortunately, the courts work at their pace. So no indication at this stage of the game.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark DeVries with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark DeVries with Barclays.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just wanted to discuss the issue of reserves against this problem cohort. I think, Jack, you indicated, you believe it's mostly covered. Is it fair to assume that when you identified the problems in this cohort with the roll rates and these character
componenttext: Yes. Just wanted to discuss the issue of reserves against this problem cohort. I think, Jack, you indicated, you believe it's mostly covered. Is it fair to assume that when you identified the problems in this cohort with the roll rates and these characteristics you just mentioned, given your kind of -- usually your 2-year forward look on reserves, that you would then look at what's coming out of deferment the next couple of years, figure out which ones kind of share those characteristics and then have reserved for those already?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I assume, given the characteristics you mentioned, that these people kind of went in and out, perhaps around the recession, that it's going -- I think you mentioned you expect only about $1 billion coming out of deferment in 2016, that, that coh
componenttext: Okay. And I assume, given the characteristics you mentioned, that these people kind of went in and out, perhaps around the recession, that it's going -- I think you mentioned you expect only about $1 billion coming out of deferment in 2016, that, that cohort is basically going away over the next year or 2.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Correct. And look, the people return to school for multiple reasons, right? We have -- the normal trend we would see in our private loan portfolio is undergrads, which is the primary customer of which private loans are made, returning to school to get a g
componenttext: Correct. And look, the people return to school for multiple reasons, right? We have -- the normal trend we would see in our private loan portfolio is undergrads, which is the primary customer of which private loans are made, returning to school to get a graduate degree. Those are generally positive trends, right? You are getting an advanced degree, and all of the history and data suggest that these customers coming out of graduate school have higher incomes, more stable jobs. In fact, in our private loan book, the best performing segment across the board is loans made to graduate school students. What we saw here is a second group return to school, which is borrowers who -- this isn't true for the entire $2.5 billion of course, but borrowers who did not obtain their undergraduate degree, went back, took more classes, reentered repayment and were back again. And so these customers take long -- took longer to either obtain an undergraduate degree or maybe did not obtain it at all. And the incidence of delinquency and default on borrowers who take more time to get an undergraduate degree is certainly higher, and I think that's what we're seeing in this particular cohort. Generally speaking, every year it takes someone to graduate increases their debt load by about 10%. So if you're going from 4 years to 6 years, you have -- not only has it taken you longer to get to the point of where you're going to generate higher income, but you've got more -- you have a higher debt burden as well. I would describe this pool and the losses coming more from customers who didn't complete their degree.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then just finally, I know you don't provide 2016 guidance, but as you think out to 2016, how much risk is there from additional NIM pressure? If your unsecured funding costs don't recover, is there kind of a need to refinance s
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then just finally, I know you don't provide 2016 guidance, but as you think out to 2016, how much risk is there from additional NIM pressure? If your unsecured funding costs don't recover, is there kind of a need to refinance some more maturities as you look out next year?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, that'll impact the spread going forward, but I think one of the things that we're going to need to look into is alternative sources of financing outside of unsecured debt.
componenttext: Well, certainly, that'll impact the spread going forward, but I think one of the things that we're going to need to look into is alternative sources of financing outside of unsecured debt.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, Somsak, I think you also alluded to the issue of the potential impact of the unhedged floor income. If the forward curve is realized over the next year or 2, should we expect some pressure on the FFELP NIM from that?
componenttext: And then, Somsak, I think you also alluded to the issue of the potential impact of the unhedged floor income. If the forward curve is realized over the next year or 2, should we expect some pressure on the FFELP NIM from that?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly, there will be pressure on that just given the fact that older loans that earned floor income will amortize away quicker than our newer FFELP loans that will amortize slower. So that value will actually decline over time.
componenttext: Certainly, there will be pressure on that just given the fact that older loans that earned floor income will amortize away quicker than our newer FFELP loans that will amortize slower. So that value will actually decline over time.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is that...
componenttext: Okay. And is that...

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: All of that is baked into the projected cash flows that we disclosed on our -- in the release here.
componenttext: All of that is baked into the projected cash flows that we disclosed on our -- in the release here.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct. And the other thing I will add is that we have hedged in our locked-in value of about $900 million of future floor income, and that's locked in through about 2019.
componenttext: That's correct. And the other thing I will add is that we have hedged in our locked-in value of about $900 million of future floor income, and that's locked in through about 2019.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Mark Hammond with Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Mark Hammond with Bank of America.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Following up on what you mentioned about the possible alternative sources of financing outside of unsecured, would you elaborate on that for me?
componenttext: Following up on what you mentioned about the possible alternative sources of financing outside of unsecured, would you elaborate on that for me?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So one of the things that we've got is basically a balance of about $11 billion of overcollateralization built in with our securitization -- within our securitization trust. And one of the things that we would look to do is figuring out ways to eith
componenttext: Sure. So one of the things that we've got is basically a balance of about $11 billion of overcollateralization built in with our securitization -- within our securitization trust. And one of the things that we would look to do is figuring out ways to either refinance those deals going forward or using ways to better lever the balance that are built in within those securitization trusts.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So can I be interpreting that as shifting from unsecured to more securitized debt?
componenttext: Okay. So can I be interpreting that as shifting from unsecured to more securitized debt?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then my last question would be, on the unsecured bond repurchase strategy, I was wondering how you determine which bond to target? I know you'd have some short-dated high-coupon bonds and then some longer-dated bonds below par as well.
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then my last question would be, on the unsecured bond repurchase strategy, I was wondering how you determine which bond to target? I know you'd have some short-dated high-coupon bonds and then some longer-dated bonds below par as well.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the vast majority of the bonds that we bought so far this year have really been targeted at the January 2016 maturity coming due. So we had excess liquidity that was sitting on our balance sheet. And so we decided to better manage our NIM by basicall
componenttext: Yes, the vast majority of the bonds that we bought so far this year have really been targeted at the January 2016 maturity coming due. So we had excess liquidity that was sitting on our balance sheet. And so we decided to better manage our NIM by basically buying those maturities out, because they were going to be due within the next 12 months anyways.

componenttext: So for private, though, Jack.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Private and FFELP, both actually, but private in particular I was referring to. And -- but they'll come too late in the year to have any meaningful impact on 2015 earnings. Clearly, we think we're a -- the best buyer for student loan assets in terms of bo
componenttext: Private and FFELP, both actually, but private in particular I was referring to. And -- but they'll come too late in the year to have any meaningful impact on 2015 earnings. Clearly, we think we're a -- the best buyer for student loan assets in terms of both federal and private given our low cost of -- particularly, we can move them onto our servicing platforms given our low cost of servicing and the higher performance that we can generate out of a portfolio of student loans. So sometimes, the loan portfolios that are offered don't have -- aren't servicing released. We're going to be less competitive on those deals. Sometimes they're residuals, in which case, you're basically just buying cash flows with no ability to kind of influence the performance. And in some instances, on some smaller portfolios, when -- particularly on the deal that was -- the private loan deal that was sold earlier this year was a residual tranche. It brings in -- because there's no financing requirements and because the servicing is structured as part of the agreement, it brings in buyers who were not traditional buyers, and they're willing to pay higher prices than we would pay. The transactions we expect later this year are likely to be whole loans that we would be able to control servicing, and therefore, we think we have better chances of success.

componenttext: Right. Certainly good luck, but I would just would observe that if a whole year does go by that couple of hundred million would certainly be excess at that point.

I mean, I know it's far from your preferred situation, but to the extent that this does go against the industry from Moody's and these bonds are downgraded, it would actually present opportunities, just like there were for you after the crisis, to buy those tranches and at a discount, would it not?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it will create opportunities for us to buy student loans, more than perhaps on some of these tranches. But the things we're looking for here are making sure that the bonds don't suffer downgrades due to timing issues, and we're working with invest
componenttext: I think it will create opportunities for us to buy student loans, more than perhaps on some of these tranches. But the things we're looking for here are making sure that the bonds don't suffer downgrades due to timing issues, and we're working with investors and the rating agencies to make sure that happens. So I think we're better served by having an orderly liquid ABS marketplace.

componenttext: We will need to tap the unsecured markets from time to time, but one of the things that you'll -- I think Jack mentioned earlier is that the unsecured debt is going to be -- will be a mix, an important funding mix going forward. headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Kim, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Navient Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Joe Fisher, Vice President of Investo
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Kim, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Navient Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Joe Fisher, Vice President of Investor Relations, you may begin your conference, sir.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2015 Third Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.Before we begin, keep in mind our disc
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2015 Third Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.
Before we begin, keep in mind our discussion will contain predictions, expectations and forward-looking statements. Actual results in the future may be materially different from those discussed here. This could be due to a variety of factors. Listeners should refer to the discussion of those factors on the company's Form 10-K and other filings with the SEC.
During this conference call, we will refer to non-GAAP measures we call our core earnings. A description of core earnings, a full reconciliation to GAAP measures and our GAAP results can be found in the third quarter 2015 supplemental earnings disclosure. This is posted, along with the earnings press release, on the Investors page at navient.com.
Thank you, and now I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter's earnings call. Thank you for listening. I appreciate your interest and your support.Our results this quarter of $0.48, excluding regulatory expenses, are holding in line with our ex
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter's earnings call. Thank you for listening. I appreciate your interest and your support.
Our results this quarter of $0.48, excluding regulatory expenses, are holding in line with our expectations. They demonstrate the quality of our loan portfolio, the earnings they generate and our strong capabilities in delinquency and default convention. Our provision for private credit loan losses declined to $117 million in this quarter, a reduction of 39% from the prior quarter and 10% from the year-ago period.
For federal education loans, we owned and service, performance trends continued to improve since the peak of the recession, with Navient delivering results 38% better than our peers. Our results also benefited from our continued expansion into services beyond student loans. Year-to-date, our non-student loan-related revenue totaled $75 million, twice the amount earned in the first 9 months of 2014.
ELO which we acquired earlier this year as part of our strategy to leverage our asset recovery and business services capabilities, has generated a 38% increase in net income year-over-year. In addition to the $8 million in regulatory expense, this quarter's results also included the impact of $11 million in loan servicing conversion expense, $6 million from the reduction in asset recovery revenue from a change in interpretation of the Department of Education allowed collection fees and the write-off of $5 million in deferred financing costs as a result of our calling ABS Securities. 
Today, we also completed the acquisition of Xtend Healthcare. This acquisition is consistent with our previously announced intentions that leverages our core capabilities in the asset recovery and business services area to the attractive health care payment sector. Xtend works with over 130 hospitals and medical providers to process payments for the large and rapidly growing patient pay marketplace. This transaction provides a footprint in this attractive sector from which we believe we can drive significant organic growth. This transaction will bring value to our shareholders and our franchise, will be more accretive than share repurchases, even in current market conditions, and after the purchase price is cash flow positive. We're delighted to welcome the Xtend team to Navient.
Our business units continued to deliver on the operations front. For example, we successfully completed the conversion of nearly $5 billion in FFELP loans from a third-party servicer platform to our own. Our conversion methodology met or exceeded best practices, including robust data mapping and testing, multiple communications prior to and after the conversion to the customer and a dedicated and specially trained call center team.
Our team worked hard to deliver a positive experience for customers, and I'm pleased with the rewarding customer feedback. This past week, we launched a new customer online portal, designed to simplify the experience for customers and improve operating efficiency. We also continued our conversion to a new collections platform that will create flexibility for on boarding new clients as well as drive lower operating cost.
We continued to leverage automation tools to support compliant and consistency while delivering operating efficiency. In addition, we continued to assist our customers in the successful management of their loans. Last month, the Department of Education released the 2012 3-year cohort default rates. And once again, Navient service several loans, defaulted at a significantly lower rate than other borrowers. As I stated earlier, 38% lower. Our efforts to help customers succeed drive these results. We help over customers successfully manage their loans through extensive and targeted outreach efforts, to promote affordable payment solutions.
For example, nearly 1 in 5 borrowers and 1/3 of all dollar serviced are enrolled in income driven repayment plans. We promote repayment options to our 10 million federal loan customers through over 170 million letters, e-mails and text each year. And we assist the 345,000 borrowers who paid their loans in full this year.
As you and certain we management and fellow shareholders are well aware, several items, including industry-specific issues, are weighing heavily on our stock price and credit spreads. The status have put limits on our access to new sources of liquidity, particularly new issuance of unsecured notes. Ironically, while the price of our unsecured debt makes it very attractive to repurchase, it's very difficult to find willing sellers.
While these issues have created some uncertainty for our investors, I considered the market reaction to be significantly out of proportion. As a result, I will address the main issues of the legal final maturity date in the current regulatory environment directly.
Earlier this year, Moody's and Fitch placed $34 billion of our FFELP ABS on credit watch due to concerns that trust cash flows will not be sufficient to pay all bonds by the legal final maturity date. This concern is based largely on the increased use of income driven repayment programs and other repayment options.
While borrowers aren't back using these important options, particularly income driven repayment programs at higher rates, we still expect borrower payments will be sufficient to meet the legal final maturity dates. To provide added assurance, we have added call rights on most trust that allow us to purchase up to 20% of the original balance of student loans sold to the trust.
To help put this issue in perspective, of the $34 billion in bonds on credit watch, less than $2.2 billion have a maturity date in the next 5 years. Even at a 0% prepayment speed, a rate our trust have never experienced, we expect loan cash flows to be sufficient to meet the maturity dates. Our data show borrower payment did slow with the recovery of the economy in the improvement in the job markets, due to a rapidly falling default rates. This is a good thing. Since then, borrower prepayment speeds have returned to historical levels and remained at levels that are significantly greater than 0%.
Last week, we released an in-depth loan payment data package including an audio explanation of the slides. And earlier this week, we filed a very detailed response to Moody's request for comment. We'll continue to work with the rating agencies to produce the appropriate outcome.
As you know, the CFPB and state agencies have been reviewing our servicing and collections operations. The common public narrative is that the majority of borrowers are struggling with excess to student loan debt. And further, it only services informed borrowers of the available repayment options, delinquency and defaults would all but disappear.
In reality, the vast majority of all borrowers are successfully meeting their payment obligations, and we have assisted more than 1/2 of borrowers that we service, covering nearly 70% of balances to select and enrolled an alternative payment program.
At Navient, we developed sophisticated data-driven strategies to reach struggling borrowers. When we do connect, more than 9 out of 10x, we are able to enroll the customer in a program that keeps them out of default. Sadly, over 90% of our borrowers that do reach default, do not respond to our hundreds of attempts to contact them. It goes without saying, we cannot enroll a borrower in an alternative payment program if we cannot connect with them.
Some also believe that all borrowers should be enrolled in income driven repayment options. And for some borrowers, enrollment in an income driven payment plan is the right choice. Income driven repayment plans, however, extend the loan term. As a result from any borrowers, this would significant increase the total amount paid over the life of the loan. For example, a borrower with $30,000 in loans, and a starting salary of $30,000 per year, they would pay 33% more under payee than under the standard repayment term, even though a small portion of the loan would be forgiven after 20 years. For some borrowers, this is just not an attractive alternative.
Finally, there is some concern that regulatory changes will create significant increases in servicing cost. While we expect regulators to issue standard practices for students loan service and collection, we believe these standards will establish consistency within the industry and will be beneficial to borrowers and servicers. We would welcome the introduction of standards that are recognized by all of our regulators.
These factors have combined to weigh heavily on overstock price. Many analysts have written reasonable discounted value of our stable and predictable cash flows support a stock price north of $20 a share, I agree. Since quarter end, we have purchased 4.7 million shares, at an average price of $11.81, bringing our year-to-date purchases to 46.7 million shares, at an average price of $17.80. 
Also, since quarter end, we repurchased $43 million of unsecured debt, mainly at the July 2018 issue. Our near-term objective is to take advantage of these current market prices. And while we have ample liquidity to service our debt over the next few years, we are aggressively pursuing options that would allow us to increase our activities in both debt and share repurchases. We have substantial assets available to do so, and I am confident in our ability to execute here.
For example, we have $5.2 billion in unencumbered student loans, $11.5 billion in net assets in our securitization trust, and close to $5 billion in servicing cash flows from our securitization trust. 
Bottom line, our business is sound and is generating the earnings and cash flows we expect. Our student loan assets represent a rocksolid foundation of value that were well prepared to capture. These assets and our existing operating capabilities will allow us to continue to create value for our investors.
Sobczak will now provide more details on the results of the quarter. Sak?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation, beginning with Slide 4 which provides a summary of our core earnings.In the third quarter, we reported $0.47 per share of core earnings
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation, beginning with Slide 4 which provides a summary of our core earnings.
In the third quarter, we reported $0.47 per share of core earnings. These results included $0.01 per share or $8 million impact of regulatory-related cost and a $0.02 per share or $11 million of one-time conversion costs to nearly $5 billion of FFELP loans to our servicing system.
Our third quarter operating expenses totaled $228 million, compared to operating expenses of $195 million a year ago. The increase is related to the cost previously mentioned and additional costs resulting from the recent acquisition of Gila. We expect 2015 core EPS to be approximately $1.85 and operating expenses of less than $900 million. These items do exclude regulatory related costs as well as the impact of the acquisition of Xtend.
And before I go in to our segment results, I'd like to highlight the financing activities that took place in the third quarter on Slide 5. In the quarter, we issued a $700 million private loan securitization transaction. The collateral for this transaction was made up of well seasoned, high-quality loans, primarily from our SLM 2010-B trust. This transaction resulted in lower cost of funds overall and raised over $70 million of cash after paying off the 2010-B transaction.
As Jack mentioned, we submitted our comments addressing the legal final maturity issue to Moody's earlier this week. And to help address this issue, during the quarter, we funded $852 million of cleanup calls associated with 7 FFELP trusts. Year-to-date, we have funded $1.1 billion of cleanup calls to our FFELP ABCP conduits. Additionally, we amended another 16 trust to include a 10% optional servicer purchase right.
Our unsecured debt declined by $428 million to less than $16 billion outstanding at quarter end. We maintained a tangible net asset ratio of 1.25x and purchase an additional $43 million of unsecured debt in October.
In the quarter, we repurchased 12.1 million shares or $175 million and have repurchased an additional 4.8 million shares as of October 20. We have remaining authority of $168 million under our current share repurchase plan as of October 20. 
Although this activity was undertaking while maintaining a strong capital position. And we will look for ways to manage the timing of our future cash flows from our student loan portfolio to better match the maturity profile of our unsecured debt. 
Let's turn to Slide 6 to discuss our FFELP segment results. FFELP core earnings were $70 million of third quarter 2015 and that is compared with $79 million in the third quarter 2014. For the quarter, FFELP net interest margin was 81 basis points. And going forward, FFELP NIM maybe impacted by future LIBOR rates which will impact the amount of core income in our portfolio. We expect the fourth quarter FFELP net interest margin to remain in the low 80s.
I'm going to move to Slide 7 to review our private education loan segment. Core earnings in this segment decreased $21 million from a year-ago quarter to $77 million. Third quarter net interest margin came in at 3.77%. The private net interest margin was 6 basis points lower than our expectations, primarily due to a decrease in the spread between our prime earnings assets that are funded with LIBOR-based debt.
For the fourth quarter, we expect the private student loan net interest margin to be approximately 3.65%. The decrease in our provision for losses of $74 million in the prior quarter is a result of the additional reserve we booked in the second quarter for segment of borrowers who exited the firm in 2014 And are experiencing unfavorable credit trends compared to those who exited the firm in the previous years.
Slide 8 shows our private education loan asset quality trends over the last 5 years. This is a portfolio that is well seasoned with 94% of our loans and repayment status, having made more than 12 payments.
Third quarter charge-offs were at 2.3% or $10 million lower than the third quarter of last year. Our total delinquency rate, which is 7.4%, and that's compared to 7.9% in the year-ago quarter. We do expect our annualized charge-off rates for the full year to be approximately 2.6%.
Let's turn to Slide 9 to review our business services segment. In this segment, core earnings of $79 million in the quarter compared with $85 million in the third quarter of 2014. We saw an increase in our asset recovery revenues of $20 million versus the prior year. This increase was primarily related to the full integration of Gila, which expanded our footprint in the asset recovery and business process outsourcing space. The decline in asset recovery revenues from the prior quarter is mainly related to 3 items: First, an expected reduction of volume for student loan collections. Second, an unexpected rate change to a flat yearly fee structure associated with the Department of Education collection contract, which became effective on July 1; and third, change in the interpretation of Department of Education, which impacted allowed collection fees for FFELP loans that Jack mentioned earlier.
During the quarter, we were awarded the state tax amnesty contract that resulted in an increase in our contingency asset recovery receivable inventory of $5.7 billion. The amnesty program will be conducted from September 15 through November 16 of this year. In the past 10 years, we've recovered over $1 billion under similar tax amnesty contracts for states and large municipalities. We expect our asset recovery revenues to be approximately $355 million for 2015.
Finally, turning to GAAP results on Slide 10. We recorded third quarter GAAP net income of $237 million or $0.63 per share, as compared with net income of $359 million or $0.85 per share in the third quarter of 2014. And just as a reminder, the primary differences between core earnings and GAAP are to March related to our position, expenses related to the restructuring and reorganization and the income associated with SLM Banco.
With that, let's open up the call up for questions.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think a lot of this depends on what you're actually financing. So to the extent that you're financing cash flows that you would, otherwise, expect to be -- that would be financed with our unsecured debt today, clearly those proceeds would go to repurcha
componenttext: I think a lot of this depends on what you're actually financing. So to the extent that you're financing cash flows that you would, otherwise, expect to be -- that would be financed with our unsecured debt today, clearly those proceeds would go to repurchasing our unsecured debt maturities. Our goal -- our long-term goal here has been and what we've actually accomplished has been to pay down our unsecured debt for the most part, but smooth it out, so we've steady issuers in the unsecured arena over the last several years to flatten out our maturity profile there, to better match our cash gross. At the same time, we substantially reduced the amount of our unsecured debt outstanding and have continued to do so year-to-date in 2015. To the extent that we're financing and pulling in future earnings, that's where you really look to creating the capability of enhancing our stock repurchase program.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on the first point of the regulatory items, we have responded to the CFPB's listed issues, and we're now waiting to hear back from them. There's not a specific time frame for that process but certainly very eager to engage and begin to resolve some of
componenttext: So on the first point of the regulatory items, we have responded to the CFPB's listed issues, and we're now waiting to hear back from them. There's not a specific time frame for that process but certainly very eager to engage and begin to resolve some of these items. I think it's important to note that several of the items here on this list our items that were previously covered through other regulatory settlements, particularly with the FDIC. Some items are related to Department of Ed policies and regulations. And to my earlier comments, we and borrowers, I think, would certainly benefit from a common understanding of regulators of what the rules and program terms and conditions should be. And some were just will continue to work with them or items that we have addressed and changed in prior years, just as we continue to work with customers to make the process of managing their loans easier. On the needle final maturity date issue, I -- this is obviously, a complicated issue and has lots of moving parts. But at the end of the day, we believe that borrower payments and cash flows coming off the student loan portfolio, while they did slow during that 2008 and 2013 period were loss of air various reasons, the activities or the performance of those periods really don't form a baseline, which would extrapolate off of. And that if you look at historical norms and that is probably closer to what we're experiencing today, prepayment speeds for borrowed loans are substantially higher than they were during that time frame. And when you run cash flows and expected borrower behavior off of those numbers, you do get very, very good different results. And so having -- we would certainly rather the rating agencies take more time to evaluate the data and get a more comprehensive understanding of potential cash flows here and borrower behavior then to make a short term answer or solution. Obviously, we'd like the issue resolved, but it certainly better it to have it resolved right or appropriately.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The final question, you guys talk extensively how sell assets to buy back stock, but you also mentioned that you wanted adhere to the tangible net asset ratio of 1.25x, and it's been hard to repurchase debt. I mean there's anything that would preclude you
componenttext: The final question, you guys talk extensively how sell assets to buy back stock, but you also mentioned that you wanted adhere to the tangible net asset ratio of 1.25x, and it's been hard to repurchase debt. I mean there's anything that would preclude you from exhausting the share buyback or extending it further if you can't do the debt?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, obviously, our philosophy here in practice has been to as we generate excess capital, both through earnings and through the release of capital from the amortization of our loan portfolios, that, that will be returned to shareholders through sh
componenttext: No. I mean, obviously, our philosophy here in practice has been to as we generate excess capital, both through earnings and through the release of capital from the amortization of our loan portfolios, that, that will be returned to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. I don't think anything has changed here on that side of the equation. Clearly, the current stock price would encourage us and makes it far more attractive for us to be more aggressive on that front. But that does require the ability to be able to issue any unsecured markets to be able to smooth out our debt maturities among that's one of the things that we're very eager to do. We believe that as we address some of the items that investors have, that I said we -- I would describe them as being out of the portion, that you would see credit spreads continued to tighten as we have over last couple of weeks here. And then return to more normalized levels.
