componenttext: Okay. And you kind of alluded to this in a previous question, but I mean how should we think about from the issues related to the CFPB the fact that perhaps some of the companies that the CFPB has examined and is looking at this report haven't dealt with some of the regulatory bodies that you have, I mean, how do you think that influences the process as it goes forward?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, this is really the first time for us through that with the Bureau, so I think that's really going to be a wait and see. We feel like we have outstanding controls and practices here to protect borrowers and service they loans appropriately. I think t
componenttext: Well, this is really the first time for us through that with the Bureau, so I think that's really going to be a wait and see. We feel like we have outstanding controls and practices here to protect borrowers and service they loans appropriately. I think the most important thing we do and the thing that we feel more strongly about is helping customers avoid default and the severe consequences of that, that means getting them into repayment for once they can afford. And as the Department of Ed defaults statistics to illustrate here, we do this better than anybody. I mean to take loans that are basically the same across all servicers and deliver a 38% lower default rate as those are the results people are looking for here, right? Getting borrowers into programs they can afford. As I mentioned, some folks do believe that income driven repayment is the ultimate solution. What we do is we really work with customers to let them understand the range of options that they have available to them and they get to pick the one that fits their budget fast. And 70% of our dollar volume is enrolled in an alternative payment program, which would include everything from income driven repayment solutions to loan consolidation, which extends of the long-term out. So these are the solutions that work for our customers and drive the substantially lower default rates. I think -- that's just kind of how we've been working with the regulators in this, and if it means changing some of our practices to be -- to improve outcomes, we're all in on that.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean I was struck by the fact that the deal in their report pointed to the federal government for not advertising some of the repayment options as supposed to the servicers. I don't know maybe if you can kind of list those in the process and kind of rou
componenttext: I mean I was struck by the fact that the deal in their report pointed to the federal government for not advertising some of the repayment options as supposed to the servicers. I don't know maybe if you can kind of list those in the process and kind of round out a little better.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Certainly, we would argue here that there's a couple of things that need to happen. And certainly encouraging borrowers to contact their services is something that we would like to see more of, because when we do contact the customer and can connect
componenttext: Yes. Certainly, we would argue here that there's a couple of things that need to happen. And certainly encouraging borrowers to contact their services is something that we would like to see more of, because when we do contact the customer and can connect with them, more than 9x out of 10, we're able to resolve that delinquency. And the other issue period which without your about before and everything else is simplification of the program. The share volume and terms of some of these repayment options can be very overwhelming to people who are not dealing this pay today, it's hard for them to understand which program produces the best results for them. And if we can simplify and narrow and shrink them down to a fewer, but more simple programs to understand, I think everyone benefits from that.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The last question what I got, you made a comment I'd which I think was pretty interesting. You said that the acquisition of Xtend would be better than deploying cash in share repurchase, can you talk a little bit what the economics are and where there are
componenttext: The last question what I got, you made a comment I'd which I think was pretty interesting. You said that the acquisition of Xtend would be better than deploying cash in share repurchase, can you talk a little bit what the economics are and where there are other opportunities out there that can be comfortable in that fee-based area?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we have -- sure, one of the things that we've looked at as we completed the separation is what are our core capabilities and how are those transferable into different areas or different asset classes. And in the asset recovery business services sect
componenttext: Well, we have -- sure, one of the things that we've looked at as we completed the separation is what are our core capabilities and how are those transferable into different areas or different asset classes. And in the asset recovery business services sector, this is an area where we have developed a very, very strong and successful track record of helping our customers manage their cash flows to either asset recovery or business processes types of things. And for years, our focus here was on educational loans, almost exclusively. And we began to develop alternatives, working with state agencies and municipalities. Somsak referenced the state tax amnesty program that we're running as an example. We have long-standing contracts with a number of cities and states, managing their receivables book. And we thought that there are a couple of places that we could go to expand our footprint and really put us in a place that we can grow rapidly on an organic basis off of that. Gila, the acquisition of Gila earlier this year, was one example of leveraging those skills and capabilities into a broader municipal arena and geographic areas where we were not strong, to begin with, and Xtend does the same thing for us in a new area of health care payments. Our view here was that an acquisition in this space was really necessary for us to bring a resume to bear and yet the activities that they do are very, very similar to what we do in other asset classes and so bringing our scale, our data, sophistication and strategies to that process is something that we think will allow us to grow those businesses rapidly. And when you look at the opportunities there, relative to share repurchases, you know that's where we do our math and understand what we can drive in terms of the economics. It's a better deal for shareholders, in our view, to allocate that capital to the acquisition than it is to do share repurchases. I want to be clear, however, that these are small -- relatively small acquisitions that has helped us built a footprint, it's not -- our strategy is not by our -- buy these businesses through series of acquisitions, but to build a footprint and grow organically.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Lee Cooperman with Omega advisors.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Lee Cooperman with Omega advisors.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's really more observations, philosophical rather than questions, but they are important to me. I think, if my numbers are right, that since the spin, we have spent $1.242 billion buying back 69 million shares in an average price of $18, and when you in
componenttext: It's really more observations, philosophical rather than questions, but they are important to me. I think, if my numbers are right, that since the spin, we have spent $1.242 billion buying back 69 million shares in an average price of $18, and when you increased about the repurchase program, I think the response of the company generally has been that you believe the net asset value was to the area of 22 or 23, and repurchasing to make sense. We agree with that by the way, of numbers 23. If we still believe that, we would urge you to find ways of being creative to raise additional funds, double down or tripled down. I think your in sympathy with that, we were just urge you, there's no better use of shareholder money than buying something back $0.50 and a dollar, particularly in this environment where they are few things selling $0.50 and a dollar, so that's kind of advocacy question -- not a question, but an advocacy statement. Second, I noticed recently that a company, by the name, Realty, announced an intention to liquidate. And when I called the CEO, I was not a shareholder in the company, when I call the seal what motivated them, he said he felt that the prospect of him getting the net asset value that he believed the company had was so remote that he felt the best thing to do is to liquidate the company or return the money to shareholders. And kind of a theme out of that book, you deal with many regulators, some of which have conflict views, we're living with constant criticism and hostile environment despite the social good you do for the people that borrow money from you. Has the Board considered part by stability of liquidating the company but run off and returned the money to shareholders so the can invest the companies that are more appreciated by shareholders or the government? And so that's kind of a philosophical question. And third, your comment, I felt was very interesting. I have no problem with the Xtend acquisition, companies cannot the purchase stock success in you've got to grow the business. But when you said it's more accretive to stock repurchase, I would probably challenge that because essentially, when you buy back stock, you're probably looking at the earnings per share impact of what earnings you got versus the quest of money, et cetera. But in the stock repurchase, you're retiring a 5% dividend and you're capturing a $9 discount to NAV. And obviously, as we retire more share at a $9 discount to NAV then NAV goes up. So I'm not sure you're calculating correctly the virtue of Xtend versus a stock repurchase, but that's not a big deal I think you're trying to grow the company. Those are observations, I don't know if you want to comment on them but I leave them up to you. We're very supportive of management of complaint, this is an observation.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Denis. We definitely agree with your first point, and we are working hard to find those creative alternatives to allow us to do more and more both in 2 things are on sale here, both at the debt and the share price. And so we are aggressively wo
componenttext: Thank you, Denis. We definitely agree with your first point, and we are working hard to find those creative alternatives to allow us to do more and more both in 2 things are on sale here, both at the debt and the share price. And so we are aggressively working on both of those. One of the unique parts of our business is if we can finance assets through an ABS transaction, we're able to raise funds substantially cheaper than our cost of debt in an unsecured arena so it's an easy arbitrage to take advantage of and one that would like to do see more of that, same is true on the share repurchase side. I do want to spend a little I'm just on your comment on the liquidation issue here. The value -- the franchise value of this company is really anchored in the cash flows coming from the student loan portfolios. And I would say the regulatory issues are coming from our service -- the servicing of student loans. Be -- in effect, not because we chose this, it was chosen by Congress, we are liquidating our student loan holdings. They're amortizing portfolio, no new FFELP loans are being created and those loans will -- those portfolios will go to 0 over time and our job is to maximize the earnings of that portfolio. We think we can -- we're doing that and running the operation on that side of the equation is frankly not a whole lot different in either kind of alternative structure. On the servicing side of the equation, you know, there's no question that as a business, we do a great job in this space and we deliver value for our customers and taxpayers and the results that we generate. If the regulatory environment is not going to allow that business to work, and be profitable, then it's not an attractive business. And that is certainly something we would take a look at. We need to work with the regulators today to resolve the open issues with and then CFPB and we're going to do that. And a big part of our strategy is this really about driving and producing the results that all including the regulators are looking for here. But it's to be determined opportunity for sure.

componenttext: Well, first of all, I think the items that were on the table, both legal and final maturity and the regulatory step create where the outcome is unclear, that uncertainty creates the opportunity for the events that you just described to happen. Some of those were certainly interpreted by some incorrectly so there was a view earlier on that it's early in the process that the legal final maturity issue would cause us to spend liquidity that would otherwise be used to service our unsecured debt, clean up those assets back calls. I think the clearly explain that is not the case, as an example. And as we've kind of responded to the -- some of the thesis here and items I think you see both our credit spreads tighten and our stock price improve. Our goal and objective is, of course, to produce the outcomes and make sure people understand the outcomes that are likely to occur here and that's what we've been working on both the legal final maturity and the regulatory cost side of the equation, but we do need those items to resolve before I think you get back to completely normal. I did -- as I mentioned in the beginning of the call, one of the challenges we're facing, is even though it's attractive for us to buy back debt, it's difficult for us to get any kind of meaningful volume here. And that I think tells you a little bit about how whether the fixed income investors are, they see the same value that we do and therefore, are unwilling to sell.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2015 Third Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.Before we begin, keep in mind our disc
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2015 Third Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.
Before we begin, keep in mind our discussion will contain predictions, expectations and forward-looking statements. Actual results in the future may be materially different from those discussed here. This could be due to a variety of factors. Listeners should refer to the discussion of those factors on the company's Form 10-K and other filings with the SEC.
During this conference call, we will refer to non-GAAP measures we call our core earnings. A description of core earnings, a full reconciliation to GAAP measures and our GAAP results can be found in the third quarter 2015 supplemental earnings disclosure. This is posted along with the earnings press release on the Investors page at navient.com.
Thank you, and now I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter's earnings call. Thank you for listening. I appreciate your interest and your support.Our results this quarter of $0.48, excluding regulatory expenses, are holding in line with our ex
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our third quarter's earnings call. Thank you for listening. I appreciate your interest and your support.
Our results this quarter of $0.48, excluding regulatory expenses, are holding in line with our expectations. They demonstrate the quality of our loan portfolio, the earnings they generate and our strong capabilities in delinquency and default prevention. Our provision for private credit loan losses declined to $117 million this quarter, a reduction of 39% from the prior quarter and 10% from the year-ago period.
For federal education loans we own and service, performance trends continued to improve since the peak of the recession, with Navient delivering results 38% better than our peers. Our results also benefited from our continued expansion into services beyond student loans. Year-to-date, our nonstudent loan-related revenue totaled $75 million, twice the amount earned in the first 9 months of 2014.
Gila, which we acquired earlier this year as part of our strategy to leverage our asset recovery and business services capabilities, has generated a 38% increase in net income year-over-year. In addition to the $8 million in regulatory expense, this quarter's results also included the impact of $11 million in loan servicing conversion expense, $6 million from the reduction in asset recovery revenue from a change in interpretation of the Department of Education allowed collection fees and the write-off of $5 million in deferred financing costs as a result of our calling ABS securities. 
Today, we also completed the acquisition of Xtend Healthcare. This acquisition is consistent with our previously announced intentions that leverages our core capabilities in the asset recovery and business services area to the attractive health care payment sector. Xtend works with over 130 hospitals and medical providers to process payments for the large and rapidly growing patient pay marketplace. This transaction provides a footprint in this attractive sector from which we believe we can drive significant organic growth. This transaction will bring value to our shareholders and our franchise, will be more accretive than share repurchases even in current market conditions and after the purchase price is cash flow positive. We're delighted to welcome the Xtend team to Navient.
Our business units continued to deliver on the operations front. For example, we successfully completed the conversion of nearly $5 billion in FFELP loans from a third-party servicer platform to our own. Our conversion methodology met or exceeded best practices, including robust data mapping and testing, multiple communications prior to and after the conversion to the customer and a dedicated and specially trained call center team. Our team worked hard to deliver a positive experience for customers, and I'm pleased with the rewarding customer feedback. 
This past week, we launched a new customer online portal designed to simplify the experience for customers and improve operating efficiency. We also continued our conversion to a new collections platform that will create flexibility for onboarding new clients as well as drive lower operating costs.
We continue to leverage automation tools to support compliance and consistency while delivering operating efficiency. In addition, we continue to assist our customers in the successful management of their loans. Last month, the Department of Education released the 2012 3-year cohort default rates. And once again, Navient-serviced federal loans defaulted at a significantly lower rate than other borrowers. As I stated earlier, 38% lower. 
Our efforts to help customers succeed drive these results. We help our customers successfully manage their loans through extensive and targeted outreach efforts to promote affordable payment solutions. For example, nearly 1 in 5 borrowers and 1/3 of all dollar serviced are enrolled in income-driven repayment plans. We promote repayment options to our 10 million federal loan customers through over 170 million letters, e-mails and texts each year, and we assist the 345,000 borrowers who paid their loans in full this year.
As you and certainly we as management and fellow shareholders are well aware, several items, including industry-specific issues, are weighing heavily on our stock price and credit spreads. These factors have put limits on our access to new sources of liquidity, particularly new issuance of unsecured notes. Ironically, while the price of our unsecured debt makes it very attractive for us to repurchase, it's very difficult to find willing sellers.
While these issues have created some uncertainty for our investors, I consider the market reaction to be significantly out of proportion. As a result, I will address the main issues of the legal final maturity date in the current regulatory environment directly.
Earlier this year, Moody's and Fitch placed $34 billion of our FFELP ABS on credit watch due to concerns that trust cash flows will not be sufficient to pay all bonds by the legal final maturity date. This concern is based largely on the increased use of income-driven repayment programs and other repayment options. While borrowers are in fact using these important options, particularly income-driven repayment programs, at higher rates, we still expect borrower payments will be sufficient to meet the legal final maturity dates. To provide added assurance, we've added call rights on most trusts that allow us to purchase up to 20% of the original balance of student loans sold to the trust.
To help put this issue in perspective, of the $34 billion in bonds on credit watch, less than $2.2 billion have a maturity date in the next 5 years. Even at a 0% prepayment speed, a rate our trusts have never experienced, we expect loan cash flows to be sufficient to meet the maturity dates. Our data show borrower payment did slow with the recovery of the economy and the improvement in the job markets due to a rapidly falling default rates. This is a good thing. Since then, borrower prepayment speeds have returned to historical levels and remain at levels that are significantly greater than 0%.
Last week, we released an in-depth loan payment data package, including an audio explanation of the slides. And earlier this week, we filed a very detailed response to Moody's request for comment. We'll continue to work with the rating agencies to produce the appropriate outcome.
As you know, the CFPB and state agencies have been reviewing our servicing and collections operations. The common public narrative is that the majority of borrowers are struggling with excessive student loan debt. And further, if only servicers informed borrowers of the available repayment options, delinquency and defaults would all but disappear. In reality, the vast majority of all borrowers are successfully meeting their payment obligations, and we have assisted more than 1/2 of borrowers that we service, covering nearly 70% of balances to select and enroll in an alternative payment program.
At Navient, we developed sophisticated data-driven strategies to reach struggling borrowers. When we do connect more than 9 out of 10x, we are able to enroll the customer in a program that keeps them out of default. Sadly, over 90% of our borrowers that do reach default do not respond to our hundreds of attempts to contact them. It goes without saying, we cannot enroll a borrower in an alternative payment program if we cannot connect with them.
Some also believe that all borrowers should be enrolled in income-driven repayment options. And for some borrowers, enrollment in an income-driven payment plan is the right choice. Income-driven repayment plans, however, extend the loan term. As a result for many borrowers, this would significantly increase the total amount paid over the life of the loan. For example, a borrower with $30,000 in loans and a starting salary of $30,000 per year, they would pay 33% more under payee than under the standard repayment term even though a small portion of the loan would be forgiven after 20 years. For some borrowers, this is just not an attractive alternative.
Finally, there is some concern that regulatory changes will create significant increases in servicing costs. While we expect regulators to issue standard practices for student loan servicing and collection, we believe these standards will establish consistency within the industry and will be beneficial to borrowers and servicers. We would welcome the introduction of standards that are recognized by all of our regulators.
These factors have combined to weigh heavily on our stock price. Many analysts have written that a reasonable discounted value of our stable and predictable cash flows support a stock price north of $20 a share. I agree. Since quarter end, we have purchased 4.7 million shares at an average price of $11.81, bringing our year-to-date purchases to 46.7 million shares at an average price of $17.80. 
Also since quarter end, we repurchased $43 million of unsecured debt mainly at the July 2018 issue. Our near-term objective is to take advantage of these current market prices. And while we have ample liquidity to service our debt over the next few years, we are aggressively pursuing options that would allow us to increase our activities in both debt and share repurchases. We have substantial assets available to do so, and I am confident in our ability to execute here. For example, we have $5.2 billion in unencumbered student loans, $11.5 billion in net assets in our securitization trusts and close to $5 billion in servicing cash flows from our securitization trusts. 
Bottom line, our business is sound and is generating the earnings and cash flows we expect. Our student loan assets represent a rock-solid foundation of value that we're well prepared to capture. These assets and our existing operating capabilities will allow us to continue to create value for our investors.
Somsak will now provide more details on the results of the quarter. Sak?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings.In the third quarter, we reported $0.47 per share of core earnings
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings.
In the third quarter, we reported $0.47 per share of core earnings. These results included $0.01 per share or a $8 million impact of regulatory-related costs and a $0.02 per share or $11 million of onetime conversion costs through nearly $5 billion of FFELP loans to our servicing system.
Our third quarter operating expenses totaled $228 million compared to operating expenses of $195 million a year ago. The increase is related to the cost previously mentioned and additional costs resulting from the recent acquisition of Gila. We expect 2015 core EPS to be approximately $1.85 and operating expenses of less than $900 million. These items do exclude regulatory-related costs as well as the impact of the acquisition of Xtend.
And before I go into our segment results, I'd like to highlight the financing activities that took place in the third quarter on Slide 5. In the quarter, we issued a $700 million private loan securitization transaction. The collateral for this transaction was made up of well-seasoned, high-quality loans, primarily from our SLM 2010-B trust. This transaction resulted in lower cost of funds overall and raised over $70 million of cash after paying off the 2010-B transaction.
As Jack mentioned, we submitted our comments addressing the legal final maturity issue to Moody's earlier this week. And to help address this issue, during the quarter, we funded $852 million of cleanup calls associated with 7 FFELP trusts. Year-to-date, we have funded $1.1 billion of cleanup calls through our FFELP ABCP conduits. And additionally, we amended another 16 trusts to include a 10% optional servicer purchase right.
Our unsecured debt declined by $428 million to less than $16 billion outstanding at quarter end. We maintained a tangible net asset ratio of 1.25x and have purchased an additional $43 million of unsecured debt in October.
In the quarter, we repurchased 12.1 million shares for $175 million and have repurchased an additional 4.8 million shares as of October 20. We have remaining authority of $168 million under our current share repurchase plan as of October 20. All this activity was undertaking while maintaining a strong capital position. And we will look for ways to manage the timing of our future cash flows from our student loan portfolio to better match the maturity profile of our unsecured debt. 
Let's turn to Slide 6 to discuss our FFELP segment results. FFELP core earnings were $70 million for third quarter 2015, and that's compared with $79 million in the third quarter 2014. For the quarter, FFELP net interest margin was 81 basis points. And going forward, FFELP NIM may be impacted by future LIBOR rates, which will impact the amount of core income in our portfolio. We expect the fourth quarter FFELP net interest margin to remain in the low 80s.
I'm going to slide to -- I'm going to move to Slide 7 to review our private education loan segment. Core earnings in this segment decreased $21 million from the year-ago quarter to $77 million. Third quarter net interest margin came in at 3.77%. The private net interest margin was 6 basis points lower than our expectations, primarily due to a decrease in the spread between our prime earning assets that are funded with LIBOR-based debt. For the fourth quarter, we expect the private student loan net interest margin to be approximately 3.65%. 
The decrease in our provision for losses of $74 million in the prior quarter is as a result of the additional reserve we booked in the second quarter for a segment of borrowers who exited the firm in 2014 and are experiencing unfavorable credit trends compared to those who exited the firm in previous years.
Slide 8 shows our private education loan asset quality trends over the last 5 years. This is a portfolio that is well seasoned with 94% of loans in repayment status having made more than 12 payments.
The third quarter charge-offs were at 2.3% or $10 million lower than the third quarter of last year. Our total delinquency rate was at 7.4%, and that's compared to 7.9% in the year-ago quarter. We do expect our annualized charge-off rates for the full year to be approximately 2.6%.
Let's turn to Slide 9 to review our business services segment. In this segment, core earnings of $79 million in the quarter compare with $85 million in the third quarter of 2014. We saw an increase in our asset recovery revenues of $20 million versus the prior year. This increase was primarily related to the full integration of Gila, which expanded our footprint in the asset recovery and business process outsourcing space. The decline in asset recovery revenues from the prior quarter is mainly related to 3 items: first, an expected reduction of volume for student loan collections; second, an expected rate change to a flat unit fee structure associated with the Department of Education collections contract, which became effective on July 1; and third, a change in the interpretation of the Department of Education, which impacted allowed collection fees for FFELP loans that Jack mentioned earlier.
During the quarter, we were awarded the state tax amnesty contract that resulted in an increase in our contingency asset recovery receivable inventory of $5.7 billion. The amnesty program will be conducted from September 15 through November 16 of this year. In the past 10 years, we've recovered over $1 billion under similar tax amnesty contracts for states and large municipalities. We expect our asset recovery revenues to be approximately $355 million for 2015.
Finally, turning to GAAP results on Slide 10. We recorded third quarter GAAP net income of $237 million or $0.63 per share as compared with net income of $359 million or $0.85 per share in the third quarter of 2014. And just as a reminder, the primary differences between core earnings and GAAP are the marks related to our derivative positions, expenses related to the restructuring and reorganization and the income associated with SLM BankCo.
With that, let's open the call up for questions.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Mark DeVries from Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Mark DeVries from Barclays.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question, Jack, with all the securities in your capital structure trading so cheap, I know you've talked about pulling forward cash flows, what's your appetite here for potentially selling residuals, particularly in private student loans, so you can
componenttext: First question, Jack, with all the securities in your capital structure trading so cheap, I know you've talked about pulling forward cash flows, what's your appetite here for potentially selling residuals, particularly in private student loans, so you can buy back debt and buy back stock here?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we think we have more attractive options available to us to raise liquidity to do both of those things at lower rates and better returns, ultimately, for shareholders. So I think selling residuals at this stage in the game is -- it's more attractive
componenttext: Well, we think we have more attractive options available to us to raise liquidity to do both of those things at lower rates and better returns, ultimately, for shareholders. So I think selling residuals at this stage in the game is -- it's more attractive, frankly, for us to hold those on our books than it is to sell them and to do financing transactions off of our unencumbered loan portfolio as well as our over-collateralization in our trust as an example.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And what's your optimism about your ability to do something in the near term in terms of securitizing some of those unencumbered assets?
componenttext: Okay. And what's your optimism about your ability to do something in the near term in terms of securitizing some of those unencumbered assets?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm very optimistic about it. I think both of these asset classes, particularly -- well, the unencumbered side of the equation is a well-worn path here in terms of how to get those deals done and an investor base that understands the cash flows and the st
componenttext: I'm very optimistic about it. I think both of these asset classes, particularly -- well, the unencumbered side of the equation is a well-worn path here in terms of how to get those deals done and an investor base that understands the cash flows and the structure of the deals. So that's really a function of more the organized time it takes to complete a transaction as you go through the series of mechanisms or rating agency reviews and process, et cetera, and underwriting the deal. On the over-collateralization -- financing against the over-collateralization in the trust, that's not something that's been done before, but it's really akin to financing whole loans in a conduit type of facility and something that we are very confident of our ability to pull off here.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And should we expect you're going to be focused more on securitizing your unencumbered private student loans rather than FFELP at this point?
componenttext: Okay. And should we expect you're going to be focused more on securitizing your unencumbered private student loans rather than FFELP at this point?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then how should we think about the use of that cash? Will most of that be -- go to just moving out your debt maturities? Or will there be some room to buy back stock as well from that?
componenttext: Okay. And then how should we think about the use of that cash? Will most of that be -- go to just moving out your debt maturities? Or will there be some room to buy back stock as well from that?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think a lot of this depends on what you're actually financing. So to the extent that you're financing cash flows that you would otherwise expect to be -- that would be financed with our unsecured debt today, clearly, those proceeds would go to repurchas
componenttext: I think a lot of this depends on what you're actually financing. So to the extent that you're financing cash flows that you would otherwise expect to be -- that would be financed with our unsecured debt today, clearly, those proceeds would go to repurchasing our unsecured debt maturities. Our goal -- our long-term goal here has been to -- and what we've actually accomplished has been to pay down our unsecured debt for the most part, but smooth it out. So we've been steady issuers in the unsecured arena over the last several years to flatten out our maturity profile there to better match our cash flows. At the same time, we've substantially reduced the amount of our unsecured debt outstanding and have continued to do so year-to-date in 2015. To the extent that we're financing and pulling in future earnings, that's where you'd really look to creating the capability of enhancing our stock repurchase program.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And then, finally, just one last question on the private student loan NIM. Could you give us a little better sense of why guidance on that is falling? What are the moving pieces here that are causing NIM to come in kind of below previous exp
componenttext: Okay, got it. And then, finally, just one last question on the private student loan NIM. Could you give us a little better sense of why guidance on that is falling? What are the moving pieces here that are causing NIM to come in kind of below previous expectations?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mark. The issue on the private NIM is just really, more than anything, a timing issue when our assets reset and when -- what our liabilities that fund those assets are tied to. So there was an expectation there that the prime -- our assets -- 2/3 of
componenttext: Sure, Mark. The issue on the private NIM is just really, more than anything, a timing issue when our assets reset and when -- what our liabilities that fund those assets are tied to. So there was an expectation there that the prime -- our assets -- 2/3 of our private portfolio is tied to the primary, which, as you know, had not increased and is typically tied to the Fed funds rate. And meanwhile, the underlying LIBOR rates have steadily increased. Once there's, call it, an increase in the primary, you will see a recovery in that spread between prime and LIBOR.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. But you're just not willing to call for that in the fourth quarter so you took the NIM down?
componenttext: Okay, got it. But you're just not willing to call for that in the fourth quarter so you took the NIM down?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Sanjay Sakhrani from KBW.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess following up on the NIM commentary switching over to FFELP. I would have thought you'd see a little bit more benefit from some of the cleanup calls. Could you just talk about how much of that's kind of factored into fourth quarter and what other p
componenttext: I guess following up on the NIM commentary switching over to FFELP. I would have thought you'd see a little bit more benefit from some of the cleanup calls. Could you just talk about how much of that's kind of factored into fourth quarter and what other pressures are factored into the FFELP NIM?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I do think the amount of bonds that we acquired during the cleanup call are a relatively small percentage compared to the total mix, so that's a bit of a -- it would be hard to move the entire spread item on that basis. And remember, this quarter, w
componenttext: Well, I do think the amount of bonds that we acquired during the cleanup call are a relatively small percentage compared to the total mix, so that's a bit of a -- it would be hard to move the entire spread item on that basis. And remember, this quarter, we also -- the NIM -- the FFELP NIM would have absorbed the $500 million expense result from the dispensing of the deferred financing costs in that -- in the NIM as well.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. That item effectively reduced the NIM by about 2 basis points, Sanjay.
componenttext: Yes. That item effectively reduced the NIM by about 2 basis points, Sanjay.

componenttext: Okay. And so that is going to be ongoing?

componenttext: Yes. And just if you think about it right, the $852 million of -- that we call represents less than 1% of our overall FFELP portfolio.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then I guess looking ahead, as far as the time line of events of important items, how should we think about what's on the horizon? I guess we would hear from the CFPB sometime soon. And then maybe if you can just talk about the relevance o
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then I guess looking ahead, as far as the time line of events of important items, how should we think about what's on the horizon? I guess we would hear from the CFPB sometime soon. And then maybe if you can just talk about the relevance of Moody's extending out the comment period talks over. When do we get a decision from them? Is it a constructive thing that they moved it out to October?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on the first point of the regulatory items, we have responded to the CFPB's listed issues, and we're now waiting to hear back from them. There's not a specific time frame for that process. But certainly, we're eager to engage and begin to resolve some
componenttext: So on the first point of the regulatory items, we have responded to the CFPB's listed issues, and we're now waiting to hear back from them. There's not a specific time frame for that process. But certainly, we're eager to engage and begin to resolve some of these items. I think it's important to note that several of the items here on this list are items that were previously covered through other regulatory settlements, particularly with the FDIC. Some items are related to Department of Ed policies and regulations. And to my earlier comments, we and borrowers, I think, would certainly benefit from a common understanding of regulators of what the rules and program terms and conditions should be. And some will just -- we will continue to work with them or items that we have addressed and changed in prior years, just as we continue to work with customers to make the process of managing their loans easier. On the legal final maturity date issue, I -- this is -- it's obviously a complicated issue and has lots of moving parts. But at the end of the day, we believe that borrower payments and cash flows coming off the student loan portfolios, while they did slow during that 2008 and 2013 period, were loss of various reasons, that the activities or the performance in those periods really don't form a baseline in which one should extrapolate off of. And that if you look at historical norms, and that is probably closer to what we're experiencing today, prepayment speeds for borrower loans are substantially higher than they were during that time frame. And when you run cash flows and expected borrower behavior off of those numbers, you do get very, very different results. And so having -- we would certainly rather the rating agencies take more time to evaluate the data and get a more comprehensive understanding of potential cash flows here and borrower behavior than to make a short-term answer or solution. So obviously, we'd like the issue resolved, but it's certainly better to have it resolved right or appropriately.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The final question, I know you guys talked extensively about how you could sell assets to buy back stock. But you also mentioned that you want to adhere to the tangible net asset ratio of 1.25x, and it's been hard to repurchase debt. I mean, is there anyt
componenttext: The final question, I know you guys talked extensively about how you could sell assets to buy back stock. But you also mentioned that you want to adhere to the tangible net asset ratio of 1.25x, and it's been hard to repurchase debt. I mean, is there anything that would preclude you from exhausting the share buyback or extending it further if you can't do the debt?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, obviously -- so our philosophy here in practice has been to as we generate excess capital, both through earnings and through the release of capital from the amortization of our loan portfolios, that, that would be returned to shareholders thro
componenttext: No. I mean, obviously -- so our philosophy here in practice has been to as we generate excess capital, both through earnings and through the release of capital from the amortization of our loan portfolios, that, that would be returned to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. I don't think anything has changed here on that side of the equation. Clearly, the current stock price would encourage us and makes it far more attractive for us to be more aggressive on that front. But that does require the ability to be able to issue in the unsecured markets to be able to smooth out our debt maturities. That's one of the things we're very eager to do. We believe that as we address some of the items that investors have, that we -- as I said are -- we -- I would describe them as being out of proportion, that you would see credit spreads continue to tighten as we have over last couple of weeks here and return to more normalized levels.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Moshe Orenbuch from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Moshe Orenbuch from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess just a follow-up on that stock buyback question. I guess it kind of looks like you've been doing in the neighborhood of $60 million a month through the Q3 and I guess a little faster on October because it's not a full month yet. I mean, I guess wh
componenttext: I guess just a follow-up on that stock buyback question. I guess it kind of looks like you've been doing in the neighborhood of $60 million a month through the Q3 and I guess a little faster on October because it's not a full month yet. I mean, I guess what factors -- which is -- and I guess probably slightly slower actually in dollars than you were doing previously. Is there any constraint in terms of the trading volumes of the stock?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, no. It's just really completing the allocation that we had at the $1 billion authorization from earlier this year.
componenttext: No, no. It's just really completing the allocation that we had at the $1 billion authorization from earlier this year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you kind of alluded to this in a previous question. But I mean, how should we think about from the issues related to the CFPB, the fact that perhaps some of the companies that the CFPB has examined and is looking at, at this report haven't dealt
componenttext: Okay. And you kind of alluded to this in a previous question. But I mean, how should we think about from the issues related to the CFPB, the fact that perhaps some of the companies that the CFPB has examined and is looking at, at this report haven't dealt with some of the regulatory bodies that you have? I mean, how do you think that influences the process as it goes forward?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, this is really the first time for us through that with the bureau, so I think that's really going to be a wait-and-see. We feel like we have outstanding controls and practices here to protect borrowers and service their loans appropriately. I think
componenttext: Well, this is really the first time for us through that with the bureau, so I think that's really going to be a wait-and-see. We feel like we have outstanding controls and practices here to protect borrowers and service their loans appropriately. I think the most important thing we do and the thing that we feel most strongly about is helping customers avoid default and the severe consequences of that. That means getting them into repayment programs they can afford. And as the Department of Ed default statistics illustrate here, we do this better than anybody. I mean, to take loans that are basically the same across all servicers and deliver a 38% lower default rate as -- those are the results people are looking for here, right, getting borrowers into programs they can afford. As I mentioned, some folks do believe that income-driven repayment is the ultimate solution. What we do is we really work with customers to let them understand the range of options that they have available to them, and they get to pick the one that fits their budget best. And 70% of our dollar volume is enrolled in an alternative payment program, which would include everything from income-driven repayment solutions to loan consolidation, which extends the loan term out. So these are the solutions that work for our customers and drive the substantially lower default rates. I think that's kind of how we've been working with the regulators in this. And if it means changing some of our practices to be -- to improve outcomes, we're all in on that.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I was struck by the fact that the GAO in their report pointed to the federal government for not advertising some of the repayment options as opposed to the servicers. I don't know, maybe you can kind of list those in the process and kind of r
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I was struck by the fact that the GAO in their report pointed to the federal government for not advertising some of the repayment options as opposed to the servicers. I don't know, maybe you can kind of list those in the process and kind of round that out a little better. [indiscernible]

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, we would argue here that there's a couple of things that need to happen. I mean, certainly encouraging borrowers to contact their servicers is something that we would like to see more of because when we do contact the customer and can con
componenttext: Well, certainly, we would argue here that there's a couple of things that need to happen. I mean, certainly encouraging borrowers to contact their servicers is something that we would like to see more of because when we do contact the customer and can connect with them, more than 9x out of 10, we're able to resolve that delinquency. And the other big issue here, which we have talked about before and I've written about, is simplification of the program. The share volume and terms of some of these repayment options can be very overwhelming to people who are not dealing with this day to day. It's hard for them to understand which program produces the best results for them. And if we can simplify then narrow then shrink them down into a fewer, but more simple programs to understand, I think everyone benefits from that.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And lastly, what I've got is, you made a comment that I thought was pretty interesting. You said that the acquisition of Xtend would be better than deploying cash in a share repurchase. Could you just talk a little bit about what the economics are and whe
componenttext: And lastly, what I've got is, you made a comment that I thought was pretty interesting. You said that the acquisition of Xtend would be better than deploying cash in a share repurchase. Could you just talk a little bit about what the economics are and whether there are other opportunities out there that could be comparable in that -- in the fee-based area?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we have -- sure, in that side. One of the things that we have looked at as we completed the separation is what are our core capabilities and how are those transferable into different areas or different asset classes. And in the asset recovery busine
componenttext: Well, we have -- sure, in that side. One of the things that we have looked at as we completed the separation is what are our core capabilities and how are those transferable into different areas or different asset classes. And in the asset recovery business services sector, this is an area where we have developed a very, very strong and successful track record of helping our customers manage their cash flows through either asset recovery or business processes types of things. And for years, our focus here was on educational loans almost exclusively. And we began to develop alternatives working with state agencies and municipalities. Somsak referenced the state tax amnesty program that we're running as an example. We've had long-standing contracts with a number of cities and states managing their receivables book. And we thought that there are a couple of places that we could go to expand our footprint and really put us in a place that we can grow rapidly on an organic basis off of that. Gila -- the acquisition of Gila earlier this year was one example of leveraging those skills and capabilities into a broader municipal arena and geographic areas where we were not strong to begin with. And Xtend does the same thing for us in a new area of health care payments. Our view here was that an acquisition in this space was really necessary for us to bring a resume to bear and -- but yet, the activities that they do are very, very similar to what we do with other asset classes and so bringing our scale, our data, sophistication and strategies to that process is something that we think will allow us to grow those businesses rapidly. And when you look at the opportunities there relative to share repurchases, that's where we do our math and understand what we can drive in terms of the economics. It's a better deal for shareholders, in our view, to allocate that capital to that acquisition than it is to do share repurchases. I want to be clear, however, that these are small -- relatively small acquisitions that help us build a footprint. It's not a -- our strategy is not to buy our -- buy these businesses through a series of acquisitions, but to build a footprint and grow organically.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Lee Cooperman with Omega Advisors.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Lee Cooperman with Omega Advisors.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's really more observations, philosophical rather than questions, but they're important to me. I think, if my numbers are right, that since the spin, we have spent $1.242 billion buying back 69 million shares in an average price of $18. And when you inc
componenttext: It's really more observations, philosophical rather than questions, but they're important to me. I think, if my numbers are right, that since the spin, we have spent $1.242 billion buying back 69 million shares in an average price of $18. And when you increased about the repurchase program, I think the response in the company generally has been that you believe the net asset value is in the area of $22 or $23, and repurchasing to make sense. We agree with that, by the way. That number is $23. If we still believe that, we would urge you to find ways of being creative to raise additional funds, double down or triple down. I think you're in sympathy with that, but we will just urge you. There's no better use of shareholder money than buying something back at $0.50 and a dollar, particularly in this environment where there's very few things selling at $0.50 and a dollar. So that's kind of an advocacy question -- not a question, but an advocacy statement. Second, I noticed recently that a company by name of Winthrop Realty announced the intention to liquidate. And when I called the CEO -- I was not a shareholder in the company. When I called the CEO I knew, I asked him what motivated him. He said he felt that the prospect of him getting the stock to sell at the net asset value that he believed the company had was so remote that he felt the best thing to do is to liquidate the company, return the money to shareholders. And kind of a theme out of that book, you deal with many regulators, some of which have conflicting views. We're living with constant criticism and a hostile environment despite the social good you do for the people that borrow money from you. Has the Board considered the advice of liquidating the company by going into a runoff and returning the money to shareholders so they can invest in companies that are more appreciated by shareholders or the government? And so that's kind of a philosophical question. And third, your comment, I thought, was very interesting. I have no problem with the Xtend acquisition. Companies cannot repurchase stock at a success, you got to grow the business. But when you said that it's more accretive than stock repurchase, I would probably challenge that because, essentially, when you buy back stock, you're probably looking at the earnings per share impact of what earnings we got versus the cost of money, et cetera. But in the stock repurchase, you're retiring a 5% dividend and you're capturing a $9 discount to NAV. And obviously, as you retire more shares at a $9 discount to NAV, then NAV goes up. So I'm not sure you're calculating correctly the virtue of Xtend versus a stock repurchase. But that's not a big deal because I think you're trying to grow the company. So those are just observations. I don't know if you want to comment on them, but I'll leave them up to you. But we're very supportive of management. That's not a complaint, just an observation.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lee. We definitely agree with your first point. And we are working hard to find those creative alternatives to allow us to do more and more both in -- 2 things are on sale here, right, at both the debt and the share price. And so we are aggress
componenttext: Thank you, Lee. We definitely agree with your first point. And we are working hard to find those creative alternatives to allow us to do more and more both in -- 2 things are on sale here, right, at both the debt and the share price. And so we are aggressively working on both of those. And one of the unique parts of our business is if we can finance assets through an ABS transaction, we're able to raise funds substantially cheaper than our cost of debt in the unsecured arena, and so it's an easy arbitrage to take advantage of and one that would like to do -- see more of that. Same is true on the share repurchase side. I do want to spend a little bit of time on your -- just on your comment about the liquidation issue here. The value -- the franchise value of this company is really anchored in the cash flows coming from the student loan portfolios, and I would say the regulatory issues are coming from our service -- the servicing of student loans. The -- in effect, not because we chose this, it was chosen by Congress, we are liquidating our student loan holdings. They're amortizing portfolio. No new FFELP loans are being created. And those loans will -- those portfolios will go to 0 over time, and our job is to maximize the earnings of that portfolio. We think we can -- we're doing that. And running the operation on that side of the equation is frankly not a whole lot different in either kind of alternative structure. On the servicing side of the equation, there's no question that as a business, we do a great job in this space, and we deliver value for our customers and taxpayers in the results that we generate. If the regulatory environment is not going to allow that business to work and be profitable, then it's not an attractive business, and that is certainly something we would take a look at. We need to work with the regulators today to resolve this -- the open issues with the state agencies and the CFPB, and we're going to do that. And a big part of our strategy is really about driving and producing the results that all, including the regulators, are looking for here. But that's a to-be-determined opportunity for sure.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I will be willing to take a higher cost temporarily on issuing unsecured debt to buy an asset back at $0.50 and a dollar. And the only thing -- just to keep your feet to the fire a little bit [indiscernible] you guys, but in the second quarter of 20
componenttext: Well, I will be willing to take a higher cost temporarily on issuing unsecured debt to buy an asset back at $0.50 and a dollar. And the only thing -- just to keep your feet to the fire a little bit [indiscernible] you guys, but in the second quarter of 2015, we spent $300 million at $19.76. In the first quarter of 2015, we spent $300 million at $20.52, okay? If we spent $300 million -- $600 million at the $20 level, we should be spending $1 billion at this level. That's all, but pretty easy for me to do the 20 -- hindsight is 2020, but we should just find a way of being more aggressive down here because we're on sale.

componenttextpreview: Right, I agree. Thank you.
componenttext: Right, I agree. Thank you.

componenttextpreview: I think the issue here is more about a more -- a functioning marketplace. I think investors are looking for some clarity in the process, and there are a couple of tools that we have available to us where -- that we think will tighten spreads here that are
componenttext: I think the issue here is more about a more -- a functioning marketplace. I think investors are looking for some clarity in the process, and there are a couple of tools that we have available to us where -- that we think will tighten spreads here that are -- it's cheaper for us to pursue opportunities to finance off of our assets than it is to finance in the unsecured, and both produce the same net proceed types of things. And once we can demonstrate that and do it, I think the unsecured spread has tightened again. Our goal here, as I said earlier, is to spread those maturities out, so we would -- we -- all else being equal, we plan to be an issuer in the unsecured arena. And the sooner those spreads can return to a level that we think is more appropriate, that's when we would be back in the marketplace.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

componenttext: So payee as an expansion is yet another income-driven repayment solution, and the primary benefit of this program is going to be to customers who are new to repayment. So there are income-driven repayment options available under FFELP. We certainly would see -- expect to see some accounts consolidate into direct lending to capture that program, but the benefits of it are not -- if you've been paying your loan for 5 years, you are far better off working through the repayment options available to you in FFELP than you would be to start over again and repay.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: It just seems apparent to me that you guys don't have a cash flow issue, but it's a timing of cash flow concern that the unsecured markets seem to have. And Jack, you talked about it earlier, either several things that seem to have come together all at on
componenttext: It just seems apparent to me that you guys don't have a cash flow issue, but it's a timing of cash flow concern that the unsecured markets seem to have. And Jack, you talked about it earlier, either several things that seem to have come together all at one time from a headline perspective that I think made, perhaps, bondholders nervous and also some stockholders nervous expecting the selloff. And it seems like to a certain extent, with the bond spread are widened out that's also resulted in kind of a cycle where the stock has held up as well just because people wonder if the bond market is nervous, then we should be nervous as well. So I was just curious, in terms of trying to figure out the chain of events going forward, I mean, clearly, we find out Moody's what their thinking is, but you've announced they're showing pretty clearly that you have the cash flows, they comfortably lead the legal maturity dates and also, cash flows over time to meet your unsecured debt maturities, and yet none of that seems to matter. So what I was curious about, and I've asks the question a little bit differently from what Lee was asking earlier, rather than going to liquidation, in your discussions with fixed income investors, is the concern here in the widening of credit spreads for you guys more a function of some concern that you might split the company up into some sort of servicing and asset management business, such that credit spreads -- that would explain the spread widening? Is there a concern that maybe you take the company private, given all the headline risks that are out there? And is that something you would contemplate? Just help me get your thinking around that because something here doesn't seem to add up. So just your thoughts would be helpful here.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I think the items that were on the table, both the legal final maturity and the regulatory step create, where the outcome is unclear, that uncertainty creates the opportunity for the events that you just described to happen. Some of th
componenttext: Well, first of all, I think the items that were on the table, both the legal final maturity and the regulatory step create, where the outcome is unclear, that uncertainty creates the opportunity for the events that you just described to happen. Some of those were certainly interpreted by some incorrectly, so there was a view earlier on that it's early in the process, that the legal final maturity date issue would cause us to spend liquidity that would otherwise be used to service our unsecured debt to clean up those asset-backed calls. I think we've clearly explained that, that is not the case, as an example. And as we've kind of responded to the -- some of the thesis here and items, I think you're seeing both our credit spreads tighten and our stock price improve. Our goal and objective is, of course, to produce the outcomes that -- and make sure people understand the outcomes that are likely to occur here. And that's what we've been working on, on both the legal final maturity and the regulatory cost side of the equation. But we do need those items to resolve before I think you get back to completely normal. I did -- as I mentioned in the beginning of the call, one of the challenges we're facing is even though it's attractive for us to buy back debt, it's difficult for us to get any kind of meaningful volume here. And that I think tells you a little bit about how -- where the fixed income investors are, they see the same value that we do and therefore, are unwilling to sell.
